HEADLINE: LVMH Reports Record Profit for 2000 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: PARIS, March 7 

 BODY:
The world's leading luxury goods group, LVMH- Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton of France, reported record revenue and profit for 2000 today, but warned of more difficult conditions in 2001 because of slowing growth prospects in major economies, most notably in North America.
 After a two-year acquisition spree, the company said it would focus more on strengthening its cash flow and easing the burden of acquisition-related debt. 
 The results came the day before a ruling was expected from a Dutch commercial court in a legal battle that pits LVMH against another big French retailer, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, for control of the Gucci fashion house. LVMH indicated that the outcome of the suit could result in a bid by LVMH for all of Gucci. 
Disappointed at the dimmed prospects for 2001, and perhaps fearing that LVMH has bitten off too much, investors bid down the company's stock price by 5 percent before a slight recovery late in the trading day to close at 63.05 euros ($58.94) a share. The stock has slumped more than 30 percent since August.
LVMH said that though it expected double-digit growth in revenue and operating income this year, the 13 percent rate in the first two months of 2001 was a considerable drop-off from the 35 percent rate it posted in the corresponding period last year.
Figures for operating profit last year were stronger, rising 27 percent, to 1.95 billion euros ($1.82 billion), in 2000 on a 35 percent increase in revenue, to 11.58 billion euros. The cost of servicing 7 billion euros in debt held net profit down to a 4 percent rise, to 722 million euros, in 2000.
Bernard Arnault, the flamboyant French billionaire who has built up LVMH over the last 15 years, said he expected revenue growth to slow in the first half-year because of morose American sentiment toward the economy. But he said experience showed that LVMH tended to gain market share during downturns. 
In the last two years, LVMH has spent over $3 billion acquiring a stable of brands including Fendi and Emilio Pucci of Italy and Donna Karan in the United States. But the big prize Mr. Arnault has sought, Gucci, has so far eluded him.
The court in Amsterdam is expected to respond on Thursday to a request by LVMH that it order an investigation of a $3 billion deal in 1999 that gave Pinault control of Gucci. That deal, which pitted Mr. Arnault against another French billionaire, Francois Pinault, sliced a considerable stake that LVMH had amassed in Gucci to only 20 percent. LVMH hopes a favorable decision will force Mr. Pinault to negotiate a deal over Gucci; failing that, Mr. Arnault suggested that bank financing would be available for LVMH to bid for all of Gucci.
The Dutch case is just one in a web of disputes surrounding Gucci, which has filed an antitrust complaint against LVMH with the European Commission. LVMH has also complained to American securities regulators over stock options that LVMH says Gucci illicitly provided to its chief executive and other top managers. 
But LVMH management has also been following a lawsuit and a grand jury proceeding in California involving the French bank Credit Lyonnais, Mr. Pinault and others, who are accused of defrauding the state in connection with the purchase of a portfolio of junk bonds. LVMH is evidently hoping that rulings unfavorable to Mr. Pinault in California could add to the pressure on him to seek an accommodation over Gucci.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bernard Arnault, right, the chairman of LVMH, and Myron Ullman III, the general director, reported company results yesterday in Paris. (Agence France-Presse)

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 37

LENGTH: 4663 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ABCD: A COLLECTION OF ART BRUT," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 977-7170 (through July). Memorably vivid and widely abused, the phrase Art Brut (meaning raw or rough art) was coined in the 1940's by the French artist Jean Dubuffet. This exhibition, drawn from the holdings of a Paris-based foundation, attempts to reinstate his original meaning, revisiting the amazing pantheon of artists who inspired it and proposing some additions. Its many highlights include works by acknowledged greats like Adolf Wolfli, Aloise Corbaz, Henry Darger and Augustin Lesage, but the show also introduces many equally riveting artists unfamiliar to American audiences. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Roberta Smith).

GEORGES ADEAGBO, "Abraham: L'Ami de Dieu," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through March 30). Mr. Adeagbo, born in Benin in 1942, is making his United States debut with a rich, deceptively low-key installation that resembles an African outdoor market, a New York City sidewalk sale and a personal archive in the process of being sorted. Hundreds of objects are neatly arranged on the floor and walls: paintings, secondhand books, record albums, African sculptures and magazines, many of which the artist gathered in New York, sent to Africa, then brought back for the show, reversing the global itinerary of African art centuries ago. And what do they all add up to? A myth-laden history of the world, of art and of African and American culture circa 1960. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2, students and 60+ (Holland Cotter).

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; as well as spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded by elegance, economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Smith).

* "COMMITTED TO THE IMAGE: CONTEMPORARY BLACK PHOTOGRAPHERS," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through April 29). This sharply installed survey of 94 artists covers several decades of work, much of it by a generation of photographers who came of age in the 1960's and 70's. The pictures are sorted by broad themes (people, beauty, family, religion, etc.), and formal polish tends to predominate over conceptual grit. The terrain is, over all, unsensational ordinary life, with the heat now and then turned up high. Images of urban churchgoers, Louisiana sugar cane cutters, the magnetic Billie Holiday and children in African refugee camps sit side by side. The eclectic array has its share of bland entries, but there are dozens of wonderful artists here, and their collective spirit is persuasive. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 am. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of the month). Admission: $4; $2, students and 62+ (Cotter).

* "CORREGGIO AND PARMIGIANINO: MASTER DRAFTSMEN OF THE RENAISSANCE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through May 6). This copious and beautiful exhibition has nearly 130 drawings by two artists who were aligned in time, geography and, briefly, style in the third decade of the 16th century. Correggio, who blew the roof off Renaissance illusionism with the ecstatic ceiling paintings that he made in Parma in the 1520's, is represented by a room of exquisite mostly red-chalk studies that reflect a penchant for brazen foreshortening, glowing light and atmospheric sfumato; they also attest to a sensuousness that can seem more proto-Rococo than Proto-Baroque. The two galleries of Parmigianino's drawings seem true to his Mannerist sensibility. A searching restlessness is evident in the constant shifts in medium, style and subject, in the considerations of other artists' work (including Correggio's), in the pensive self-portraits and portraits and most of all in several drawings that layer together unrelated motifs. So is a relatively new notion for his time: drawing for the sake of drawing. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Smith).

"THE GLOBAL GUGGENHEIM: SELECTIONS FROM THE EXTENDED COLLECTION," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through April 22). Of the big permanent collection shows that have been taking up so much space, the Guggenheim's is the last. It's also the coolest, the prettiest, the least programmatic and the most conservative. Despite the "global" spin of the title, this is strictly a Euro-American affair. And thanks to the eye of the curator, Carmen Gimenez, it is a very beautiful one. The great Wright spiral feels freshly swept out; the bays are sparingly hung; and dozens of top-notch works, including a few from the Hermitage in St. Petersburg and Guggenheim branches abroad, have been paired and grouped to ignite free-associational sparks. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 am. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "ANDREAS GURSKY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). The giant pictures in this mid-career retrospective of Mr. Gursky, the 46-year-old German photographer, are so eye-poppingly, drop-dead gorgeous that in this world, where no good turn goes unpunished, you may feel compelled to react with suspicion and reserve. But knee-jerk resistance at the sight of the nondescript global emblems of new capitalist sprawl that Mr. Gursky photographs is short-circuited by sheer awe at the incredible, sublimely weird, almost erotic glamour he imparts to them. The work is instantly attractive to the point of alarm, which is the feeling of falling in love. You might as well give yourself over to it and worry about the consequences later. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; until 8:15 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* THE MARY AND MICHAEL JAHARIS GALLERIES OF BYZANTINE ART AND THE GALLERY OF EARLY MEDIEVAL ART, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Dec. 31). The new galleries for the Met's superb holdings in Byzantine and early medieval art exemplify inward expansion at its best. The refurbished hallway galleries beside the Grand Staircase are now entered through a beautiful little brick-lined Crypt Gallery (carved out of former storage space) and completed by a recently rediscovered apselike space. The configuration seems tailor-made for works that reflect the first flowering of Christian art, from stone carvings from fourth-century Egyptian monasteries to a larger-than-life wood crucifix from 12th-century Italy. It also has intricately carved ivories, vivid enamels, graffitoed ceramics, jewelry and textiles. It adds another jewel to an already heavy crown. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* "KENNETH JOSEPHSON: A RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through May 27). The first full-scale career assessment for one of the earliest and most inventive explorers of photography's character and the issues of perception and representation that it raises. In the 1960's, when Mr. Josephson began commenting on it, the truthfulness of photography was still a myth with a powerful hold on the imagination. Best of all, his philosophizing is often served up with a generous portion of wit. Much of his work has never been exhibited, and he is not nearly so well known as he deserves to be. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Vicki Goldberg).

* PAUL McCARTHY, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through May 13). From his far-out position where the psychic security of Hollywood's packaging of sex and violence doesn't exist, Mr. McCarthy taps veins deep in the collective unconscious, far beyond where most shock artists have the audacity or intelligence to operate. Mr. McCarthy has been a cultish presence in Los Angeles for years, and his moment has finally come in New York with this retrospective and shows at Luhring Augustine in Chelsea; Deitch Projects in SoHo; and, in collaboration with the Public Art Fund, at the public atrium on the northwest corner of 56th Street and Madison Avenue. We see an artist of wild highs and lows, of black comedy, cheap jokes, unspeakable actions, dry formalism and some real fiascos, the mark of an artist risking failure, a good sign. There is something beyond mere Pop parody or social provocation in the work, something to do with deep private needs and desires, which we perceive secondhand as comic pathos. It is art as tough therapy, disturbingly honest. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, artists, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "NINETEENTH- AND 20TH-CENTURY CHINESE PAINTINGS FROM THE ROBERT H. ELLSWORTH COLLECTION, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Aug. 19). The 19th and 20th centuries were shattering times for China, bringing wars, civil violence and the fall of an empire. In art, old forms survived and flourished but also changed. This exhibition surveys how elite painting traditions developed for a new audience and under Western influences from 1850 to 1980. Among the highlights is a group of paintings by Qi Baishi (1864-1957), deservedly one of the most popular of all Chinese artists. The big news is that a major museum has quietly taken a firm stand on modern art in Asia, seeing it not as a postscript to a great tradition but as an integral, living part of the continuum. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "PERFECTING MANKIND: EUGENICS AND PHOTOGRAPHY," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through March 18). A timely exercise wildly disproportionate in significance to its size, this one-room show tackles the complicated story of photography's supporting role in eugenics, the pseudoscience of human breeding. Via 19th-century composite portraits of Jews, snapshots of "Fitter Family" and "Perfect Baby" contest winners and early Nazi photographs of Aryans, it tracks the arc of eugenics' popularity, an object lesson for this era of genetic engineering. And it shows the dubious results of an unreflective faith in technological science, in this case the new technology of photography, which seemed at the time a reliable instrument of reason. The exhibition is a reminder that photographs almost always say less than people think or want, and sometimes precious little except about the prejudices of the viewer. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

"JEAN POYET: ARTIST TO THE COURT OF RENAISSANCE FRANCE," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through May 6). His reputation as one of the great manuscript illuminators of the Renaissance has declined over the centuries, with much of his work ascribed to others, but the French artist Jean Poyet (ca. 1445-1503) is re-established in this beautiful show as the true author of some well-known Books of Hours and other religious treasures. His use of perspective, color, light and shadow and his convincing representations of the human figure took his work well beyond the limitations of his Late Gothic predecessors, as seen in such powerful manuscripts as the "Missal of Guillaume Lallemant" and "The Hours of Henry VIII." The judicious use of lightbox transparencies, blown-up color photographs and a CD-ROM room where viewers can turn the pages of virtual manuscripts all add to the show's accessibility. It is one of the season's most impressive presentations. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

"THE THINGS THEMSELVES: PICTURES OF DUST BY VIK MUNIZ," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through May 20). Never have dust motes been such a presence in art. Using as his medium grit gleaned from the Whitney's galleries and offices, Mr. Muniz made drawings from photographs of Miminalist and post-Minimalist sculptures and paintings exhibited at the museum over 30 years. Then he photographed the drawings and enlarged them so that the results are reproductions of reproductions. The dust -- plainly observable as strands and mats of hair, flecks of paper, flakes of dirt and fragments of pebbles -- blurs the hard-edge outlines of the sculptures, putting one in mind of aging movie stars photographed through filters. It can also have a dramatic effect, as in the case of one Robert Morris installation whose hazy black-and-white bleakness suggests the stark ruins of a future city. Mr. Muniz claims that his copies ask the viewer to look harder at the originals -- but which originals? Perplexing as it may be, his photograph-drawings are originals too. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

* "THE TREASURY OF BASEL CATHEDRAL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 27). The jewel-embellished gold and silver liturgical objects and reliquaries in this show exist on some exotic outer fringe of beauty, where the crass and the ineffable meet. Together they have a cliffhanger of a tale to tell, as frustrating as it is uplifting. (They were preserved as an ensemble until Basel city politics intervened in the 19th century.) There's the rarity factor: almost none of the 75 works have visited the United States before. And it's hard to remember the last time anything quite like their single-minded incandescence radiated from a local museum. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "VAN GOGH'S POSTMAN: THE PORTRAITS OF JOSEPH ROULIN," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). This revelatory microexhibition reunites five portraits of the postal worker Joseph Roulin, whom van Gogh met while living in Arles in the south of France. The show affords an excellent opportunity to study the painter's craft as he processes a single motif through a series of approaches from painterly naturalism to richly patterned symbolism. It is fascinating as well to see the portraits in light of the biographical background. Roulin cared for van Gogh after the famous ear-cutting incident, and he grew in the artist's imagination from an amusing local character to a figure of Christ-like benevolence. Hours and admission: See above. (Ken Johnson).

Galleries: Uptown

* "WOMEN DESIGNERS IN THE U.S.A., 1900-2000: DIVERSITY AND DIFFERENCE," Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, Design and Culture, 18 West 86th Street, (212) 501-3000 (through April 8). At the turn of the 20th century, female designers were mostly white, middle-class and skilled in "female" pursuits; today their ethnicity is widely diversified, and they have made enormous progress in fields once open only to men. Architecture, landscaping, interiors, furniture, textiles, apparel, posters, tableware, wallpaper, ceramics, lighting, jewelry, floor coverings, silverware, doors for cars, costumes and industrial products are represented in this bountiful show, which shoehorns some 220 objects into three floors of tight gallery space. Works by American Indians and African-Americans are given special attention (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

* OSKAR KOKOSCHKA, "Memorial Exhibition," Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, (212) 541-4900 (through March 17). This show is a continual reminder that Kokoschka, who died in 1980 at 93, gave his whole self, without evasion and without stint, in everything he did. It begins with his portraits of the composers Webern (1914) and Schoenberg (1925); continues with his big cityscapes, with their attention to telling detail; and makes a strong case for his late watercolors, in which the image is briskly defined and the color has an irresistible energy. This hand never shook (John Russell).

* "OUR BEAUTIFUL AND TORMENTED AUSTRIA: ART BRUT IN THE LAND OF FREUD," Galerie St. Etienne, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 245-6734 (through March 17). This extraordinary show introduces the recently discovered work of two self-taught Viennese artists: Emanuel Navratil (1875-1956), who made large colored-pencil drawings that transform his native city into a magical kingdom of fantasy architecture, intricate pattern and bourgeois contentment; and Josef Karl Radler (1844-1917), a retired porcelain painter whose fusions of writing and painting infuse scenes of the hospital where he spent his final years with a power akin to illuminated manuscripts (Smith).

Galleries: Chelsea

BRIAN ALFRED, Max Protetch, 511 West 22nd Street, (212) 633-6999 (through March 24). A current minitrend has some young painters using tape to stencil hard-edged, 60s-style acrylic pictures of the modern built environment. Mr. Alfred, having his first solo exhibition, is an adept practitioner of the genre. The cheerful neo-Pop surfaces of his pictures of a building being demolished, a swimming pool or a great suspension bridge mask rueful emotions about utopian modernism (Johnson).

ROBERT F. HAMMERSTIEL, Cristinerose, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 206-0297 (through March 31). This Austrian photographer focuses on the dog industry to critique capitalism. Photographs of dog leashes alternate with small mug shots of dog owners. Each in a series of thin boxes displays a dog portrait and an actual syringe used for inserting identification microchips under the animal's skin. This may sound like a parody of some kind of neo-Marxist Conceptualism, but it is not particularly funny. Perhaps Mr. Hammerstiel is serious: that would be funny (Johnson).

BEVERLY SEMMES, Leslie Tonkonow, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-8450 (through April 14). An artist known for her sculptures in the form of gigantically oversize women's clothing, here presents something monumental and absurd but abstract: a great, vaguely fecal mound of convoluted, fat, stuffed tubes of electric green nylon. Gallery personnel are wearing overalls made from the same material, which creates a mysterious sense of industrial purpose (Johnson).

LEON TARASEWICZ, Gary Tatintsian, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 633-0110 (through March 31). Mr. Tarasewicz, selected to represent Poland in the Venice Biennale later this year, paints brushy stripe compositions on canvas and, more interestingly, turns whole galleries into striped environments. Here fuzzy brown stripes alternating with blue, white or green wrap around a series of thick partitions and cover one wall, creating an enveloping interplay of Minimalist structure and humming painterly surface (Johnson).

"THEM!" Jay Grimm, 505 West 28th Street, (212) 564-7662 (through March 17). The most interesting items in this curiously didactic show about some of the least favorite animals are not artworks but actual exotic insects collected, mounted and framed by Bob Natalini. Otherwise, there are round photographic portraits of ants by Bill Scanga; nice washy watercolors of a praying mantis and a ladybug by Emilie Clark; and Shane Hope's strange, funky miniature assemblages with insectoid elements emerging from the gallery's electrical receptacles (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

CHRIS MARTIN, Malca, 580 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-8854 (through March 31) and at Sideshow, 319 Bedford Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 486-8180 (through March 19). Mr Martin is a perennially interesting and admirably unfashionable painter. At Malca, a canvas measuring 10 by 36 feet and bearing a stack of white rectangles topped by a flying-saucer-like form, looks like a giant sign made by a nonartist who had a close encounter of the third kind. At Sideshow, pictures of orange or yellow boxes against sky blue fields are richer as paintings and transcendentally suggestive as images (Johnson).

ERIN O'KEEFE AND VINCENT SZAREK, Sandra Gering, 476 Broome Street, (212) 226-8195 (through March 24). Two sculptors each combine Minimalist structure and lush material: Ms. O'Keefe arranges colored blocks and mirrors in boxes behind squares of frosted glass, creating blurry, spatially ambiguous compositions. Mr. Szarek, borrowing from custom-car culture, fabricates sleek undulating wall works with glossy automotive paint jobs; one beauty sports a sumptuous candy cherry red metalflake coating (Johnson).

ROBERT SCHMID, Sears-Peyton, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-7469 (through March 31). With sensitive, assiduous craft, Mr. Schmid paints small-scale copies of blurred, smeared, double-exposed or otherwise distorted snapshots of people, city streets and natural landscapes, which were taken with a defective camera. He organizes these images into gridded compositions that have a moody cinematic quality (Johnson).

Other Galleries

DENNIS OPPENHEIM, Ace Gallery, 275 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 255-5599 (through March 24). This medium-size, occasionally amusing survey of Mr. Oppenheim's work is what you would expect: a fun-house mixture of documentary photographs, booming electronics, videos, cockamamie sculpture and installations. The art is, at heart, about how hard it is to make art. Among the early works is a mechanized marionette, "Attempt to Raise Hell" (1974), a self-portrait that smashes its head into a big cast-iron bell. Frustration, anger and violence have been his creative touchstones, along with a sense of humor. His legacy is to have turned futility into a medium, a singular plan, sometimes effective but often not memorable enough visually (Kimmelman).

Last Chance

"A WINTER GROUP OF ARTIST COUPLES," Katharina Rich Perlow, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-7171 (through tomorrow). It is not a new idea, but it is always interesting to compare works by two artists who are (or were) a couple. This 22-artist show includes Abstract Expressionist paintings by James Brooks and Charlotte Parks; a squiggly drawing by Willem de Kooning and a slashing painting by Elaine de Kooning; and an elegant Constructivist-style drawing by Joel Shapiro with a delicately misty painting of a blue vase by Ellen Phelan (Johnson).

* NELL BLAINE, "The Abstract Work," Tibor de Nagy, 724 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street, (212) 262-5050 (through tomorrow). This terrific show displays the astoundingly accomplished biomorphic abstractions that Blaine painted in the 1940's, when she was barely 20 and fresh off the train from Richmond, Va. They reflect study with Hans Hofmann, love of jazz, Leger, Mondrian and a prodigious talent. They should also sharpen one's appreciation of the formal rigor of the rapturous landscapes and garden views that Blaine painted from the late 1950's to her death in 1997, and underscore that this extraordinary artist is ripe for re-evaluation (Smith).

SARAH BEDFORD, JEANNE LORENZ AND AMY WILSON, Bellwether Gallery, 150 Franklin Street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 389-3213 (through Sunday). The unstated theme of this show is Americana run decorously amok. Ms. Bedford's collagelike bad-dream visions of bugs, plants, geometric patterns and Currier & Ives sleigh rides are the most elaborate entries. Ms. Lorenz, in large grisaille watercolors, transforms winsome porcelain figurines from eBay auctions into bug-eyed mutants. Ms. Wilson also works in watercolor. In paintings the size of pages in children's books, she uses pleasing colors, draftsmanly finesse and wide-ranging research to chart the sinister inner workings of the military-industrial complex (Cotter).

* BODY AND THE EAST: FROM THE 1960'S TO THE PRESENT, Exit Art/The Third World, 548 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 966-7745 (through tomorrow). Organized in 1998 by the Museum of Modern Art in Ljubljana, Slovenia, this exhibition surveys the body and performance work of some 100 artists or artists' collectives from 14 former Soviet bloc countries. It represents a tremendous effort of retrieval, adds many new names, locations and artworks to the constantly expanding map of postwar art and offers further proof that American and Western European artists did not and do not act alone (Smith).

"HANDS ACROSS THE SEA," Phyllis Kind Gallery, 136 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 925-1200 (through Thursday). Arranged in a series of telling, often surprising comparisons between American and European self-taught artists, this exhibition demonstrates that there is plenty of reason to stretch Jean Dubuffet's original definition of Art Brut beyond its original European perimeter (Smith).

RICHARD NONAS, "Sophia Maria and the Indians," Lawrence Markey, 42 East 76th Street, (212) 517-9892 (through tomorrow). Carefully placed in this gallery's square white room, the simple, rough-hewn wooden sculptures by a veteran Minimalist create a slowed-down, contemplative ambience. An inclined plane of heavy beams; a saw-tooth pattern cut into a thick plank; an X made of intersecting blocks: these Brancusian objects encourage a calming attention to elemental facts of light, space and structure (Johnson).

BILL OWENS, Paul Morris, 465 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2752 (through tomorrow). Mr. Owens published his famous and enthralling book "Suburbia" in 1973, but he continued his sharp-eyed documentation of suburban culture into the early 80's. This show presents large color prints from the series, including the images of a pretty young woman with big hair snorting coke in a restroom and a beautiful picture of a swimming pool titled "Hockney Painted This Pool" (Johnson).

"POETRY PLASTIQUE," Marianne Boesky Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 680-9889 (through tomorrow). Art and poetry: made for each other. Poets write about art; artists turn to poetry for ideas. Sometimes the two disciplines meet in collaboration. Such meetings are the subject of this show, in which image and word are flexibly intertwined. Organized by the poet Charles Bernstein and Jay Sanders, it covers a stretch of recent historical ground, from word-peppered Blakean drawings by Robert Smithson from 1962 to work by Mira Schor, Richard Tuttle and Susan Bee from last year. When the gallery was host to a series of related panel discussions and readings, the buzz of voices and ideas made the art feel alive and interactive. Some of the pieces really need that charge; others do fine on their own. Certainly the cross-disciplinary concept behind the show is ripe for further exploration (Cotter).

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES; 
A Dynasty In Which Pottery Ruled

BYLINE:  By Wendy Moonan 

 BODY:
The Tang dynasty (A.D. 618 to 906) was unlike any other era in China, or in the world for that matter. It was a time of peace, prosperity and thriving international trade.
 "The Tang Empire was very powerful and very rich," said Khalil Rizk, director of the Chinese Porcelain Company in Manhattan. "It had a mighty army." Its borders stretched from the Caspian Sea in the west to Korea in the east, and from Manchuria in the north to Vietnam. 
 Like Constantinople, the Tang capital city of Changan (the modern Xian) had two million inhabitants, about what it has today. The government supported a large class of Confucian literati who served as civil servants and ran the country well. The crime rate was at an all-time low, with prisons reportedly empty. Inflation was under control. The poor had enough rice to eat and the ability to pay taxes.
"It was one of the most sophisticated periods of Chinese history," said Theow H. Tow, Christie's international director of Chinese ceramics and works of art. "China attracted Persians, Indians and Jews. Last summer they found the site of a seventh-century Christian church, so there were already Christians there, too."
The silk route opened China to foreign ideas, religions, culture and lifestyles. Foreign merchants established markets in Changan to sell exotic spices and aromatics, camels, horses, tropical birds, jewelry, ivory and furs.
"The Chinese tended to be inward-looking," Mr. Tow said. "The Tang is one of the few dynasties that looked outward."
The first 137 years of the dynasty were also a golden age for Chinese art. "Nowhere else in the world were they making better pottery at the time," Mr. Rizk said. Tang potters made elegant earthenware vessels for everyday use and sculptures for tombs, including the Tang horses and camels so prized in the West. 
The potters also created figurines representing exotic foreigners, with their odd physiognomy, costume and customs. "Sometimes the depictions of foreigners were like caricatures," Mr. Tow said. Horse grooms, for example, could have had wildly curly hair, bushy beards, big noses or bulging eyes.
Many of the Tang ceramics on the market today are tomb sculptures and vessels. The Chinese did not hedge their bets. They planned for the afterlife years in advance, buying hundreds of pottery figures and sculptures.
"The princes, princesses, wealthy ministers and distinguished nobles surrounded themselves with all the extravagances that money could buy, not only in life, but also in death," wrote the Chinese ceramics scholar Margaret Medley in a 1989 catalog for a show at the Dixon Gallery in Memphis, "Tang Sancai Pottery From the Collection of Alan and Simone Hartman."
Forty-eight pieces from the Hartman exhibition will be auctioned at Christie's in New York on March 20. The preview begins on Tuesday. "It's a good snapshot of life at the time," Mr. Tow said.
Mr. Hartman, who owns Rare Art Inc., a Manhattan gallery specializing in British and American silver and Chinese art, said that he and his wife, Simone, had collected Tang ceramics for 30 years and that he hoped to sell his pottery to one institution or collector for $1.3 million. If one buyer does not reach his reserve price, the collection will be sold in individual lots.
The Hartmans' pottery is all sancai (meaning three-colored) glazed earthenware in the colors of straw and amber (made from iron oxide) and green (from copper oxide). Sancai usually also includes blue glaze, which is rarer and was made from oxides with imported cobalt.
Other Tang sculptures are for sale in Sotheby's Chinese Ceramics and Works of Art auction on March 22. In addition, Mark Richards, a Los Angeles dealer, and Alberto Manuel Cheung, a private dealer in Manhattan, are bringing Tang ceramics to the Arts of Pacific Asia Show at the 69th Regiment Armory at Lexington Avenue and 26th Street, from March 22 to 25.
Mr. Cheung is selling a figure of a Tang woman playing a polo-like game on a horse whose legs are outstretched, similar to one exhibited last year at the International Museum of the Horse in Lexington, Ky. Nicholas Grindley, a London dealer, has two fine early unglazed Tang horses and two foreign grooms, which he is showing at the Kate Ganz Gallery, 25 East 73rd Street in Manhattan, from Wednesday through March 25.
The Hartman pottery is remarkable in its diversity. "The sculptures are of people who were part and parcel of Tang life," Mr. Tow said. There is a courtier, a groom, a falconer, an entertainer, a dancing lady, a foreign wine merchant and various animals. "They depicted native animals like buffalo and boar and foreign ones like camels and lions," Mr. Tow said. "The lion looks a bit like a pug, but they'd probably never seen a lion."
There are also jars, a water pot shaped like a beast, an ambrosia vase and a ewer with the head of a phoenix. The provenances of many pieces can be traced to the 1920's. Others were acquired at auction decades ago.
Tang artists were not the first to make tomb sculptures. Clay tomb figures go back to at least the third century B.C., before the Han dynasty. But Tang potters were more accomplished than their predecessors. The modeling is more subtle and individualized and the glazes are shinier and more colorful.
Perhaps the most extraordinary figure in the Christie's sale is a charming court lady seated on a rattan drum stool looking at a round mirror in her left hand. Her elaborate hairdo has two round buns. She rests her right foot on her knee, while one loose shoe, with a pointed toe, rests on the base. She wears a figure-revealing green gown with blue sleeves and has an amber throw on her shoulder.
Probably made in a mold, the figure has an unglazed head with a subtly carved, hand-painted face. The estimate is $170,000 to $200,000. "She cost me more than my apartment on Park Avenue," said Mr. Hartman, who bought his apartment in the 1970's. 
Another striking piece is a blue water buffalo with striped brown horns, huge ears and a plaintive look in his eyes. His tender, a small boy, sleeps on his back, the tether in his hand. The boy's straw hat rests on his hip. "This is one of the earliest depictions of a boy on the back of a water buffalo," Mr. Tow said.
Mr. Hartman added, "I bought it 20 years ago at Christie's East when it was being sold as a fake." Its estimate is $80,000 to $100,000.
According to Christie's, the only known similar depiction is of a cow with a boy wearing a straw hat in the Freer Gallery of Art in Washington.
Why are the Hartmans selling their collection? "I have eclectic tastes," Mr. Hartman said. "I collect jade and early English silver. In my gallery I sell English and American silver, Japanese cloissone, silver and ivory. I've been partial to the Tang, but times change. I'd rather put my resources into English silver now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A large detail of a court lady figurine from China's Tang dynasty. (Christie's)

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Owning and Leasing; 
More Buyers Put Money on the Table

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
NOT long ago, when stock prices were soaring and discount lease deals were easy to find, it seemed almost foolish to pay cash for a car -- and hardly anyone did. In 1998, cash-paying customers fell to a historic low of less than 4 percent of car and truck buyers.
 But times have changed, as anyone who has recently tried to gain access to a vanished Web site understands. No longer is there easy money to be had by investing in dot-com stocks, and those too-good-to-be-true lease deals are fading, too. 
 A growing number of consumers are using their money not for speculation but for transportation. Last year, 8.8 percent of vehicle buyers paid cash, more than double the 3.9 percent who did so just two years ago, according to CNW Marketing/Research. 
Cash purchases fall far short of the levels of the 1950's, when a third of buyers, many with memories of the Great Depression, regularly eschewed debt to buy their cars with greenbacks.
But the recent shift toward paying cash is the strongest since the early 1990's, before automakers turned to leasing in an attempt to jump-start sales. And it is in line with the levels of the 1970's and 80's, when 9 to 10 percent of car buyers paid cash.
"The trend toward paying cash is simple," said Art Spinella, president of CNW, a research firm in Bandon, Ore. "For whatever reason, people want to own a car and they don't want to have payments."
Dan Martin of Whitefish Bay, Wis., investigated lease deals this winter when he set out to replace his 1988 Audi 100, which he had bought before his two children, ages 10 and 7, were born.
He planned to make a modest down payment to secure the lease and leave the rest of the money in the bank to earn interest. But he said the monthly payments were too high on the leases that were available. Also, he said, his savings were earning interest barely above the rate of inflation.
So Mr. Martin, 40, paid $35,000 cash for a top-of-the-line Chrysler Town & Country Limited minivan, in white, with leather seats, a CD player and a power liftgate.
"We looked at paying it off monthly, but we had the cash," said Mr. Martin, vice president of Hellerman Tyton, a company that makes plastic automotive parts. "We decided, Why bother with small profits when we can just write a check and drive it off the lot?"
Relatively affluent buyers like Mr. Martin are the most likely to pay cash for vehicles, according to CNW's data. Cash purchases regularly account for 20 percent or more of transactions at Jaguar, Land Rover, Mercedes and Porsche. Among those recent buyers was Jeremy P. Anwyl, the president of Edmunds.com, a Web site that provides information for those seeking to buy or lease vehicles. Although Mr. Anwyl's site provides tips on the most favorable loan rates and the most generous buyer incentives, he paid $68,000 cash for a Jaguar XJR, the latest in a series of cars he has bought without financing.
"I don't gamble; I don't drink heavily," Mr. Anwyl said. "This is my hobby. I'm really fickle. I get in and out of cars really fast."
Buyers are especially quick to whip out their checkbooks for something in hot demand. About 40 percent of the buyers of the Lexus LS 430 luxury sedan, which was redesigned for 2001, have paid cash.
"When you come out with a brand-new car, the number of people paying cash shoots up," said George Borst, chief executive of Toyota Financial Services, which provides financing for buyers of Toyota and Lexus vehicles. "There's still this pride of ownership -- 'I've got to get it.' Leasing is more of a rental mentality."
Mr. Borst, who keeps close watch on spending trends, said he began to notice a steady stream of cash buyers returning to the market during the last 18 months.
The growth coincided with decisions by banks and automakers' financing companies to put the brakes on lease programs. In the mid- to late 1990's, lenders offered attractive deals by setting generous residual values -- the amount that vehicles are estimated to be worth at the end of their leases. The higher the residual, the lower the monthly payment.
The situation was a boon to consumers, both the well-heeled seeking a bargain, and others who were able to take home vehicles that they could not afford to buy outright.
But this strategy began to backfire when many formerly leased vehicles turned out to be worth less than their residual values, in part because so many were coming back into the used-car market. The gap between the residuals and the actual values left lenders with $10.4 billion in losses last year, and CNW estimates that they face $11.1 billion in losses this year. Big lenders like GE Capital have left the lease market, and the "captive" finance companies owned by automakers have significantly scaled back their discount leases.
With attractive lease deals less common, and with the economy so uncertain, Mr. Borst says a number of previous lessees are choosing to pay cash instead. Some wealthy buyers are spending money they made in stocks before that market turned down.
Mr. Borst said: "They think, 'What am I going to do with this money? Put it in tech stocks? I might as well put it into something tangible.' "
Other buyers are simply following their convictions. Brenda Clough, a science-fiction writer in Reston, Va., has always paid cash for vehicles, citing her thrifty upbringing and an uncertain income that make her wary of accumulating bills.
Unexpectedly flush last fall after selling a novella to Analog, a science-fiction magazine, Ms. Clough gave her Honda Odyssey minivan to her 16-year-old daughter and paid $20,000 cash for a red 2000 Toyota Celica. "There are certain things you are stuck with -- you are stuck with paying interest on your mortgage because there is no way to pay cash for your house," Ms. Clough said. "I pay cash for everything. I pay credit card bills the minute they come in."
Ms. Clough said she felt she got a good deal by taking home a 2000 vehicle, instead of a higher-priced 2001 model.
But experts say Mrs. Clough's tactic does not always yield the best result. Mr. Spinella said dealers were more likely to bargain if they also provided financing, since they earn a commission on each loan or lease. "You can't negotiate the best price that way, unless it is a vehicle that nobody wants that is sitting on the lot," Mr. Spinella said.
Ron Palumbo, a longtime Volkswagen dealer in Middletown, N.Y., says that no dealer will turn away a cash customer. But given a choice, dealers "absolutely" prefer that a consumer arrange financing through the showroom, Mr. Palumbo said.
With brands like Oldsmobile offering interest-free loans, "paying cash for a car is the stupidest thing you can do," Mr. Spinella said. "It is a terrible waste of your money."
Unless, of course, it is love at first sight, a reason given by many consumers inspired to put down cash for the vehicles of their dreams. That was the case, in fact, for Mr. Spinella, who spotted a black Jeep Wrangler last October at a dealership near his home in Coos Bay, Ore. He went in the next day and paid $16,000 cash for the sport utility, to which he has added $3,000 in alloy wheels and chrome trim.
"I saw it in the showroom window and said, 'Oh, yeah, I have to have it,' " Mr. Spinella said. "It's a completely emotional purchase. It makes no sense at all."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 4; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 31

LENGTH: 1658 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Magic Turns Light Into Life

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
GENIUS does not flourish in a vacuum. That's the simple lesson vividly conveyed by "Vermeer and the Delft School," an alternately tousled and crystalline show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It includes 15 paintings by Vermeer -- nearly half of the 35 works firmly attributed to him -- along with paintings, drawings and prints by a host of other artists and a smattering of decorative objects and books.
 This show tracks the emergence of an increasingly effortless illusionism in Delft in the late 1650's and 60's. In the process, it demonstrates that Vermeer's miraculous images, the pinnacle of this illusionism, emanated from a petri dish of precedent, influence, inspiration, collaboration and patronage that contained more than a jot of pure chance, including an assassination. 
 William the Silent, the George Washington of the Netherlands, was killed in Delft in 1584, and in the following decades his son and successor, Prince Maurits, moved the court to The Hague, three miles away. Not a great distance perhaps -- by the 1660's the two cities were connected by canal barges that left twice an hour in both directions -- but enough to place Delft on the margins of court patronage and taste, which favored artists influenced by Caravaggio. 
These events freed some of Delft's artists to investigate the ways light played upon the world around them, putting their own spin on ideas and conventions that were then in the air.
Picking up on work by Frans Hals, Nicolaes Maes and Gerard ter Borch, Pieter de Hooch helped revise the "merry company" tavern scenes popular in both Holland and Flanders into pools of domestic calm and intimacy. By 1650, influenced by Pieter Saenredam of Harlem, Gerard Houckgeest turned from grandiose evocations of imaginary Italianate architecture to measured renderings of the whitewashed interiors of the Old Church in Delft, setting a new standard for architectural perspective that de Hooch and Vermeer later applied to their domestic scenes.
The paintings of Vermeer, de Hooch and Houckgeest dominate this show, along with those of Carel Fabritius, a star pupil of Rembrandt who went to Delft in 1650 and may have taught Vermeer but certainly influenced him. Fabritius was 32 when he died, along with hundreds of others, in the accidental explosion of a gunpowder arsenal that leveled a sizable portion of Delft in October 1654. His "Sentry," painted that year, is one of the show's highlights, a dazzling arrangement of creams, gray and blacks that depicts a soldier dozing in the generous geometry of a sun-warmed courtyard.
But these artists have plenty of backup: the church interiors of Hendrick Cornelisz van Vliet, Emanuel de Witte and Louys Aernoutsz Elsevier, which sometimes cross over into trompe l'oeil; the flower paintings of Jacob Woutersz Vosmaer, Gillis Gillisz de Bergh and Balthasar van der Ast, with their increasingly transparent pockets of background space; the images of well-dressed burghers and their families in brick-lined courtyards or on front stoops by Jan Steen and Hendrick van der Burch. 
There are wonderful paintings by artists you've never heard of, from museums you may never visit, notably Egbert van der Poel's "Barnyard Scene" of 1658, an orchestration of coppery browns, tenderly rendered farm equipment and fading afternoon light, lent by the Museum for Foreign Art in Riga, Latvia.
This exhibition comes only six years after the first retrospective of Vermeer's art, a show of 20 canvases seen in Washington and The Hague. While that show presented one Vermeer after another, like pearls on a string or a row of motionless beacons, the Met's exhibition is like a roving spotlight that almost giddily illuminates a succession of artists, mediums and generations. It has been organized by Walter Liedtke, a curator in the Met's department of European paintings, with Axel Ruger, curator of Dutch paintings at the National Gallery in London, where the show will be seen this summer.
In the wall labels, Mr. Leidtke parses the qualities that might be defined as local, regional and international. He proposes the Delft School as a porous, fluctuating idea that intermittently revealed "a preference for understatement, for rationality and reserve and for sober realism." There doesn't seem to be a discernible Delft School of landscape painting, although the show contains a little corner of breathtaking ones. And whatever school existed wasn't triggered by a single work or artist, or the sudden arrival of artists like Fabritius or Paulus Potter, but was built over several generations.
In the opening galleries, things feel a bit piecemeal and disjointed. Enormous tapestries and pieces of silver-gilt from around 1600 attest to Delft's role in the production of high-end luxury items and to its exacting levels of craftsmanship, which were carried over into its painting. Yet all the conventions and motifs that Vermeer and his generation would refine into a new kind of representation are present, in one work or another.
In its own gaudy, cramped, awkwardly drawn way, the show's first painting, Bartholomeus van Bassen's "Renaissance Interior With Banqueters," even offers a compendium, if not a caricature, of what lies ahead. Its carefully detailed, albeit palatial and Italianate interior contains a rowdy "merry company," a more restrained group of well-dressed men and women gathered around a table next to a window, walls lined with art, a sort of still life and a checkerboard floor. (Few Dutch houses or churches had such floors, but they recur throughout these paintings, measuring the recession of space with clarity and eclat.)
It is striking to realize how many of these elements, floor included, are present, profoundly realigned and transformed, in Vermeer's grand, enigmatic "Art of Painting," which awaits the visitor in the show's final gallery.
If this exhibition places Vermeer in context, emphasizing milieu over individual achievement, it proceeds in a restrained, object-oriented manner characteristic of the Met. Those expecting to see examples of the Turkish carpets that cover the tables in Vermeer's paintings, or the guild membership roll open to the page with his name, will be disappointed.
On view, however, are Gillis van Scheyndel's imposing engraving of the winding line of dignitaries (many identified by name) that formed Prince Maurits's funeral procession in 1625, and an even larger house-by-house map of the town, first published in 1678 by Johannes de Ram and Coenraet Decker. Both are resplendent examples of civic pride and close observation.
A large selection of drawings, among them two views of the devastation of the 1654 arsenal explosion, corroborate the assertion in a catalog essay by Michiel C. Plomp that there is more to the Delft School than oil on canvas. Other supporting material includes books on perspective and its use in painting; blue-and-white Delftware chargers, or presentation bowls, which mix Chinese motifs with local landscape scenes; and a single exquisite diamond-engraved wineglass, made in Delft around 1685.
This glass is placed to the right of Vermeer's "Glass of Wine," a painting of a woman who hesitantly drains a nearly identical one while her male companion waits. It confirms that Vermeer's interiors, for their time, tended to be luxuriously appointed, in keeping with the patrician calm of his subjects.
But more germane is what leads up to this painting from the left side: a progression of four canvases from the mid- and late 1650's by de Hooch that display a growing confidence in the treatment of the domestic interior articulated by natural light. Almost painting by painting, we see spare paneled rooms, open doors and mullioned windows become the full-fledged partners, if not the stars, of de Hooch's interiors. It is a development that anticipates Vermeer's even more commanding use of the convention.
Luminous, compressed and perfect in every way, Vermeer's "Glass of Wine" trumps the lineup. It eliminates extraneous gesture or expression and any suggestion of narrative.
Yet his cool, omnivorous mind is everywhere, polishing every granule of surface until it communicates the maximum of visual information: about the painting on the wall behind the man and woman, the carpet covering their table, the light filtering through the slightly open stained glass window.
One of Vermeer's distinguishing strengths, beyond his skill at rendering the human figure (which de Hooch lacked), was his supreme evenhandedness. Painting the animate and the inanimate as if they were of equal import, he paradoxically implied the relentless inner pulse of life and thought, but from a discreet distance.
De Hooch and Vermeer were more equal outdoors, painting their brick courtyards and building fronts, which appear on the opposite wall of this gallery. First come two nearly identical paintings of brick courtyards by de Hooch that confirm that the Delft realists didn't necessary stick to reality. A spate of big and little differences -- from the street outside (visible through the passageway) to the angles of walls, the patterns of bricks and the courtyard's inhabitants -- attest to ways that reality was constantly rearranged to suit the artist, or a client.
But again Vermeer trumps, this time with "The Little Street," with its orderly progression of brick surfaces and forms; the disparate activities but shared concentration of the four figures, which mirror his own; and the creamy, loosely indicated cobblestones rendering the canvas soft and open at its bottom edge.
This exhibition outlines a world without which Vermeer could not possibly have been Vermeer. But it doesn't diminish or flatten his achievement. It makes it sharper, more specific and more miraculous than ever.
"Vermeer and the Delft School" remains at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500, through May 27. It will be at the National Gallery in London from June 20 to Sept. 16.

(Photographs from the Metropolitan Museum of Art)(pg. E34); A detail of "The Art of Painting" (1666-68), above, by Vermeer and a detail of Pieter de Hooch's "Courtyard of a House in Delft" (1658), at the Metropolitan Museum. (Photographs from the Metropolitan Museum of Art)(pg. E31) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Science and Surpluses 

BYLINE:  By D. Allan Bromley; D. Allan Bromley, a professor of nuclear physics at Yale, was science and technology adviser to President George H. W. Bush from 1989 to 1993.

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
When President Bush spoke to Congress and the nation on Feb. 27, he outlined three cardinal goals: a $1.6 trillion tax cut, a first-class education for every child and a restructured military that confronts emerging post-cold-war threats. The next day, he announced a budget that jeopardizes the nation's ability to achieve any of these truly laudable goals.
 Both the tax cut and the spending that would support educational and military buildups depend upon an estimated $5.6 trillion surplus over the next 10 years. Where is all that money coming from? There are several sources, but the major driver of our nation's economic success is scientific innovation. And the Bush budget includes cuts, after accounting for inflation, to the three primary sources of ideas and personnel in the high-tech economy: the National Science Foundation is cut by 2.6 percent, NASA by 3.6 percent and the Department of Energy by an alarming 7.1 percent. 
 Economists, including Alan Greenspan, attribute much of America's 1990's boom to increased productivity stemming, in large part, from scientific research. Two simple discoveries -- the transistor and the fiber optic cable -- are at the root of it. Anyone skeptical of this should turn off the computer for a day and see how much work gets done.
The 21st century economy will continue to depend on scientific innovation. Economists estimate that innovation and the application of new technology have generated at least half of the phenomenal growth in America's gross domestic product since World War II. Keeping that economic source productive is critical to both national prosperity and federal revenues. (And where defense is concerned, basic scientific discovery also has a more direct role: it leads to the applied science that eventually provides advances in defense hardware.)
Technological innovation depends upon the steady flow of discoveries and trained workers generated by federal science investments in universities and national laboratories. These discoveries feed directly into the industries that drive the economy. It's a straightforward relationship: industry is attentive to immediate market pressures, and the federal government makes the investments that ensure long-term competitiveness.
The proposed cuts to scientific research are a self-defeating policy. Congress must increase the federal investment in science. No science, no surplus. It's that simple.

HEADLINE: New Legal Disputes Put Holocaust Victim Payments in Doubt 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 8 

 BODY:
Eight months after Germany and the United States reached an agreement on establishing a $5 billion fund to compensate victims of the Holocaust, the prospect of payments actually being made has been delayed by serious new legal disputes.
 The continued courtroom battles have increased the risk that many of the survivors, already in their 70's and 80's, will die before payments begin. And though German companies and the German government say they want to begin making payments as soon as possible, the companies are raising legal objections that defy easy resolution. 
 The most significant setback occurred on Wednesday, when a federal judge in New York refused to dismiss a batch of lawsuits brought against German companies by Holocaust victims. Judge Shirley Wohl Kram questioned whether the money would be there to pay the claims. And her decision raised doubts about whether German companies would achieve what they believed was their part of the deal: immunity from future lawsuits related to the Holocaust. 
Under the agreement signed last July, German companies as a group and the German government each pledged to provide about $2.5 billion for the fund. In exchange, the United States government promised to urge the courts to reject all existing and future lawsuits against German companies coming from slave laborers and other victims of the Nazi era. 
But the real problems lie less with Judge Kram's objections, which Germany companies may be able to address, than with deeper disputes about the issue of "legal peace," giving the companies future immunity, and if that is not resolved, the entire settlement could unravel. 
Judge Kram did not reject the basic premise of the agreement signed last year. Rather, she said, it was premature to dismiss the lawsuits because there are still uncertainties about whether German companies will come up with the money. 
The judge expressed particular concern that German industry has raised only 3.6 billion of the 5 billion German marks it pledged as its share of the fund. Many smaller and middle-sized German companies continue to resist making contributions, though German industry leaders insist they can and will fulfill their commitments. 
Other problems exist as well. In the last few weeks, Deutsche Bank and DaimlerChrysler have circulated letters arguing that no money should be paid until all pending court cases have been settled.
The companies noted that additional lawsuits have been filed since the agreements were signed last July, and one of them was filed by a lawyer, Michael Hausfeld, who took part in the negotiations last year.
"How can we contend that legal peace has been established when even certain actions are still pending?" wrote Klaus Kohler, Deutsche Bank's general counsel, in a letter to members of the German industry foundation collecting money for the fund. "How can we explain such a proposition to those companies who must continue to defend contested cases not yet finally dismissed?" 
In a letter to companies involved in the fund, DaimlerChrysler's chief financial officer, Manfred Gentz, argued that no money should be paid until at least 13 cases, including recently filed, are dismissed. 
If the industry group maintains this view, it might delay payments for months or indefinitely -- even assuming that the industry group gets pledges for the full amount and satisfies the objections raised by Judge Kram.
"The treaty is saying that first the cases have to be dismissed and then the payments will begin," said Wolfgang Gibowski, a spokesman for the German Economy Foundation, which represents companies contributing to the Holocaust fund.
But lawyers representing Holocaust victims said today that the German industry had created its own problems, because it refused to settle the claims as a conventional class-action lawsuit. In such a suit, the defendants and the plaintiffs would have proposed a settlement to the presiding judge and the judge would have the power to declare that case -- and all similar ones -- closed.
But neither German companies nor the German government wanted to put themselves under the power of an American court. Instead, the Germans reached a complex agreement with the United States government, under which the government agreed to urge the courts to dismiss all Holocaust lawsuits in a strongly worded "statement of interests."
The government did exactly that in the cases before Judge Kram, but the statement failed to persuade the judge, and thus failed to do what it was meant to do. 
"The reason we are in this position is that German industry and German parliamentarians insisted from the very first day on using the wrong legal mechanism," said Michael Witti, a lawyer in Munich who represents thousands of people forced to work in German factories and concentration camps during World War II. 
Mr. Witti said that now it is inevitable that new lawsuits will be filed, because the United States government has no legal right to block them and each judge will be able to decide whether to accept the government's plea to dismiss each case as it is presented. 
German leaders denounced the judge's ruling.
Count Otto Lambsdorff, who represented German industry in the long negotiations that led to last year's agreement, called it an "erroneous, bad, unjustified decision" and said German companies would appeal immediately.
In Washington, Richard Boucher, a spokesman for the State Department, which supported dismissal of the case, issued a statement criticizing the judge's ruling.
"The decision is contrary to the recommendations of all parties having an interest in the case and will delay justice and payments to Holocaust victims, a significant number of whom are dying each month."

HEADLINE: Lamenting a Loss For Injured Workers 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "House Joins Senate in Repealing Rules on Workplace Injuries" (news article, March 8):
 Congress denigrates all workers, especially women, in overturning protections against work-related injuries like carpal tunnel syndrome. 
The emotional, physical and economic effects of carpal tunnel syndrome are devastating, costing the United States more than $20 billion a year in lost productivity. 
 Workers' compensation offers insufficient recourse. Fear of job loss often overrides reporting pain, increasing severity. And it often takes years before a claim is approved.
Prevention is the only solution. If President Bush signs this legislation repealing workplace safety regulations, he contributes to the onset of dependency and the cycle of poverty. 

MARIANNE C. FAHS
New York, March 8, 2001

The writer is an associate professor in the Milano Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy, New School University.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
$140 Million Complex for Jersey City Riverfront

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The latest housing complex planned for Jersey City's Hudson River waterfront will also be the city's tallest, continuing the skyward growth of an old industrial neighborhood turned residential at the river's edge.
 Called HarborSpire, the complex will consist of two Art Deco-style rental towers: a 55-story building with 445 apartments and a 50-story building with 417 units. The apartments, ranging from studios to three-bedroom units, will have 600 to 1,650 square feet. Those above the 24th floor will have clear water views. 
 The brick towers will be among the tallest residential buildings in New Jersey and will anchor the northeast and southwest corners of a six-story base that will house 20,000 square feet of retail space and parking for 786 cars.
"The towers will be a nice addition to the city's skyline, which is growing on a daily basis," said Annemarie C. Uebbing, director of the city's Department of Housing, Economic Development and Commerce. "There are no other residential buildings planned so far that will be taller."
The $140 million complex is to rise over the next four years on a city block now used for parking that had been intended for office development since the mid-1980's. The site, near the PATH station at Exchange Place, is on the east side of Washington Avenue, across from the Harborside Financial Center.
The Applied Development Company of Hoboken, N.J., is developing the project with Liberty Center Associates, a group of New Jersey and Florida investors who own the site. The architect is Peter DeWitt of Manhattan.
Construction of the taller tower, which recently got a 15-year tax abatement from the city, is to start in November, said David B. Barry, a principal at Applied, which will manage the entire project.
He said his company would use its own money and had signed a letter of intent with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Pension Trust Fund to finance the first building, which will cost $80 million.
HarborSpire is Applied's 10th project on the west bank of the Hudson River. Its other developments, either completed or under way, will ultimately have 4,500 units, most of them rentals, in Hoboken, North Bergen, Fort Lee and Jersey City.
Mr. Barry said HarborSpire would be a "true Manhattan-style luxury building on this side of the Hudson." 
All units will have marble tile bathrooms, a corner window and washers and dryers, he said. There will be an outdoor swimming pool, a basketball court, a health club and a children's play area. 
Mr. Barry said that although the office and residential markets were equally strong in Jersey City, his company argued to the investors that housing would maximize the site's value faster. Building offices would have required securing a tenant for much of the space before financing could be obtained, he said. Housing is a permitted use on the site, where the zoning allows buildings to rise 55 stories without special permits, he added. 
And that, Ms. Uebbing said, is among the reasons the project, despite its height, has encountered little resistance.
Most of the Exchange Place district projects so far have been office buildings. "We're interested in pursuing residential because it will populate the streets," said Robert Cotter, the city's planning director, "and help create a neighborhood."
The project's retail space will be on three sides of the base of the complex. The fourth side on the ground floor will be for parking until a decision about the fate of its neighbor, a century-old powerhouse in need of repair that is used to power part of the PATH train system.
Mr. Barry said rents at the first HarborSpire building would be at or above the high end of the market, which ranges from $1,600 for studios to $3,800 for three bedrooms. He said construction of the second tower would begin once the first was substantially complete.
Real estate experts say the rental vacancy rate along the riverfront is negligible. Mr. Barry said the demand for housing had been fueled by the wave of waterfront offices rising at Harborside as well as at the Colgate Center, the former site of a Colgate toothpaste factory just to the south, and the Newport mixed-use complex at the northern end of the waterfront.
Most of the spate of new buildings have already been leased by Manhattan-based companies, including Chase Bank and Goldman Sachs, which is erecting the city's tallest office building, a 45-story, 1.6-million-square-foot tower at Colgate Center.
There are other residential projects now under way or planned in the area. Fisher Associates of Purchase, N.Y., is building 650 rental units in two towers at Colgate Center. At Harborside, construction could begin this year on 300 rentals on a pier, according to Mack-Cali Realty Corporation of Cranford, N.J., which owns the complex.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A rendering of HarborSpire, a rental apartment complex proposed for Jersey City. (DeWitt Tishman Architects L.L.P.)

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Reports Tax Compliance Rates 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Senators, representatives and their employees are much more likely than federal employees as a whole not to file tax returns or to have unresolved debts for back taxes, an Internal Revenue Service report showed yesterday.
 Each year since 1993, the I.R.S. has checked its computer files to determine whether federal employees and retirees have filed tax returns and whether those who did file owed back taxes. Taxpayers who have signed an agreement with the I.R.S. to make payments on their tax debts are considered to be in compliance with the law. 
 The I.R.S. then calculates what percentage of workers at each federal agency or office either did not file a tax return or have unresolved debts for back taxes. 
For all federal employees and retirees, the noncompliance rate as of last October was just under 3 percent. For I.R.S. employees, the rate was less than 1.7 percent. For all Americans, the rate was 5.7 percent, meaning that 1 in 17 Americans was out of compliance.
The noncompliance rate for the 435 representatives and their 11,000 employees was 5 percent last year, down from 6 percent in 1999. 
For senators and their staff members, the rate was 4.4 percent, down from 5 percent in 1999.
It could not be determined from the data how many, if any, members of Congress had not filed returns, or owed back taxes but had not signed an agreement to pay off their tax debt.
The Clinton White House had a significantly better rate than Congress last year, though not in previous years. In the Executive Office of the President, the noncompliance rate was 3.1 percent last year, down from 4.3 percent in 1999 and 7.2 percent in 1998. Both Bill Clinton and Al Gore made their tax returns public, so the noncompliance involves only their staff members.
Federal judges and court employees had a 2.8 percent rate last year, the only period for which data was available. It could not be determined how many judges were included in the figures.
I.R.S. employees, whom Congress has ordered to be fired if they willfully fail to comply with the tax laws, had one of the best rates of compliance, far exceeding Congress and its staff members. A separate report, prepared last October, showed that fewer than 1.7 percent of I.R.S. workers were noncompliant, down from 2.2 percent two years earlier.
That means that House members and their staffs were three times as likely as I.R.S. workers to be out of compliance with the tax laws.
The House members and employees who owed back taxes had an average tax debt of $10,045, a much higher number than for the Senate ($5,942), the federal courts ($6,380), the White House ($8,968) or for all noncompliant Americans ($2,027). It is not known how much, if any, is owed by those who did not file tax returns. Some of those taxpayers may actually be owed refunds because the withholding tax tables are designed to collect slightly more than taxpayers taking the standard deduction owe.
Commissioner Charles O. Rossotti sent a letter to the heads of each federal agency with a copy of the report and urged them to reduce the noncompliance figures.
The lowest rates were at the Office of Special Counsel, which had perfect compliance, although two employees owed back taxes and were paying them under installment agreements.
Among large agencies, the best rates were at the F.B.I. and the Justice Department, both below 2 percent. That was the same level as retired civil servants. 
The highest noncompliance rate was 9.8 percent at the Inter-American Foundation, an agency that promotes economic development in Latin America. Among large agencies, the worst compliance rates were at the Federal Reserve, at 5.2 percent, and the State Department, at just less than 5 percent. 
Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said the noncompliance rate for the Senate was unacceptable. "It's against the law not to pay your taxes," Mr. Grassley said. "That applies to every taxpayer, whether an elected official, public employee or private citizen."
