HEADLINE: The Dreams Of Webzines Fizzle Out; 
Online Magazines Scramble for Readers and Ads

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
In the good old days of just a year ago, the founders of Inside.com sniffed at the dead weight of their competitors' "legacy publications" -- that is, those printed on paper. Like others, they predicted that the nimbleness of the Internet would quickly make them a must-have magazine for media professionals.
 Then they cranked up their Web site last spring, just as the Internet stock bubble burst. Out went the forecasts of 30,000 paying Internet subscribers within a year (not to mention 100,000 subscribers and profitability after three years). And in came a somewhat retrograde Plan B: a print magazine. 
 "We realized pretty early that being an independent, Web-only provider was not entirely viable," said Michael Hirschorn, editor in chief of Inside.com. "You had to find other ways to become viable." 
Like a lot of others, Inside.com miscalculated its audience, which peaked at far below its forecast for the first year, he said. New-media companies generally made the mistake of "thinking they were bigger than they really were," said Mr. Hirschorn, who was the editor of Spin magazine before founding Inside.com with Kurt Andersen, the former editor of New York magazine.
Five years ago, Slate and Salon arrived amid proclamations that "Webzines" would become a multibillion-dollar business and displace print publications by stealing their readers and sucking their advertising dry. Many people, including not a few print publishers, believed it. But none of it happened.
In the last year, as subscription and ad sales forecasts fizzled and financing dried up, more than a dozen online magazines have gone back to tap old media, including radio and print, to draw audiences -- and advertisers -- at least until the Web delivers on its promise.
For example, Salon, based in San Francisco, has branched out into newsletters. Its rival, Slate, edited in Redmond, Wash., introduced a print edition and offers versions on the Web that can be printed out or saved as an audio file or an e-book. Inside.com, in New York, has been playing host to industry exhibitions as well introducing its glossy magazine.
In each case, the goal is to build readership and earn enough money to hang on until someone figures out how to make money publishing on the Internet. Many online magazine publishers hope the industry eventually will be able to charge subscriptions for Webzines. At the same time, however, they are hedging their e-bets by venturing into unproven arenas, like sending breaking news to cellular phones and translating essays into audio recordings, in the hope that affluent people will buy such services and advertisers will want to reach them.
Some online publishers without deep pockets are hoping that they have created enough of a buzz and a brand name that an old-economy company will acquire them.
Driving their new vision of entrepreneurialism is the rising morbidity among Internet content sites. Dozens of publications, including Word, have published their last issues. Other Webzines, including Salon.com, have retrenched after losing millions of dollars and having their stocks harshly punished. Slate is somewhat protected from being driven out of business because of the deep pockets of its owner, Microsoft, but in 1999 it abandoned trying to charge for subscriptions and returned to relying mostly on revenue from advertising.
"Things look really bleak right now" for online content companies, said Robert Hertzberg, an Internet analyst at Jupiter Communications, an Internet research firm in New York. A slowdown in the growth of online advertising in the second half of last year has not helped, not that advertising on the Web ever lived up to expectations.
Almost all Internet businesses have suffered since the Nasdaq stock market peaked last March, and investors became wary of technology companies. Among the hardest hit were companies that provide online content because, despite flashy marketing campaigns and high-profile leaders, Webzines have yet to make money. Even successful print magazines usually take three to five years to make a profit.
Mr. Hirschorn is convinced that the online magazine industry will survive. He said that magazines that provide news and analysis on the Web and in print, like Fast Company and Wired, would be able to use their revenue-generating ventures to finance experimentation online until they find some way to make enough money on the Net. But even these magazines are vulnerable because of their reliance on dot-com ads.
The hasty rewrite of business plans for online magazines has led to many chuckles among ink-on-paper publishers. While the migration to print may not be a retreat from the Internet as a communication tool, analysts said the retrenchment does signify something fundamental for Internet magazines: a general agreement that Internet advertising has not lived up to expectations.
"What the Web really offers is the communication ability -- e-mail and voice, auctions and chat -- and I think that has been really revolutionary on the consumer side," said Justin Post, an analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "But what has changed is that people are doubting the effectiveness of Web advertising banners."
The problem, he said, was that people bought Internet publishing stocks on the assumption that the companies' revenues would double each year, even though advertising sales were expanding at less than half that pace. "We have really cut back the rate at which we think the Internet can grow" Mr. Post said.
Kevin Ryan, the chief executive of DoubleClick Inc., the Web's largest advertising and data services company, told entrepreneurs at the Silicon Alley 2001 conference in Manhattan last week that even though advertisers spent $10 billion online last year, the Net was not likely to displace print and television any time soon. Over all, advertisers spent $233 billion last year, according to Universal McCann, a unit of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising.
Some Webzines, including those that dropped subscription fees because so many competitors were free, will slowly begin to charge for their articles, Mr. Ryan added, citing the example of TheStreet.com, a financial news Web site. For now, he added, online publishers must increase the amount of space devoted to advertising from about 20 percent to something closer to the 60 percent seen in newspapers. "There is not enough advertising on the Web," he said, "and it's not as intrusive."
Until that happens, Internet magazines are searching for other ways to raise revenue and attract readers.
Slate, which is edited by Michael Kinsley, a former editor of The New Republic and a former CNN talk-show host, started a paper edition, Slate on Paper, to draw readers who were not reading online. Slate initially printed its paper edition and mailed it out, but switched to a less-expensive option of letting readers download and print it themselves.
Slate also offers an audio version of its articles and essays, as does Salon. Both Salon and Inside.com broadcast exclusives and other breaking news to cellular phones, pagers or hand-held computers. Inside also promotes sales of its print magazine on its Web site. Consumers either pay for such services, or they accept specially tailored advertisements that ad agencies have deemed more effective than Web banners.
Though these ventures have increased revenue, Scott Moore, the publisher of Slate, said the Internet itself was being judged too narrowly. After all, he said, Slate on the Web attracts more than two million visitors a month.
"From my perspective, a lot of the negative stuff that has been written about Internet content is from the perspective of Wall Street," he said. "If you look at it from a user perspective, online content is not only alive and well, but thriving.
"The audience that matters in the end are not the Wall Street analysts or the media critics," he added, "but the audience of readers, and they are voting with their mice."
Mr. Hirschorn of Inside.com agrees: "The Web is very powerful in terms of how to build a brand quickly and powerful to sell offline products. If we did not have the Web, people would not know who we are."
According to Jupiter Media Metrix Inc., a New York research firm that tracks Web readership, the number of people who go online for news and analysis is growing faster than the number for any other medium, as happened with cable, television and radio during their infancies. 
Online publishers hope their retreat to old media and embrace of several new technologies will let them stick around long enough to exploit that trend. They know that online publishing has exhausted its gee-whiz good will; practitioners must demonstrate the ability to make money, and fast.
Some Webzine workers take comfort in a comparison of their industry with the cable television business in the 1970's -- a new medium that struggled at first because it lacked enough unique, high-quality content to attract subscribers. It is now a multibillion-dollar industry.
"When cable television was invented, the 30-second spot already existed, and we are talking about developing a whole industry from scratch," Mr. Moore said. "Remember, we are only in our infancy."

HEADLINE: The Grandeur That Graft Built; 
Boss Tweed's Courthouse Slowly Reveals Its Glory In a Painstaking and Expensive Restoration

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
No one, not yet, not even 120 years later, is prepared to say that the citizenry got everything it paid for at the New York County Courthouse behind City Hall.
 But an $85 million restoration of that notorious landmark, better known as the Tweed Courthouse, has uncovered a surpassingly vibrant 19th-century civic structure. Disdained and underused for so long, it was preserved by default. Now that it is coming back to light, one can marvel at just how much of a building New York received in exchange for lining the pockets of the political boss William M. Tweed and his Tweed Ring confederates. 
 "To see the care in craftsmanship and the amount of attention to detail, you have to conclude that while they poured a lot of dough in it, there is at least a lot to show for it," said John S. Dyson, who is Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's adviser on the project. "Perhaps not every penny's worth. But a lot." 
The restoration, which began in May 1999 and is to be finished this year, will pave the way for reuse of the building as a new home for the Museum of the City of New York, which expects to move from Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street in about 18 months to two years.
Tweed Courthouse will also serve as a ceremonial space for functions that now crowd City Hall. John G. Waite Associates are the architects. The construction manager is Bovis Lend Lease.
"I think we're going to get what we paid for this time," said Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
But with Boss Tweed still casting a shadow, the expense of the project has raised more than a few eyebrows.
Though city officials acknowledge that the price tag more than doubled in five years, from an initial estimate of $37 million, they said that reflected the expanding scope of necessary work, including two new sets of fire stairs and the replacement of a marble cornice that was beyond repair.
"It's a significantly different project than the one priced out in 1996," said Michael G. Carey, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, which is overseeing the job.
At first, the city envisioned stabilizing the roof. In the end, Mr. Carey said, it undertook "a top-to-bottom, full-scale restoration of a building that has been neglected for years and years and years."
The county courts moved out in 1929, and the Tweed building served as a city courthouse until 1961. After that, it was used as a municipal office building. But 28-foot-high rooms were scarcely suited to that purpose, and that bedeviled numerous earlier renovations.
"The building was never made for offices," Ms. Raab said. "That fact has finally been acknowledged. It's not a convenient fact, but the scale of the rooms is astonishing."
So is the scale of the current restoration.
It has ranged as far afield as a farm in Sheffield, Mass., that was once a Tweed-controlled quarry and had supplied some of the stone for the New York courthouse. (Other marble came from a quarry in Tuckahoe, N.Y., where a shopping center now stands.)
About 120 blocks of marble -- up to 3 by 4 by 8 feet, weighing 9,600 pounds -- were still at the farm. Some had apparently been destined for Chambers Street in the 1870's, said Donald Curtis, a vice president of Bovis Lend Lease and project executive at the courthouse renovation.
They were bought from the owner of the farm, Craig Moskowitz. With the help of a local excavator, Bovis Lend Lease built a road to cart them away. Twenty-five trailer trucks from Granite Importers of Barre, Vt., hauled the stone to the Georgia Marble Company in Tate, Ga., for carving.
Granite Importers is also furnishing stone for what will surely be the most noticeable exterior feature. The grand stairway leading to the central portico, truncated in 1942 to allow the widening of Chambers Street, is to be restored.
Seventeen missing steps will be replaced. To accommodate the stairway, the sidewalk will be widened 11 feet into a no-parking, no-standing lane. Work is to begin next month, with completion expected by October.
For the rotunda, a 52-foot-wide octagonal stained- and etched-glass skylight is being fashioned by the Cummings Studios of North Adams, Mass., to replace one that was removed long ago. Based on surviving fragments, it will have two rings of amber, ruby and emerald panes depicting birds, squirrels, frogs, fish and flowers. This is to arrive in July.
At the moment, on scaffolding 65 feet above ground, a dust-covered, three-man crew from B & H Art-in-Architecture in Brooklyn -- Shi-Jia Chen, Muneto Maekawa and Patrick Mahon -- is recarving pilaster capitals that either crumbled or were lopped off.
Blocks of snowy Georgia Cherokee marble lie on the scaffold. In Mr. Chen's hands, a piece of stone 11 by 12 by 24 inches will yield a broad acanthus leaf supporting an eight-and-a-half-inch curlicue scroll. "We are artists," he said. "That's why we're here."
More than anything, the restoration has clearly revealed that the courthouse is really two buildings in one: an elegant Renaissance composition of pediments and pilasters designed by John Kellum, who died in 1871, and a wildly exuberant Romanesque counterpoint, with powerful arches and polychromatic brickwork, by Leopold Eidlitz, who finished the job a decade later.
This is nowhere more evident than in the 85-foot-high rotunda, where decades' worth of paint layers have been removed to reveal the expanses of intricately patterned red, cream and black brick -- tooth-edged, banded and diamond-shaped -- that Eidlitz inserted between classical niches at each corner.
Other surprises abound in the building.
The ornamentation of the 20-foot-high window frames in the third-floor courtrooms, for example, still has a pristine, knife-edge crispness that cannot simply be attributed to the fine work performed by Andrew Garvey, the Prince of Plasterers in the Tweed Ring, who was paid $133,187 for two days' work.
Close inspection reveals the secret: screw heads. These frames are made of cast-iron elements that have been screwed together. And they are thick. "The vendor was being paid by the pound," explained Nancy A. Rankin of John G. Waite Associates.
Another happy discovery was a piece of the original iron corrugated roof, which was found in the attic during an inventory of old doors. This was used to design a reconstruction of the roof, which is now made of stainless steel coated in tin and zinc, over a synthetic rubber waterproof membrane.
"The priority has been to address the structural issues first and the cosmetic issues second," Ms. Rankin said.
That meant sawing off the old cornice, which runs for about 900 feet around the building, and replacing it with new blocks of Georgia Cherokee stone, fastened with stainless-steel rods.
Old stone was not discarded. Instead, about three million pounds were shipped to the Georgia Marble Company to be refashioned as windowsills and odd-shaped replacement pieces, called dutchmen, for use in the more visible lower parts of the facade.
"We are mining the building for its own materials," Ms. Rankin said.
Some discoveries had to be left in place. In the course of an archaeological probe around the possible route of underground utility lines, workers came across eight graves presumed to date from the Colonial era. By agreement with the Landmarks Preservation Commission, they were left undisturbed.
Ms. Raab, who will step down from the commission later this year to assume the presidency of Hunter College, had championed the restoration of the Tweed Courthouse. She said it represented the final act in reclaiming the civic center, including the renovation of City Hall, City Hall Park and the former Sun Building at 280 Broadway, across Chambers Street.
"I'm very satisfied to see that ultimately it's been a priority of the administration to invest in its historic home," she said.
And if the job is completed on schedule, Mr. Giuliani will get to cut the ribbon.
"I said to the mayor that no Democrat will dare touch this thing because of Boss Tweed," Mr. Dyson recalled. "I always said it's going to take a Republican to do this, and I don't know when we're going to get another one, so we'd better do it while you're here."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Dow Rises for 5th Day, but Technology Shares Fall 2.5%

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose for a fifth consecutive session yesterday, as a dour profit forecast by the Internet company Yahoo drove investors to businesses that may better weather the soft economy.
 But the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell almost 2.5 percent, to a level only about 50 points above its 52-week closing low. 
 "This is part of the process of trying to find a bottom in the technology sector," said John Bartlett, director of economics and market strategy at the Commerce Trust Company, which oversees about $10 billion in investments. "We all know business stinks today, and the question is how soon will things turn." 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 128.65 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,858.25. The Dow has gained almost 4 percent in the last five sessions.
The Nasdaq composite dropped 55.10 points, or 2.48 percent, to 2,168.82. Cisco Systems, the leading maker of networking equipment, led the index lower with a slide of $1.19, to $22.81. Declining issues outpaced those advancing, by 2,177 to 1,434.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 2.85 points, or 0.23 percent, to 1,264.74.
Investors, concerned over the economic slowdown's effect on technology companies, bought defensive issues. Procter & Gamble, up $2.48, to $71, and Johnson & Johnson, up $3.07 at $97.87, helped lift the Dow. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up $4.26, to $117.19, and Exxon Mobil, up $1.64, to $85.85, also added strength.
Yahoo fell $3.31, to $17.69, after trading as low as $16.25. On Wednesday, Yahoo said that earnings this year would fall below estimates and that its chief executive would step down. Yahoo "just reminds us of the headwind the stock market has to slug its way through day after day," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany.
Late in the afternoon, the semiconductor giant Intel cut revenue estimates for the first quarter and said it would eliminate 5,000 jobs, or 6 percent of the work force, mainly by attrition. Intel shares fell as low as $30 after hours, ending late trading at $30.94, down $2 from Wednesday. A small chip maker, Cree, and a systems integrator, Tibco Software, deepened concern about corporate earnings as companies cut back on technology purchases. Cree fell $7.94, to $17.50, after warning of disappointing revenue; Tibco, forecasting lower revenue and earnings from order delays, slipped 94 cents, to $9.94.
Computer storage companies suffered after Salomon Smith Barney cut investment ratings on several stocks. Brocade Communications fell $5.44, to $33.31. EMC dropped $3.85, to $37.15.
Two Fed officials -- William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Michael H. Moskow, the Chicago Fed chief -- said yesterday that the soft economy was likely to pick up speed later in 2001 and minimized recession fears.
In Tokyo, Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said Japanese government finances were close to a "catastrophic situation." --------------------

Treasuries Are Mixed
By Bloomberg News
Treasury prices were mixed yesterday as investors postponed purchases awaiting today's jobs report. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note was unchanged at 100 27/32. Its yield remained at 4.89 percent.

HEADLINE: 3 Men Are Charged With Fraud In 1,100 Art Auctions on EBay 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ and JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Three men accused of trying to sell an abstract painting for $135,805 on the eBay auction Web site last year were indicted yesterday on charges of taking part in a bidding ring that cost hundreds of art buyers a total of $450,000.
 The 35-page indictment charges the men with 16 counts of wire fraud and mail fraud. It accuses them of placing "shill" bids in 1,100 auctions between October 1998 and May 2000, including an auction involving the abstract painting, which seemed to be the work of the artist Richard Diebenkorn. 
 Using more than 40 online user ID's, or screen names, like thriftstorebob and big-fat-mamba-jambas, the indictment says, the bidders buoyed prices and intended to trick other bidders into believing that the sellers were respected users of eBay.
Shill bidding, or bidding on one's own auction, is forbidden by eBay rules and is generally illegal in the traditional auction world. Each count of mail fraud and wire fraud could, if proved in court, lead to a maximum penalty of up to five years in prison and $1 million in fines. 
Two of the men, Kenneth A. Walton of Sacramento, Calif., and Scott Beach of Lakewood, Colo., have been contacted by investigators but have not been arrested. The third, Kenneth Fetterman of Placerville, Calif., has not been located, said Nick Rossi, an F.B.I. spokesman in Sacramento, where the indictment was issued. Mr. Fetterman also faces six counts of money laundering.
The F.B.I. has said that it opened its investigation after reading an article that appeared in The New York Times on June 2, 2000. That article outlined how Mr. Walton, a Sacramento lawyer, almost sold the "Diebenkorn" for $135,805 after putting it up for sale for 25 cents. Mr. Walton paid a fee to eBay to have the painting listed as a "Featured Auction" in the art category on the Web site.
According to the indictment, the description of the work in a May 2000 listing said that Mr. Walton had bought the painting at a garage sale in Berkeley, Calif., before he was married, "and that his child had punctured a hole in it with a Big Wheel." A picture of the hole showed the initials "R.D."
The indictment says that "these statements were misrepresentations designed to deceive potential bidders." It added that Mr. Walton "had never been married, and had never had a child," and that he bought the picture at a secondhand shop in Littlerock, Calif.
The price of the painting skyrocketed on speculation that it might have been created by Richard Diebenkorn. The three defendants made more than 50 bids on the painting, the indictment says, and a man in the Netherlands placed the winning bid. The auction company later nullified the sale and suspended Mr. Walton for bidding on his own painting under at least five Internet names.
According to the indictment, the bidding ring had eclectic tastes in art, selling and bidding on hundreds of paintings that seemed to have been created by artists like Edward Hopper, Alberto Giacometti and Clyfford Still. The indictment states that Mr. Fetterman and Mr. Walton went so far as to create user ID's that included the names "Giacometti" and "Still" to give the impression that "a family member of the famous artists was bidding in the auctions of those paintings."
The two men also created an e-mail account for Gerald Stone, a fictitious expert on the art of Still, according to the indictment, and "Stone" sent an e-mail message to the winning bidder of the sham Still painting, congratulating the buyer for recognizing an "excellent example" of the artist's work. 
Online auctions remain one of the few raging successes of the faltering Internet economy, and eBay is by far the largest of the companies offering auctions online. In the fourth quarter of 2000, eBay had 22.5 million registered users, more than double the number it had in December 1999; some six million auctions are taking place at any time, adding up to more than 200 million auctions a year.
The site's visitors spend more than $5 billion a year on items that include baseball cards and cars. Current auctions include the $5 million Florida castle of the sculptor Howard Solomon, and 41,686 separate auctions of items pertaining to the late Dale Earnhardt, the Nascar driver who died last month in a crash at the Daytona 500.
Because auction sites like eBay are open to all -- eBay allows anyone to list an item for a fee of 25 cents to $2 -- the sites have been used to commit a wide range of swindles. Most of those turn on sellers receiving payment for goods they never ship, or for products that are damaged or less valuable than described. The number of auction fraud complaints to the Federal Trade Commission has leaped to nearly 11,000 in 2000, from 107 in 1997. Last year, "they accounted for 8 percent of all consumer complaints to the F.T.C.," said an agency spokeswoman, Claudia Bourne Farrell.
EBay's critics have long contended that the site could do far more to combat fraud. But eBay insists that it has taken forceful action to reduce fraud. It has sporadically used Shill Hunter, software developed by the company to spot questionable bidding, before the "Diebenkorn" case arose, said Robert C. Chesnut, deputy general counsel for the company. But in the months since the case was publicized, the company has improved the software, Mr. Chesnut said, and has added another software tool to help identify shill bids as they happen. 
Those tools cannot scan every auction, Mr. Chesnut said, but he compared the software to police with radar guns on the highway: "It sends a message," he said.
The company, he said, was pleased to hear of the indictments. "It helps send a message, and educate our user base that this isn't proper," Mr. Chesnut said. "If you do it, there can be serious consequences."
The United States attorney's office in Sacramento said eBay "provided substantial assistance" in the investigation.
David J. Carlson, a California art dealer who employs three "e-pickers" to search for authentic paintings on eBay that he might buy for resale, said that he had seen a recent drop-off in obviously fraudulent activity on the site. "Ring bidding is practically nil," he said. "It's as clean as I've ever seen it."
One bidder in the auction for the "R.D." painting, Mark Hudnall, said that he had bid $125,000 on the painting and, after being outbid, consulted Mr. Carlson about the painting. "I was ready to go to $350,000," said Mr. Hudnall, who lives in the San Francisco Bay area. Mr. Carlson raised doubts about the painting, and Mr. Hudnall did not raise his bid. "I learned a great big lesson," Mr. Hudnall said. 
Mr. Fetterman's lawyer, Mary French of the federal public defender's office in Sacramento, said that she could not comment on the case. Mr. Beach could not be reached for comment.
A lawyer for Mr. Walton, Harold Rosenthal, said yesterday that his client cooperated fully with the investigation. "He's a good guy, and this is a dumb, juvenile thing that got out of hand," Mr. Rosenthal said. "It makes me want to hit him over the head."

COMPANY: EBAY INC (95%)

HEADLINE: CHINA'S LEADERSHIP PUSHES FOR UNITY 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM and ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 8 

 BODY:
Last month, President Jiang Zemin summoned more than 2,000 top Communist Party officials to Beijing for an extraordinary, closed-door meeting.
 At a crucial point in his political life, Mr. Jiang wanted to make sure that the ruling party remained firmly unified on two divisive issues: the campaign to crush the Falun Gong spiritual movement and the correctness of the party's decision to use troops against the 1989 pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square. 
 Such a large scale "central work conference" had not been held since 1988, political experts said. The one convened in February reflects the leadership's deep unease about party unity and domestic stability, even as their country emerges as a world power and as Mr. Jiang, who is expected to step down as president and party chief in the next two years, worries about a smooth transition and his own legacy. 
Seeking to counter rumors of high-level discord, the seven members of the Standing Committee of the party's Politburo -- the men who effectively rule the country -- stood up one by one to endorse the anti-Falun Gong campaign as an urgent necessity and to justify the 1989 crackdown, according to two officials who attended separate, detailed briefings on the meeting as part of the leadership's effort to spread the message through party ranks. 
The two said they spoke because they had misgivings about the leadership's strategy. "It is very rare to hold this kind of meeting now, and in Beijing," said one of the officials, noting that major issues of party policy and unity are normally dealt with during the leaders' summer retreat at the seaside resort of Beidaihe. "So you know this has to be very, very important to them."
Mr. Jiang warned his audience that Western powers were trying to use the Falun Gong conflict and the memory of Tiananmen to divide the party as it nears pivotal changes in leadership over the next two years, the officials said. 
Although Mr. Jiang has pursued friendlier ties with the United States, he appears to harbor deep suspicions about American motives -- or, at least, is not above using the "American threat" as a rallying cry to bolster his own position.
The leaders also reportedly expressed concern about anti-China currents within the Bush administration and warned that relations could go through a rough period, especially if the United States sells advanced weapons to Taiwan.
Although no one suggests that the party is in imminent danger of falling from power, it has no overwhelmingly dominant leader like Mao Zedong or Deng Xiaoping and indications are plentiful that the center is not holding as it once did.
At last month's conference, Mr. Jiang complained that some local leaders had been unenthusiastic about the drive to stamp out Falun Gong, allowing practitioners to go to Beijing where they have held almost daily silent protests in Tiananmen Square. Before the movement was banned as an "evil sect" last year, Falun Gong had attracted millions of ordinary Chinese with its meditative exercises said to bring about good health and spiritual salvation.
Under guidance from a new office in Beijing, each province has set up a team to coordinate the anti-Falun Gong battle using a two-pronged strategy: prison or "re-education" for leaders and recalcitrant members; intense propaganda demonizing the group for everyone else. 
But not everyone has been in step: At least one group of police officers, from the northeastern city of Shenyang, has written to the party's main newspaper, the People's Daily, to complain that the government's strategy of harsh repression is not working, a journalist with a state newspaper said. The letter was not printed.
Meanwhile, demonstrations by angry workers and farmers over issues like unpaid pensions, taxes and corruption have become commonplace. Even party stalwarts express amazement at the scale of the official corruption that is emerging from investigations around the country.
Adding to their sense of apprehension, Mr. Jiang and the rest of the leaders are taking what they see as major but necessary political risks in opening the economy further to the pressures of global competition. A temporary surge in unemployment and other dislocations are expected as China joins the World Trade Organization.
The officials said the February meeting was in part an attempt to make sure that Mr. Jiang's policies would be continued by his successors and to demonstrate to all officials that it would be risky to step out of line. 
Mr. Jiang and other top leaders made it clear that they hope to crush the defiant Falun Gong movement altogether before the 16th Communist Party Congress, to be held in the fall of 2002, when the transition to new leaders is expected to begin, the official said. 
"If this isn't solved by then it opens the possibility of a rift between the old and new leaders and that could be a real threat," one of the officials said.
A central message at the February meeting, the officials said, was that the United States and other Western powers are trying to use the Falun Gong issue and memories of the violent 1989 crackdown to drive a wedge between the current, aging leaders and their potential successors, who might find it to their political advantage to break with unpopular policies.
The recent publication in the United States of "The Tiananmen Papers," said to be secret records of leaders' deliberations as they decided to use military force to halt the demonstrations, was cited by Mr. Jiang and other top leaders at the meeting as a deliberate Western effort to split the party, the officials said. 
The book of transcripts was published in English in January and has not been widely seen here outside elite and scholarly circles. Government officials have tried to dismiss it as a fabrication, though many experts here and abroad say the documents appear to be genuine.
The papers will soon be published outside mainland China in the original Chinese, which is likely to lead to much broader circulation and discussion here via the Internet and contraband copies. While the transcripts provide no explosive revelations they provide potentially embarrassing details about the roles in the 1989 crackdown of current leaders such as Li Peng, the former prime minister who now ranks No. 2 in the party and is chairman of the National People's Congress, or Parliament. And they describe Mr. Jiang's accession to party leadership that year as having been personally engineered by Deng Xiaoping, even though Deng, the most respected figure in Chinese politics then, lacked the formal authority to do this.
"The spirit of the meeting," said one official, "was that although Falun Gong and the Tiananmen papers are threats to the party in their own right, both are also symptoms of renewed efforts in the West to undermine the Communist Party and, in particular, to sabotage preparations for the 16th Party Congress." 
The official added, "The leaders asserted that Falun Gong has become a tool of hostile Western forces, directly nurtured and protected by, among others, the C.I.A." 
As for the Tiananmen papers, the leaders reportedly said that "although the book is in itself inconsequential, it is a sign of stepped-up Western efforts to destabilize China and sow division within the party." 
The unusual gathering in February of a central work conference was featured at the time in the state-run press as an important meeting, but the specific topics were not disclosed beyond vague calls for unity and support for Mr. Jiang's opaque refinements of ideology. It was attended by all senior central officials, top party leaders from each province and leaders of the military, the judiciary and government ministries. 
After the meeting, senior officials fanned out to brief party organizations and government agencies about the message. 
This week, thousands of Chinese officials are gathered in Beijing for the annual 10-day session of the National People's Congress, which has been devoted mainly to announcing the government's economic plans. Bold political initiatives appear to be on hold as the leaders scramble behind closed doors to influence the scheduled change in the country's top three positions over the coming two years.
Mr. Jiang, 74, is expected to step down as party secretary at the party congress next fall after serving since 1989, though there is speculation that he will try to keep another senior post and hopes to run the country behind the scenes. He will remain president until his term expires in spring 2003. 
At that time, Li Peng, 72, is expected to retire from his major party and parliamentary posts and the No. 3 leader, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, 72 is also scheduled to step down, as are several other senior leaders who have reached or passed the age of 70. 
Party members and diplomats widely assume that the youngest member of the Standing Committee, Vice President Hu Jintao, 58, will succeed Mr. Jiang as party general secretary and then as president. But the politics and process of the succession are known only to a small circle. 
Mr. Hu, former chief of the Communist Youth League and party chief of two provinces, has kept a relatively low profile during his rise to power. Western diplomats, who have rarely even met the man, call him a "political cypher."
He is widely believed to have been designated in the early 1990's by Deng Xiaoping, as the best successor to Mr. Jiang's generation. There have been no open signs of discord between Mr. Hu and Mr. Jiang, but his rise through the ranks did not depend on Mr. Jiang's patronage, either.
The struggle to eradicate Falun Gong and discredit its leader in exile, Li Hongzhi, was set off in 1999 after 10,000 followers held an illegal vigil outside the leadership compound in Beijing, calling for official recognition. It has been a messy and unpleasant campaign involving intense, crude propaganda and the detention of tens of thousands of otherwise law-abiding citizens, leaving many Chinese feeling uneasy. 
Mr. Jiang and other leaders appear worried that if the struggle against Falun Gong drags on too long it could, in fact, cause divisions at the top.
Mr. Jiang is also worried about his historical legacy and if he steps down without resolving the bitter conflict, his reputation may suffer.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Best Incentive For Job Safety: Money

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
HERE we go again. By rescinding a new set of ergonomic regulations, Congress this week raised an old question: do the workers of the world need politicians and union leaders to write safety rules for them?
 It's a touchy issue, as I discovered from the large pile of hate mail that arrived after a column in 1999 about the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire. I questioned the popular view, as expressed in a documentary by Ric Burns, that the 1911 fire inspired "epoch making" reforms protecting "hapless" workers against "nightmarish" exploitation by employers. 
 The less popular view, as expressed by the economists I quoted, is that workplace safety rules never did much to protect workers. Conditions improved over the last century because safety was profitable: employers wanted to avoid injuries that lessened productivity and drove up costs, notably the bill for workers' compensation insurance.
Readers were appalled at these arguments -- callous abstractions, they said. How could I ignore the gruesome evidence of employer negligence at the Triangle factory? Descendants of garment workers cursed me. Labor activists said I was living in an economist's dream world. More than one reader wished me a severe occupational injury.
As it happens, I did have an injury on the job, and it was just the kind being debated in Washington this week. While typing my way through the 1992 presidential campaign, I came down with tendinitis in both forearms. I was one of the early victims of an epidemic of repetitive strain injuries (which included carpal tunnel syndrome) that hit reporters and editors at The New York Times in the early 1990's.
It was a scary time for us, because little was known about the injuries, and horror stories abounded. We heard of workers who were permanently incapacitated, unable to open jars or button shirts. Those of us who stopped working -- I was out of commission for six months and couldn't type normally for a year -- spent a lot of time imagining career options for a former journalist unable to type.
We were furious at our employer. We blamed the deadline pressure at the paper for our injuries. There were angry conversations about the managers' ruthlessly working us into the ground, secure in the knowledge that plenty of replacements were available from other papers. Veterans feared that managers secretly welcomed the chance to replace them with younger journalists who would work longer hours for less pay.
There were threats of lawsuits and calls for union action, none of which amounted to anything. Our union, as far as I could see, did zero to help me. Nor did we get any help from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, which would spend most of the next decade drawing up the regulations that Congress voted down this week.
BY the time OSHA acted, our problem had long since been brought under control by workers and managers. Those of us who were injured experimented, at company expense, with various kinds of therapy and equipment. Many beat the problem just by learning to pace themselves and relax their muscles. Some switched to new equipment, including voice-activated computers (or, in my case, a weird keyboard with keys at a nearly vertical angle that put my forearms in the same position as an accordion player's).
Meanwhile, the company hired experts to educate workers and redesign office equipment to avoid injuries. Through all these efforts, the epidemic ended -- without any guidance from Washington.
You could argue that we were lucky here because we had enlightened managers. (My bosses would welcome that theory.) You could argue that other kinds of workers, like blue-collar ones in unskilled jobs, wouldn't be treated so well because they're more expendable.
But the experience in this office is hardly unique: repetitive strain injuries have been declining across the country in recent years. Companies do not want to lose experienced workers of any kind, if only because replacing them takes time and money. Every company, like The Times, knows that injuries mean potential lawsuits as well as higher premiums for workers' compensation insurance.
So why do workers across America now need OSHA's ergonomic expertise? Not because they're being exploited by ruthless employers. The best justification for the new rules is that employers and workers both fail to appreciate the benefits of spending more money on safety -- a difficult argument, although not an impossible one. More on that next week. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Free Spending in Flush Times Is Coming Back to Haunt States 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
The State of Missouri was feeling generous. The economy was booming; tax dollars were pouring in and legislators decided to use some of the money to expand a modest program that gave a stipend to grandparents acting as foster parents to their grandchildren. 
 But the state did not just expand it a little. 
 With bipartisan support, the Legislature dropped virtually all restrictions on who could qualify for the $386 monthly payment, scrapping a requirement that the children be in financial need and dropping the minimum age of the grandparent to 50 from 55. The state even opened the program to people who were not grandparents at all -- aunts, uncles and other close relatives. 
The consequences have been startling. Participation skyrocketed from 280 children in August 1999 to 2,239 children now. Expected to cost $1.4 million through the fiscal year ending in June, it will now cost $10.7 million. And $22.4 million is needed for the next fiscal year.
"Quite frankly, I voted for it," said State Representative Kenneth Legan, a Republican. But "it's costing us about 16 times more than we thought it would. We think it's going to cost even more if we can't figure out how to stop it."
Mr. Legan considers himself a fiscal conservative, but a couple of years ago he and countless other lawmakers in state capitols across the country were showing uncharacteristically little fiscal restraint. In Louisiana, tens of thousands of students got free tuition at state colleges; Iowa promised school teachers thousands of dollars in bonuses; Arizona offered millions in subsidies to help people buy cars that burned cleaner fuels.
And some lawmakers say they wish they had paid more attention to how much it would ultimately cost. "I'm sure we weren't looking as close to fiscal notes as we ought to be," Mr. Legan said.
Now, thrown off balance by a suddenly sluggish economy, Missouri and many other states are finding that decisions or promises to spend money when times were flush are coming back to haunt them.
From Connecticut to Indiana, Louisiana to Arizona, governors and legislators are trying to rein in commitments for health, social or environmental programs, college scholarships, prison building or teacher bonuses. Some will have a hard time finding the money to open prisons they are building or make good on promised raises for teachers.
As of late February, 31 states reported they were spending more than they budgeted, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. And, grappling with declining tax revenues and soaring Medicaid costs, as many as 23 states may cut budgets or reach into rainy day funds for the first time in years.
Experts on state budgets say the experience of states that allocated money for programs and then suddenly found they could not afford them could be something of a cautionary tale for Congress as it considers President Bush's proposed tax cut of $1.6 trillion over 10 years.
"Things got a little heady in that we were dealing with the longest economic expansion in history and nobody knew how long it was going to continue," said Arturo Perez, a budget specialist with the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Even so, despite the troubles faced by many states -- particularly those that rely on sales tax revenues -- estimates of federal tax revenues remain strong, and most experts expect the government to continue to run surpluses for years to come. 
In addition, Mr. Perez said that in some ways federal budgets were more resilient to economic rough spots than states' budgets were.
But on the state level, where governments cannot run deficits, the rising costs of some programs are colliding head on with shrinking tax revenues.
In Louisiana, a program providing free tuition at state universities for students scoring 20 or above on the ACT has become so expensive that several legislators want it scaled back, either by raising the minimum score to 23 or forcing students who fail or drop out to reimburse the state. The top ACT score is 36.
State Representative Mike Futrell, a Republican, said the tuition program was so popular that virtually every in-state undergraduate attending Louisiana State University gets free tuition. Statewide, more than a third of those with ACT scores below 23 have failed or quit, Mr. Futrell said. 
"Statistically, we are financing their failure," said Mr. Futrell, who introduced a bill to give those scoring 20 to 23 tuition to two-year community colleges only. That would be "a lot less expensive," he said, than the $105 million projected cost of the program next year. 
Missouri is looking at a $307 million budget deficit, in part because of the exploding costs of the foster care program and also because of what Mr. Legan calls "another boondoggle": a tax credit to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs. When the credit was approved, it was expected to cost $20 million a year. Mr. Legan, who voted for the program, said the current pricetag was about $89 million. 
Arizona told people last year that if they bought cars that could burn alternative fuels, the state would pay up to half the cost. So many people applied for reimbursement that a program expected to cost less than $5 million annually threatened to reach $800 million, more than 10 percent of the state's budget.
"Frankly, nobody looked at the big picture when the bill was passed, and I take my share of the blame for signing it," Gov. Jane Dee Hull, a Republican, said last fall after calling for an emergency one-year moratorium on the program.
"The fiscal implications were all overlooked," Governor Hull said. "No one knew what the cost would be."
New York and New Jersey, which rely less on sales taxes and manufacturing than other states, continue to have surpluses and have no plans to cut budgets or tap their reserves, Mr. Perez said. But in Connecticut, one of many states that spent millions to build prisons in recent years, Gov. John G. Rowland's budget includes ideas that would save money by reducing the need for new prison cells. Strikingly, the proposals by Governor Rowland, a Republican, would also modify years of tough-on-crime policies by waiving minimum sentencing requirements for certain nonviolent drug offenders and allocating money so some nonviolent criminals could get mental health treatment instead of jail. 
"There are a lot of good examples of states around the country that went on a prison-building spree and now they're saying, 'Oh, my God, we're not going to be able to afford another prison,' " said Michael Thompson, a criminal-justice expert for the eastern region of the Council of State Governments.
Mr. Thompson said Mr. Rowland's proposals follow an effort last year to save money on new prisons by exporting nearly 500 Connecticut inmates to a Virginia prison. Problems, including inmate deaths, have fueled criticism of that program, he said, "so Connecticut's saying, We got to rethink who we're sending to prison or jail."
John Thomasian, director of the Center for Best Practices at the National Governors' Association, said that in many states, "where you saw a lot of expansions were support systems for low-income workers: transportation subsidies, child care benefits, automobile repair costs." 
In Indiana, officials started an advertising blitz to get people to enroll in the Children's Health Insurance Program in 1998. They used television, radio and billboards, handed out pencils and baby sippy cups, even set up separate enrollment centers so people could avoid any stigma of going to a welfare office, said Kathy Gifford, Indiana's Medicaid director. 
The result was an extraordinary increase in enrollment -- to about 350,000 children from about 200,000, Ms. Gifford said. More children are enrolling after officials last year raised the income level of families that qualify. And the advertising swelled the numbers of adults on Medicaid, too. 
Now, although Ms. Gifford says Medicaid needs a 9.2 percent increase next year, the Indiana House has proposed a Medicaid budget that scarcely increases at all.
"I don't have a way that I know today to get to a zero percent growth rate by July," she said. "I don't know what we would do if that budget actually passes."
And in Iowa, lawmakers decided in 1998 to give teachers who earned national board certification a $50,000 award -- $10,000 a year for five years. But, almost immediately nearly six times more than the projected number of teachers became certified. The Legislature first decided to pay out the bonus over 10 years, then cut the award to $25,000 and decided to phase out the program.
"We were criticized for not living up to promises made," said Representative Brad Hansen, a Republican. "But when budgets get tight, we ask families to tighten the belt. The government should have to do the same thing."
In Missouri, legislators are trying to figure out ways to put the runaway programs on a leash.
The problem with the elderly tax credit, several said, was that anyone who met the income and age criteria could qualify for a tax credit of up to $200, whether or not they actually needed or bought prescription drugs.
"We were qualifying people for this that are in nursing homes, who haven't spent a dime because the state pays for prescriptions in nursing homes anyway," Mr. Legan said.
And State Representative Denny Meredith, a Democrat, is sponsoring a bill to restrict the foster-care program to people in financial need and ensure that expense reimbursements from the state are for necessities, not, say, a baby sitter while foster parents "go shopping on Sunday," he said.
"It's something that we've got to do from a responsibility standpoint," Mr. Meredith said, "to make sure we take care of the state budget."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL; 
The Mets Take Aim But Miss Their Mark

BYLINE:  By Murray Chass 

DATELINE: KISSIMMEE, Fla. 

 BODY:
Add Gary Sheffield to the list, and the easiest reaction would be to question, even criticize the Mets for their winter failures. They coveted three free-agent pitchers -- Mike Hampton, Mike Mussina and Denny Neagle -- as well as a pitcher who was on the trading block, David Wells, and they snared none of them. They desired Alex Rodriguez and Johnny Damon and flirted with Sheffield and captured none of them.
 With General Manager Steve Phillips's declaration that he will no longer pursue a trade for Sheffield with the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Mets have basically decided they will begin defense of their National League pennant with the team that occupies their spring camp in Port St. Lucie on this day. 
 Phillips's decision to abandon his half-hearted pursuit of the slugging outfielder marked the second time in the past few years that he has shunned Sheffield. The reasons were basically the same -- the other team's asking price and the player's attitude.
"It was Kevin's expectation to have done something by now," another general manager said of Kevin Malone, the Dodgers' trade-maker, "but every time the outfielder opens his mouth, it makes his task tougher."
Having heard the wild-mouthed rhetoric that has emanated from Sheffield's outrageous orifice, the Mets concluded that they could quickly become the next target of his economic unhappiness.
Sheffield, tied to his contract for at least three more years, saw the groundbreaking contracts that were awarded during the off-season and decided to make a play for one of his own. He couldn't wait until he was 36 years old and at the end of his contract, after all, and expect to get one of those gifts. Sheffield struck out, but he continued swinging.
Now other teams have to decide if they want to take a chance on his intemperate behavior. The Mets no longer are one of them.
But where does their decision leave the Mets?
Despite their attempts to rationalize their previous failures, one would be hard pressed to view these Mets as being as good as the team that played in the World Series last season. At the same time, however, they deserve the chance to prove themselves correct in their self-assessment.
Whatever anyone thinks of the Mets' decisions and their unwillingness to offer more money to a free agent or more talented players to another team, the ultimate and only test will be graded in October.
If the Mets make the playoffs again, it will be difficult to fault their failure to get one or more of the players they sought. If they don't make it to the playoffs for the first time in three years, they will deserve all of the criticism rendered.
Phillips undoubtedly is putting his growing reputation squarely on the chopping block. Even though the Mets' owners have supported his moves, or lack of same, his public reputation will suffer if the Mets neither win the division championship nor continue their annual role as the wild-card team.
Forget the signing of the two starting pitchers, Kevin Appier and Steve Trachsel. They are replacements, not reinforcements. This is the first time in three years that the Mets have not bolstered themselves with the addition of significant players -- Al Leiter three years ago, Mike Piazza in May 1998, Robin Ventura and Armando Benitez two off-seasons ago, Hampton and Todd Zeile last off-season.
The Mets won the wild-card spot in the playoffs in 1999 and 2000 because they added those players. Tsuyoshi Shinjo, the outfielder with the questionable ability to hit major league pitching whom they signed this off-season, will not serve that purpose.
But the Mets and the teams that will challenge them for their playoff spot still have to play the season. Who among us knows whether the Mets have undermined their chances to be a playoff repeater? Remember, Phillips is the same man who built the teams that put the Mets in position to be a playoff repeater. A team can't be a repeater this year if it wasn't in the playoffs last year.
So if Phillips believes this team can make it again, give him the opportunity to find out if he's right. The Mets, it should be noted, don't have to get to the World Series again to validate Phillips's thinking. Ask the Atlanta Braves.
If the Mets fail, there will be plenty of time to roast Phillips. Of all the decisions he made in not securing a player the Mets wanted, the one that could be viewed with a questionable eye was the Mets' rapid removal from the Alex Rodriguez sweepstakes. That was the decision that could haunt the Mets, but even that possibility needs time to play out.

BRITISH INTEREST RATE UNCHANGED

BYLINE:  By Alan Cowell 

 BODY:
 As expected, the Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.75 percent, reflecting economists' assessments that the slowdown in the United States will have a limited impact in Britain. 
The bank cut the rate by one quarter of a percentage point a month ago, coinciding with concerns about the United States slowdown. Since then, statistics have shown an expansion in British house prices, service industries and consumer spending. Alan Cowell (NYT)

REPORT NOTES EXPORT STRENGTH

 BODY:
 Exports are increasingly important to New York's economy, according to a report to be released today by goTrade New York, a business group promoting international trade. 
The group calculated that New York State exported more than $27 billion in services like financing, accounting and consulting in 1999, supporting about 400,000 jobs. The state also exported more than $43 billion in merchandise -- including machinery, chemicals and food -- which the group said accounted for 473,000 jobs. Leslie Eaton

HEADLINE: National News Briefs; 
Jackson Defends Policies That Help Friends Profit

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 8 

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that there was nothing wrong with friends and civil rights groups profiting from companies that he had singled out in his effort to increase minority representation in business. 
 Mr. Jackson likened his tactics, including threats of boycotts and protests of proposed mergers, to the bus boycotts and civil rights marches of the 1960's. And he said if his friends who are minority entrepreneurs benefited, it was all the better. 
 "If we can get these very able people in, we'll break down the barriers, and that is our mission," Mr. Jackson said. "Of course they are friends, but that's not the basis of their getting business."
Mr. Jackson held a news conference to release financial records for two of his groups, Citizenship Education Fund and Rainbow/PUSH Coalition. An internal audit lists corporations that have donated to his groups.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
In Hewlett-Packard's new campaign, innovation moves from the garage to the laboratory.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE next phase of an ambitious, attention-getting campaign for the Hewlett-Packard Company leaves the garage to assert that past is prologue.
 The campaign, which begins on Sunday, retains the theme "Invent" that was introduced in November 1999, when Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco began efforts to burnish the Hewlett-Packard brand by adopting as a symbol the garage in which the company was founded in 1938 by William Hewlett and David Packard. 
 The next step in the campaign, with a yearlong global budget estimated at $100 million, is centered on current Hewlett-Packard employees. They outline projects under way at six laboratories around the world in areas from streaming video to wireless devices to image-processing microchips. 
In the television commercials and print advertisements and on outdoor posters and the Hewlett-Packard Web site (www.hp.com), the employees are presented as innovative inventors whose work at the laboratories -- referred to throughout the campaign as the "hp labs" -- makes them the spiritual descendants of the company's founders.
The main thought expressed in the humorous ads is that Hewlett-Packard's heritage can predict its future -- a crucial reassurance at a time of uncertainty in the high-technology and general economies as well as for Hewlett-Packard, which in the midst of a revamping recently fell short of analysts' financial projections.
"The first stage was to reignite the spirit of invention at H.-P.," said Allison Johnson, vice president for brand strategy and communications at Hewlett-Packard in Palo Alto, Calif. "The next is reminding people where we came from in the context of where we're headed."
"From a brand strategy perspective," she added, the goal is "to reconnect with our inventive roots and remind people we're the company started by the original inventors who invented Silicon Valley."
The change is indicative of the need perceived by advertisers and agencies to more frequently freshen continuing campaigns to avoid fatigue among the intended audiences for sales pitches. Here, Hewlett-Packard is aiming the ads not only at the customers for its computers, software, printers and consulting services but also at employees, investors and Wall Street analysts.
"I think the idea came from Carly Fiorina, who said what gets her most excited is walking through the labs talking to people," said Rich Silverstein, referring to the chairwoman and chief executive of Hewlett-Packard. Mr. Silverstein shares with Jeff Goodby the duties of chairman and creative director at Goodby, Silverstein, the Omnicom Group agency that handles the lead corporate brand assignment.
"The brand stands for 'Invent,' and how do we show that?" Mr. Silverstein asked rhetorically. "Right under our noses was the answer. We're trying to put a face on a very large company, and that face is the employees."
"We're saying 'Our inventors work here every day,' " he added, "and they're the real thing. Inventors are cool."
Speaking of which, Mr. Silverstein said he was particularly impressed by Cooltown, a section of the Palo Alto laboratory specializing in wired and wireless technologies and appliances devoted to mobile Web services. One such invention is featured in the campaign in a way that is cool, literally and figuratively.
Rycharde Hawkes, a senior research engineer, describes a pilot project in Helsinki, Finland, which sends customers of the public transportation system alerts over their cellular phones when buses are approaching. Frosty winter images like a snowy street and Mr. Hawkes photographed as if encased in ice suggest just how welcome those messages would be if you have "ever waited for a bus in Helsinki in December."
The polished, poised performance Mr. Hawkes delivers in a commercial demonstrating the project is evocative of the actor Jude Law, whom he resembles in appearance and accent. He is one of five employees of the laboratories in the campaign's initial phase, which will include the first Hewlett-Packard sponsorship of the Academy Awards broadcast on ABC.
Mr. Hawkes and the other "new Bills and Daves," Ms. Johnson said, are being selected for the campaign using criteria that include whether the projects are "meaningful to people in their everyday lives" and are "things people will see in a short period of time" rather than in the far-off future.
The employees are a mosaic of men and women of different races and national origins because Hewlett "is a global company and a diverse company," she added, "and that's an important component."
Another employee who, like Mr. Hawkes, is appearing in a commercial and a print ad is Susie J. Wee, project manager for streaming media technologies.
"I thought 'This could be fun; I'll give it a shot,' " Ms. Wee said in a telephone interview. When she filmed the spot -- in which she predicts a day when mountain climbers can keep up with their favorite soap operas -- she said she was surprised at "all these people milling around to make one little commercial; I was asking 'What do you do? What do you do?' "
Ms. Wee said she was unsure how many people she knew would see the spot because "to be honest, not many of my friends watch TV; we're too busy doing our work."
Asked her opinion of her ads, Ms. Wee said she believed they turned out "great."
But, she added, laughing, "I don't think I'll be quitting my day job."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Intel Again Warns of Slumping Revenue This Quarter

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 

 BODY:
For the second time in six weeks, Intel today cautioned that its revenue this quarter would fall short of Wall Street's expectations.
 The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., also said it would eliminate 5,000 jobs by year's end, mainly through normal attrition, and trim spending on research and development by 2 percent. 
 Intel said it expected revenue for its first quarter, which ends March 31, to be 25 percent less than its previous quarter, when it reported $8.7 billion in sales. In January, Intel estimated that its revenue would decline 15 percent. 
Intel did not offer any forecast for the rest of this year. Andy D. Bryant, the company's chief financial officer, said he would do so when the company reported earnings for this quarter, on April 18.
Intel, the world's largest chip maker, said large customers had canceled orders in all segments of its business.
A decline in sales for its microprocessors, which power personal computers, was expected. But Intel said demand was even weaker for chips that power server systems, communications devices and networking systems.
"We expected it to pick up here in the second half of the quarter, and we haven't seen it," Mr. Bryant said of the company's sales. "There are days you come in and you find two positive signs, and the next day you come in and find three negative signs."
An announcement late today by National Semiconductor, another chip maker, illustrated Mr. Bryant's point. The company reported earnings for its fiscal third quarter, ended Feb. 25, of 27 cents a share, beating Wall Street's per-share estimates by 7 cents. But the company, also based in Santa Clara, cut its estimates for the current quarter by 10 percent.
Two other smaller chip makers, RF Micro Devices and Integrated Circuit Systems, also lowered their expectations for the quarter, citing the same slump in demand as Intel and National Semiconductor.
Analysts said Intel's warning came as little surprise.
"They're just the latest to go to the confessional booth," David Wu, an analyst with ABN Amro Inc., an investment bank.
Craig Barrett, Intel's chief executive, had repeatedly said he intended to spend his way through the economic slowdown. His colleagues repeated his assertions today, even after cutting the research and development budget from $4.3 billion this year to $4.2 billion. The $100 million in savings will come through thrifty spending, they said, not through the elimination of development programs for its products. 
"They're just not going to cut those that much," said Joseph A. Osha, a senior semiconductor analyst with Merrill Lynch, "as long as they continue to believe at some point over the next year or two, business is going to get better."
Intel said it intended to reduce its work force from 87,000 to 82,000 by the end of the year and accelerate cost-saving efforts announced last month. The moves include the postponement of employee pay increases until the second half of the year and a 30 percent reduction in "discretionary expenses" like employee travel.
"While slashing nonessential spending across the company," Mr. Bryant said, "we are protecting investments we think will make Intel more competitive."
Before Intel's announcement late today, the company's shares rose 31 cents, or 1 percent, to $33.25. The shares fell to $30.94 in after-hours trading. National Semiconductor gained 41 cents, or 1.65 percent, to $25.25. In after-hours trading, the shares fell 45 cents, to $24.80.

HEADLINE: Discount Stores Spur Increase in Retail Sales 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Sales at American retailers edged up in February, led by Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the Kmart Corporation and the Costco Wholesale Corporation, as a slowing economy prompted consumers to buy low-priced household goods and clothing.
 Sales at stores open at least a year, a crucial industry measurement, rose 1.6 percent, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index. That was less than January's 3.4 percent gain and well below the 5.1 percent rise in February 2000. 
 Merchants cleared out leftover holiday items and restocked stores with spring goods. Consumers, whose confidence in the economy fell last month to the lowest point in more than four and a half years, did most of their shopping at discount chains that sell basic products and food.
"Consumers clearly are buying less, but they aren't afraid, they're just finicky," said Steve Paspal, an analyst at Sovereign Asset Management, a unit of John Hancock Funds.
Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, said that its same-store sales rose 4.3 percent.
Costco, the nation's biggest chain of warehouse clubs, had a 5 percent increase, and Kmart posted a 3.3 percent gain. Target, the third-biggest discount store, said sales rose 1.5 percent.
The sales gain at Kmart, the No. 2 discount chain after Wal-Mart, was the fourth consecutive monthly increase and was at the high end of forecasts.
Family Dollar Stores Inc. had a 5 percent gain, and the rival Dollar General Corporation reported a 4.7 percent increase.
Few gains were posted among specialty and department store chains. Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's biggest department store company, said its sales dropped 2 percent.
The May Department Stores Company, which owns the Hecht's and Lord & Taylor chains, posted a 1.1 percent decline, while sales at Federated Department Stores Inc., which owns Bloomingdale's and Macy's stores, fell 1.6 percent.
Dillard's Inc. dropped 2 percent, and Saks Inc., which sells luxury goods, fell 1.3 percent. The J. C. Penney Company posted a 2.1 percent decline. Its same-store sales dropped in seven of the last eight months.
"It's devastating," Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report, said of the performance of department stores and specialty apparel stores. "Terrible is a kind word."
An exception to these results was the Kohl's Corporation, a low-priced department store, which had a 7.3 percent jump in sales.
Sales at Gap Inc., the nation's largest clothing chain, dropped 11 percent. The company, which owns the Gap, Old Navy and Banana Republic chains, is trying to improve marketing, apparel offerings and management to reverse a slump.
Talbots Inc., a women's career-clothing chain, had a 9.3 percent increase, which was at the high end of its forecasts. Sales at the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation fell 6.1 percent. The company lowered its profit forecasts for its first and second quarters yesterday because it has yet to clear out slow-selling contemporary styles and replace them with the classic fashions that Ann Taylor is known for.

HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By James Barron; With Glenn Collins

 BODY:
'My Way' the Wrong Way
 MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI has regrets about his performance last weekend at the Inner Circle, the roast by reporters that is traditionally followed by an equally theatrical response from the mayor -- but not, apparently, about dressing up in a Rockette costume and showing a lot of leg. 
 "I sang 'My Way' at the Inner Circle, and I ruined it," he declared on Wednesday during the intermission of "If It Was Easy," a new play, at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater on West 42nd Street, about the pre-opening night disasters that bedevil a Sinatra-themed musical.
"If It Was Easy" was directed by STEWART F. LANE, at whose 1997 wedding to BONNIE COMLEY the mayor officiated -- "Thank God I didn't sing on that occasion," Mr. Giuliani said. Ms. Comley happens to be the star of "If It Was Easy," and Mr. Lane's monogrammed office furniture happens to dominate the set. 
The mayor's good friend, JUDITH NATHAN, went with him to the play but sounded lukewarm about Sinatra. "I'm a fan of Sinatra," she said, "when Rudy is singing."

Buenos Dias, King
DAVE H. WILLIAMS, the chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, spoke little Spanish but carried a 113-year-old gift to his audience with KING JUAN CARLOS I of Spain on Wednesday in Madrid: a maritime print by "a bigtime etching guy," as Mr. Williams described the artist Charles Adams Platt.
It was an appropriate present, Mr. Williams said yesterday after returning to Manhattan, because the king is "a bigtime sailor." It came from Mr. Williams's collection of 5,000 prints. (The apple he gave Spain's conservative prime minister, JOSE MARIA AZNAR, came from Steuben.)
And Mr. Williams's Spanish?
"One year at Austin High School has not really made me much better than 'buenos dias,' " he said, "but nearly all the government people spoke English, with the exception of the president. He uses a translator."

Thirty Days Hath . . .
PETER NORTON, the entrepreneur whose face stares out from thousands of yellow boxes of software, read a flier about a trip to St. Petersburg being planned by the nonprofit American Friends of the Hermitage Museum and fired off an e-mail message to the group's executive director, KATE BROOKS: "Love to go but don't see how we can return on June 31st."
Only then did Dr. Brooks catch the error, which appeared in five places on the four-page flier: June, of course, has only 30 days.
"This is the kind of mistake you make on computers when you type your own stuff," she said. "I'm using the technology he invented, and that's the problem. I'm so proud I can open the e-mail and read it that I don't realize what the problem really is. For me, it's all about art and Catherine the Great."
St. Petersburg was familiar territory to many of the guests at a party for Dr. Brooks's group at the Forbes Gallery, at 60 Fifth Avenue, on Wednesday. CHRISTOPHER FORBES, pictured, the vice chairman of Forbes and the honorary chairman of an April 17 fund-raiser for the American Friends of the Hermitage, recalled a recent trip: "Only George Gilder outpulled my lecture at the Hermitage," he said, referring to the libertarian writer who became a cheerleader for the high-tech economy of the 1990's.
Mr. Forbes said his topic had been Faberge: "People don't look to me for investment advice."
