HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
That Other Maker of Andean Wines

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: MENDOZA, Argentina, March 4 

 BODY:
Kendall-Jackson, the California winemaker, has had its share of mishaps since it arrived in the vine-covered Andean foothills and valleys of western Argentina in 1996. 
 Ferocious hailstorms mangled one grape harvest. An early overreliance on oak barrel fermentation of its chardonnay and malbec produced some disappointing wines. And the marketing people tripped up when they named the initial line of Argentine wines "Mariposa," or Butterfly -- a name that unfortunately matched a low-quality Argentine sweet liqueur as well as the Latin American slang word for an effeminate man. 
 But despite Kendall-Jackson's fitful early experience, it is pressing ahead with an ambitious effort to expand the size of its vineyard and sell more wine at home and abroad. Joined by a raft of other foreign heavyweights -- like two from France, Pernod Ricard and Chandon, a unit of LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton; Allied Domecq of Britain; Sogrape of Portugal; and Concha y Toro of Chile -- the company is remaking Argentina's long-slumbering wine industry into a potential export powerhouse. 
With a goal of making Argentine malbec and syrah as fashionable on world markets as Argentine steaks and tango, foreign investors have plowed in more than $250 million over the last five years to open new wineries, refurbish old ones and enter into joint ventures with undercapitalized Argentine companies hankering to modernize. 
They have imported computerized irrigation systems, stainless steel vats, French and American oak barrels, and grape vines. They have brought in renowned French and California winemakers. And Argentine investors, often in partnership with the foreigners, have followed suit with $250 million in new investments in recent years.
"The sky is the limit," Randy Ullom, Kendall-Jackson's chief winemaker, said of his company's current $5 million investment, predicting that the company will invest several times that in the next seven years. He noted that the company had completed planting only 494 acres of its 2,717 acres in Mendoza Province, and many more grapes were coming. Expressing his enthusiasm in a flurry of metaphors, he added: "Like an iceberg you see the tip, and more is coming. Argentina is the sleeping giant of the wine world."
Kendall-Jackson executives are now laughing off their early cultural mistakes. They have a new management team in Argentina, including a new Chilean winemaker, and they are altering their fermentation techniques to produce better wines for local as well as foreign tastes. Production has soared from 21,000 cases in 1997 to 34,000 in 2000 to an estimated 75,000 in 2001, with hopes to reach 200,000 cases annually in five years.
"We believe Argentina is the next frontier in the world of wine," said Carlos Garcia, managing director for Latin America at Credit Suisse First Boston Private Equity, which has $75 million invested in Grupo Penaflor, Argentina's largest wine exporter. 
The Argentine wine industry goes back to the 1540's. But, isolated for decades because of political instability and triple-digit inflation that put imposing limits on borrowing, investing and consistent pricing of exports, Argentina fell well behind Chile and other producers then opening up to the world. But an economic recovery in the 1990's based largely on pegging the value of the peso to the dollar -- a policy known here as convertibility, which reduced inflation to almost zero -- finally made investment in the slumping wine industry viable again.
Argentine wine export sales have doubled since 1996, to $125 million in 2000. The increases would have been greater over the last two years had it not been for a patch of bad weather, a wine glut in the Japanese market, and a strengthening dollar and weakening euro and Chilean peso. 
But analysts say Argentine wines are bound to be competitive over the long term because of improving quality and because land and labor costs here remain well below those in Europe, Australia and the United States. They note that a recent firming of the euro should help the competitiveness of Argentina's wines in the months ahead.
"Convertibility might have put us at a disadvantage the last few years," said Luis Alfredo Pulenta, president of Grupo Penaflor, "but convertibility gave us the possibility to export in the first place." 
Argentina is poised for 15 percent growth in wine exports this year, according to investors and Argentine winemakers, and that is only the beginning. They say Argentina has the annual potential to export more than $1 billion worth of wine in another decade while maintaining a domestic market for fine wines that surpasses $1 billion in annual sales. 
New pumping technology to bring irrigation to higher and drier fields has already increased Argentine vine acreage 10 percent in the last five years, to 543,400 acres, even while tens of thousands of acres of old, low-quality vines have been uprooted to make room for premium grapes. Analysts say that by 2005, when the current round of plantings bear fruit, a million acres may be harvested, with more to come in a country that is already the world's No. 5 wine producer.
There is plenty of room to grow, even with domestic consumption lagging in the current recession. Argentine wine represented only 1 percent of total wine imports last year into the United States and Britain, this country's two largest foreign wine markets. Chile, which produces about half the wine that Argentina does, accounts for 4 percent of the wine imported to the United States.
But questions remain: Will Argentine producers improve marketing skills enough to sell the expected growth in production? Or will a glut force down prices and profits? 
Argentina has long been a country of big hopes and dashed dreams, where a generally uncreative business establishment has neglected marketing and international trade. Waves of foreign investors have come and gone. Ten percent of the Argentine economy is based on foreign commerce, compared with 30 percent for Chile. 
"We bought 900,000 cases of Concha y Toro for the Japanese market in 1998," noted Junichi Toyoda, president of Mitsubishi Argentina. "Argentina won't reach that level in 20 years. The quality of Argentine wine is good relative to the price, but Chile has the marketing know-how." 
No Argentine company comes close to the reach of Concha y Toro, the giant Chilean winemaker, which has advertised heavily for years -- from Tokyo's radio airwaves to a giant billboard on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. But several companies here are beginning to give the Chileans a run for the international market.
Argentine wineries are introducing multilingual Web sites, employing permanent sales representatives in Europe, Asia and the United States, and organizing junkets for international wine writers and vendors to visit Mendoza. Stodgy Argentine bottle labels have been replaced by cheerful, irregularly shaped labels that look as if they belong in Napa Valley. 
The changes in marketing strategies may be summed up in a label on Allied Domecq's Balbi syrah, designed by American artists specifically for the American market, which says, "This wine is ready to enjoy tonight with casual foods such as hamburgers or pizza." Any experienced Argentine wine drinker thinks of syrah as a noble red worthy of aging in a wine cellar before serving with a barbecued steak. 
But despite the razzmatazz, Allied Domecq has been careful about blending French and American techniques at its vineyard in the town of San Rafael. Since taking over the traditional medium-size winery in 1992, it has invested $15 million in crushing machines, presses, cooling equipment and oak barrels and has torn up old vines that were good only for making cheap table wines. 
But rather than planting European or American vines, its new vines are all Argentine, and rather than rely solely on new stainless steel vats, it is still using the old concrete vats to retain traditional Argentine full-bodied tastes and aromas. Its management remains Argentine. From an initial production of 300,000 liters in 1992, production rose to 800,000 in 1995 and to an estimated 2.4 million liters this year.
"I'm looking for middle ground between the traditional and the modern," said Pedro Yanez, head of the vineyard, "while keeping a keen eye on expanding exports to the limit."
The mixing of the new and the old was amply on display at this year's Vendimia harvest festival, an extravaganza of carnival parades, strutting beauty queens and Andean folk dancing. Many wineries invited wine critics and vendors from around the world to take in the local color and taste the newest vintages. 
Sixty guests from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Sweden, Peru, Brazil and Paraguay came to the Trapiche vineyard -- newly retooled with an infusion of foreign investment -- for a tango show, an elegant lunch of tenderloin steak and puffed pastries and, of course, a wine tasting under the shade of a vine arbor. 
It was a rollicking tasting, with Trapiche's ebullient winemaker, Angel Mendoza, making graphic comparisons of the aroma of his chardonnay to the smells that once wafted from his grandmother's oven as she baked apple pie. As he closed his eyes, he asked his guests to sip his sauvignon blanc and imagine it as the fragrance of a freshly cut lawn on a spring day. 
Turning serious, he added, "On this side of the Andes we have certain advantages: healthy vines and a strong sun to harvest early." He did not have to mention the country on the other side of the Andes by name to finish his point.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 15, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about Argentina's growing wine industry misstated the amount invested there by Kendall-Jackson Wine Estates Ltd. It is $15 million, not $5 million.

HEADLINE: Talks on Merger of Utilities Break Down 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Merger talks broke down late yesterday between the Public Service Enterprise Group, which operates New Jersey's largest energy concern, and Cinergy, a Midwest energy utility, executives close to the negotiations said.
 While the talks could still be revived, the executives said that was unlikely. Both companies had spent the day trying to work out the final details in hopes of announcing a deal Monday morning, the executives said. 
 The largest stumbling block may have been that the offer included virtually no premium over Cinergy's current market value, which based on yesterday's closing price was almost $5.5 billion. Executives close to Cinergy said it had been intent on completing the deal, even without a big premium, because the agreement would have given Cinergy the size and scale it needed to compete effectively in a market increasingly dominated by several major players. But, they said, price became a larger issue yesterday as the market reacted negatively to word of the deal.
But one industry expert said that the deal might have fallen through because of the role of James E. Rogers, the Cinergy chairman, would play at the new company. "There have been a number of past deals that have crashed because of Rogers's insistence on guarantees of succession," he said. "They have been to the altar a number of times since 1998 and people have walked away." 
Cinergy, which is based in Cincinnati and was formed by the merger of the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company and PSI Energy Inc. in 1994, has been trying to sell itself for nearly four years. Mr. Rogers, has held talks with PowerGen P.L.C. and Scottish Power, among others.
An executive close to the talks said senior executives at Public Service Enterprise, parent of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and PSEG Energy Holdings, had been rushing to complete the deal before a rival bidder could emerge willing to pay more.
Cinergy and PSEG declined to comment.
The deal would have been the latest among a half-dozen over the last eight months that point to the consolidation of the electricity business on the East Coast. Utilities have sensed that they need to be larger to compete more effectively in newly deregulated markets, and in the Eastern United States, the markets have been much more fragmented, often with electricity companies serving a relatively small region.
PSEG and Cinergy work in newly deregulated markets of New Jersey and Ohio. And both have transferred their power plants to business units that are not regulated by the state and therefore have greater profit-making opportunities. The companies are also building power plants to serve attractive markets farther afield.
Size matters in the power generation market. The two companies merged would have had about 26,000 megawatts of generation, a size analysts said would have brought savings from economies of scale. The companies would have had a mix of fuels that their power plants would be using to prevent them from being too reliant on one.
Shares of PSEG fell 84 cents, to $41.61, yesterday after The Wall Street Journal reported that it was in merger talks with Cinergy. Shares of Cinergy fell 67 cents, to $34.48.

HEADLINE: BUSH ISSUES ORDER PREVENTING STRIKE BY AIRLINE UNION 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
President Bush issued an executive order yesterday preventing a potential strike next week by mechanics at Northwest Airlines and said he would take "the necessary steps" to block walkouts at any major carrier this year.
 "It's important for our economy; but more important, it's important for the hard-working people of America to make sure air service is not disrupted," Mr. Bush said in announcing the action during a speech on his tax-cut proposal in Sioux Falls, S.D., a state that would be crippled by an interruption of service at Northwest. 
 The country's four biggest airlines face possible strikes in the coming months. By intervening in the Northwest dispute, which he pledged to do last month, Mr. Bush becomes only the second president since 1966 to order workers at a major airline to stay on the job. President Bill Clinton ordered pilots at American Airlines back to work in 1997, minutes after their strike began. But no president in recent memory has issued a blanket statement that he would try to prevent strikes at all airlines. 
Mr. Bush's words offered relief to millions of travelers who have been inconvenienced by worker slowdowns at airlines in recent months and are concerned about disruptions in their travel plans. But he also ran the risk of further alienating organized labor, which is upset at several recent executive orders. 
"This announcement looks very antilabor," Charles B. Craver, a professor of labor law at George Washington University, said. "Whether it was meant to be, I don't know. But it certainly gives the impression that the White House is coming out in favor of management rather than being neutral."
In the case of Northwest, Mr. Bush used his power under the Railway Labor Act, which governs labor relations in the rail and airline industries, to appoint a presidential emergency board if the union and the airline do not reach a settlement by the strike deadline of Sunday midnight. Under the law, Northwest's mechanics, who are seeking a wage increase, must stay on the job for 60 days while the three-member emergency board prepares a report and makes a settlement recommendation.
If either side rejects the board's recommendation after the 60 days, the union can strike or the company can lock out its workers. But Congress also has the power to impose a settlement, something it has frequently done in the rail industry.
Mr. Bush's pledge to avert an airline strike comes as United Airlines, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines are nearing an end to contract negotiations, some of which have lasted for years. Some labor leaders complained that Mr. Bush had signaled a willingness to appoint emergency boards in each case, thereby undercutting the bargaining power of unions representing thousands of workers, including pilots, flight attendants, ramp workers, customer service agents and mechanics.
Sonny Hall, president of the transportation trades division of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said Mr. Bush's announcement had "short-circuited the lawful bargaining process through an inappropriate use of intervention powers." 
Other leaders were more cautious. Robert Roach Jr., a general vice president at the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents more than 130,000 workers at United, Trans World Airlines and other carriers, said: "I don't think we want to interpret for the president what he means and lock him into a position. Let's let things play out." 
Scott McClellan, a White House spokesman, declined to say whether Mr. Bush's words meant that he was ready to appoint emergency boards at other airlines. "The president was just making clear that he is very concerned about the negative impact an airline strike can have," he said. Asked if Mr. Bush was siding with airline management, Mr. McClellan said, "He is taking the side of the American people and our economy."
Presidential emergency boards were common in the airline industry until the mid-1960's when a consensus was reached among policy makers in Washington that they were not helpful. In addition, the White House and Congress were reluctant to become involved in labor disputes. 
They are still common in the railroad industry, where unions negotiate jointly and a strike is much more damaging to the country's economy. 
Since the 1960's, the threat of a strike in the airline industry has proved to be a good motivation for both management and labor to reach agreements, said Joshua Javits, a lawyer with Ford & Harrison in Washington and former chairman of the National Mediation Board, which oversees labor relations in the railroad and airline industries. 
"In the rail industry, where you have the expectation of an emergency board, you have less success in reaching collective bargaining agreements," he said. "That history would suggest that emergency board's hurt successful collective bargaining."
Without the ability to strike, labor leaders argue, workers will have no outlet for their emotions and will begin upsetting an airline's operations to vent their frustration. 
But airlines have grown so large in recent years and have become so concentrated at certain airports that some experts believe they are too important to the economy to be allowed to stop flying.
Many workers are already frustrated by the slow-moving bargaining process under the Railway Labor Act, which can drag negotiations out for years. That led to slowdowns at United, Delta and Northwest this summer and fall that disrupted hundreds of flights. 
At Northwest, mechanics have been waiting for a new contract for more than four years. They rejected a tentative agreement in 1998, and then voted for a new union, the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association, to represent them. 
The average mechanic now earns $54,600 a year, excluding overtime. Northwest has offered an 18 percent increase, to an average of $31 an hour, from a current level of $26.25. But the union is asking for $36.84 an hour. After 100 days of mediated talks, the gap between the two sides was still so wide on this and other issues that the National Mediation Board took the unusual step last month of asking the White House to appoint an emergency board. 
Northwest said yesterday that it was prepared to accept any recommendation made by the board. 
United and American declined to comment on Mr. Bush's statement. A Delta spokesman could not be reached for comment. 
Even though Mr. Bush had previously announced his intent to prevent a strike, Northwest and the union began a marathon negotiating session in Washington on Wednesday in an attempt to reach a tentative agreement before the strike deadline at midnight Sunday. 
Paul Volker, a spokesman for the union, which represents nearly 10,000 mechanics and other workers, said the two sides had narrowed the gap on many critical issues. "We are kind of baffled that he would jump in while we were making such good progress at the table," he said, referring to Mr. Bush. "We were by no means through with our negotiating until Sunday."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush said yesterday that he would use his power under a law governing transportation industries to prevent Northwest and other airline workers from striking this year. He spoke at an airport in South Dakota. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home; 
The Golden Eggs

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
"The very rich are different from you and me," Scott Fitzgerald wrote. So we are being reminded these days by President Bush's tax bill.
 The rich are the main beneficiaries of the Bush bill. The richest 1 percent of taxpayers would get 43 percent of the money from its provisions. That comes to $40,000 to $50,000 per family. 
 The big gainers mostly voted for Mr. Bush and are enthusiastic about his tax bill. Nothing surprising about that -- except for one thing. The bill they support could undermine the prosperity that has brought them unexampled wealth.
The greatest economic boom in America's history -- and the world's -- came in the 1990's. What made it possible? Just about all the experts agree on the answer. President Clinton turned away from deficit spending and made it his prime objective to bring the federal budget into balance. That enabled the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low. Result: the boom.
If all the tax cuts proposed by Mr. Bush became law, the government would likely go back into the red -- and interest rates rise. That is the unpleasant reality that he has tried to conceal by what amounts to a verbal game of three-card monte.
Mr. Bush talks about his $1.6 trillion tax cut. As my New York Times colleague Paul Krugman first pointed out, it is really $2 trillion when you count increased interest the government would have to pay on its debt. Other costs not mentioned by President Bush would bring the figure to around $2.5 trillion.
To conceal the real impact of his legislation, Mr. Bush and his budget also used fancifully low estimates of spending. He assumed there would be cuts in appropriations for such things as basic science and crime-fighting, which Congress is unlikely to make. He assumed that Congress would hold the annual growth of discretionary spending to an unrealistic 4 percent. The Economist of London pointed out that he made "no allowance for population growth, and hence his budget implies a drop in real spending per citizen."
Then there is the little matter of Social Security and Medicare. The Bush budget assumes that their reserves can be diverted for other uses instead of being there for the baby boomers as they retire.
Mr. Bush is just as slippery when he describes the effect of his legislation on taxpayers as he is when he discusses its impact on the budget.
His big theme is that the average taxpayer would save $1,600 a year. What percentage of American taxpayers would you guess would actually get less than that -- 50 percent? No, 88 percent of taxpayers would gain less than $1,600 from the Bush bill. 
The Financial Times of London, like The Economist, is a journal devoted to business and to economic realism. The paper's Washington bureau chief, Gerard Baker, wrote this week: "Instead of picking out the striving teacher in the gallery of the House of Representatives last week, it would have been more honest if Mr. Bush had identified the grinning investment banker or multi-billionaire land owner. It is the intellectual dishonesty of this approach that is most distressing."
For some conservative ideologues, the deception in presenting the tax plan is unimportant. What matters to them is starving the federal government of revenue and thus forcing it to reduce its role. They are not satisfied by the fact that federal spending as a share of gross domestic product has shrunk about 20 percent in the last decade.
Most Americans, conservative or liberal, want the federal government to do most of what it does. They would like a tax cut but give that a lower priority, according to surveys, than safeguarding Social Security, reducing the national debt and spending for domestic purposes generally. 
To me the mystery is why non-ideological conservatives, men and women who have made their way in business and the professions, should support the extravagant Bush tax plan rather than a more cautious alternative. Sure, they may save some thousands of dollars a year in the short run. But they have so much at risk in a policy that calculatedly underestimates the cost of the tax cuts and endangers the hard-won federal budget surplus that has opened the way to prosperity.
In the Greek fable, the goose laid a golden egg every day. Its owner, wanting all the treasure at once, killed the goose and looked inside. He found the inside of a goose.

HEADLINE: The Threat of Airline Strikes 

 BODY:
Labor relations in the airline industry are notoriously turbulent, but seldom before has the nation faced the possibility of four major carriers -- Northwest, Delta, United and American -- simultaneously reaching an impasse in contract negotiations with key unions. By the time the summer travel season gets under way, at least one airline could be on strike. Or, equally ominous, disgruntled unions could be forced to stay on the job with new contracts imposed by Congressional action. We trust these scenarios can still be averted with some sensible 11th-hour negotiating.
 President Bush signed an executive order yesterday to prevent a strike by mechanics at Northwest Airlines when a 30-day cooling-off period ordered by the National Mediation Board expires tomorrow at midnight. The 1926 Railway Labor Act allows the president to name an emergency board to prevent an airline or railroad strike that threatens to disrupt interstate commerce and deprive a part of the country of essential transportation. The board then has 60 days to fashion a nonbinding settlement and have the parties consider it. If the board's proposal is rejected, Congress can force a settlement on the parties, or instead allow a strike to take place. 
 Invoking the Railway Labor Act provides presidents a great deal of latitude in an age when airlines rely so heavily on hub operations. Northwest may fly only about 10 percent of passengers nationwide, but it is by far the most important carrier at its hubs in Detroit, Minneapolis and Memphis. Still, President Clinton decided not to prevent a 1998 strike that grounded Northwest, in deference to big labor. By contrast, the previous year he ordered American Airlines pilots back to work minutes into their strike. That dispute was settled during the subsequent mediation period.
President Bush said yesterday that he would "take the necessary steps to prevent airline strikes from happening this year." His desire to avert a disruption in air travel at a fragile economic time is understandable, but having a Republican president say so far in advance that he will act to prevent strikes threatens to dissuade the airlines from negotiating in good faith. They may feel inclined to wait and rely on a pro-business White House and Congress. They already profit from stalemates, since their unions cannot automatically strike when a contract is up for renewal, and new contract terms are rarely retroactive.
Unions also engage in brinkmanship, believing that they can extract better terms when a strike is imminent, or when they are causing the airlines economic pain through legal work actions. Last year, United's pilots wreaked havoc on the airline's schedule by refusing any overtime as a negotiating ploy. They wound up with a 28 percent pay raise.
Many unions offered up significant concessions in the early 1990's, when the industry was unprofitable and Northwest was on the verge of declaring bankruptcy. Now they feel entitled to a share in the profits posted in subsequent years. But airlines are fretting about the current slowdown in business, not to mention high fuel costs.
Money is the main issue separating Northwest and its mechanics. Northwest's last known offer was an immediate 18 percent increase and the highest wages in the industry. The Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association, an aggressive union seeking to win over mechanics at other airlines, wants closer to a 40 percent increase. The issue of retroactive raises may offer some room for compromise, and set a precedent that dissuades future foot-dragging by management at other airlines. The outcome of these talks will surely influence United's talks with its mechanics, though Delta's pilots are next in line to reach their negotiating deadline. 
No one expects either side in this dispute to sacrifice its interests. But labor and management must realize they are approaching a point where neither side can truly win. A negotiated settlement is almost always preferable to one dictated from Washington, and will leave less bitterness.

HEADLINE: Getting Over Our Depression 

BYLINE:  By Jeffrey Rosen; Jeffrey Rosen, an associate professor at George Washington University Law School, is the author of "The Unwanted Gaze: The Destruction of Privacy in America."

 BODY:
 The Constitution
and the New Deal
By G. Edward White.
385 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $45.
 With the exception of the presidential election, the most hotly contested question on the Supreme Court recently has been the constitutional status of the New Deal. Between 1942 and 1995, the court got out of the business of enforcing limits on Congress's power to regulate the economy. But during the past six years, the court has struck down all or part of more than two dozen federal laws, on the grounds that Congress or the president had encroached on states' rights or the separation of powers. The next four years could see a redefinition of the scope of federal power through the resurrection of an aggressive role for judges in policing boundaries of national government that had been dormant since the 1930's. Whether you think this is a principled exercise in constitutional restoration or a brazen display of judicial imperialism will depend on your views of the meaning of the mid-20th-century constitutional revolution that is conventionally associated with the New Deal. 
In an important and unexpectedly timely book, G. Edward White argues that the conventional account of constitutional history, which views the New Deal as the source of a new era in constitutional interpretation, is simplistic and wrong. When after 1932 the Democrats began to experiment with national economic regulation, the Supreme Court responded in 1934 and 1935
by striking down much of the New Deal. After Franklin D. Roosevelt's landslide re-election in 1936, he denounced the court for substituting its own views of laissez-faire economics for those of the people, and proposed in 1937 to expand the court if any of the existing justices remained on the bench after the age of 70. In the conventional account, even though the court-packing plan failed in the Senate, the political pressure it embodied persuaded the conservative justices to abandon their partisan objections to the New Deal. The court switched from a posture of judicial activism to one of judicial restraint, giving the president and Congress broad deference to regulate the economy in an increasingly interdependent world. 
White, who teaches law at the University of Virginia, argues in "The Constitution and the New Deal" that the court-packing plan was, in fact, "a symptom, rather than a cause," of a constitutional revolution that can't be attributed to the New Deal since it was well under way by the 1920's and not fully resolved until the 1940's. And this revolution was driven not by partisan politics but by the onset of what White calls "modernity" -- namely, the view that humans could shape their own destinies rather than be constrained by immutable legal, economic and social rules. Once the old constitutional rules were contested rather than universally accepted, White argues, the "traditional distinction between the will of the judge and the will of the law came to be seen as unintelligible."
Until the end of the progressive era in the early 20th century, the legal consensus was that judges should carefully police the boundaries between state and federal power by serving as guardians of unchanging legal principles. No legislature, for example, could enact "partial" laws that benefited one class of citizens and not the public as a whole: so maximum hour and minimum wage laws were viewed as special treatment for workers. But by the 1930's, the economic reality of the Depression had dislodged the assumption that labor and capital were able to compete on equal terms in the laissez-faire marketplace, and redistributive legislation was seen as a way of helping the public generally by preventing vulnerable workers from becoming wards of the new welfare state. The Supreme Court recognized this transformation in 1934 (three years before F.D.R.'s court-packing plan), when it upheld a Minnesota debtor-relief law allowing courts to extend the deadline for mortgage payments. While debtor-relief laws had been precisely what the framers of the contracts clause of the Constitution meant to forbid when they held that no state shall pass laws "impairing the obligation of contracts," the court concluded that the meaning of the Constitution had changed and that judges were free to recognize the change.
Far from being driven by partisan politics, White emphasizes, the justices who voted to strike down the New Deal, like those who voted to uphold it, were struggling to apply 19th-century legal categories in a world in which their analytical underpinnings had collapsed. By canonizing the judges who voted to uphold the New Deal and demonizing their conservative opponents, the partisan defenders of the New Deal were distorting a complicated, longstanding and legitimate constitutional debate for their own polemical purposes. "We can no longer afford to employ the New Deal as a standard for measuring the effectiveness of current political and constitutional theories," White concludes. "The New Deal needs to be cabined in its own time."
Nevertheless, White's revisionist account of the New Deal revolution helps us understand our current constitutional debates in a new, more complicated light. White's account will give little comfort to conservatives who see the court's response to the crisis of 1937 as a craven abandonment of immutable principles or to liberals who see the New Deal as a permanent feature of our constitutional landscape -- the equivalent of a constitutional amendment. 
Instead, White reminds us, assumptions about the nature of law and judging are inextricably connected to contemporary models of politics, economics and social organization, which changed dramatically over the course of the 20th century and are changing once again. Today, after having abandoned the effort for half a century, the Supreme Court is creating a series of new limitations on Congress's power. These attempts to translate 18th-century constitutional boundaries into the 21st century may or may not be accepted as more principled than political in an age when both parties agree that the New Deal era of big government is over. But if presidential elections can't resolve constitutional revolutions, they can help to influence them. That's why the role of our current conservative justices in choosing the president who could choose their successors was so unnerving. F.D.R.'s attempt to pack the court appears to have been less of a departure from the existing terms of constitutional debate than the court's recent attempt to pack itself.

HEADLINE: Clicking on the Side of Caution 

BYLINE:  By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
While adventure travel is reaching new heights of popularity, most people draw the line at finding their vacation adventure in a war zone. But each year, countless tourists book trips to faraway lands, only to find that when it's time to depart, their vacation spot has become the backdrop to armed conflict, social turmoil or major health risks.
 Although Israel is the most obvious example of the first category, it is hardly alone: in Indonesia, recent ethnic violence has left hundreds of people dead, while last month a clash involving the Burmese army and ethnic groups in Myanmar spilled across the border into Thailand, leaving three citizens of that country dead. 
 Meanwhile, tourists can unwittingly find themselves in dire health circumstances in places like Ukraine, where medical clinics frequently lack the most basic equipment or facilities for blood transfusions. And even in relatively secure countries like China, travelers can find themselves with front seats to an unexpected conflict, such as the government's recent crackdown against the Falun Gong. Such events pose little harm to tourists, but can swiftly quell the chatter within any tour group. 
While the Internet has been a boon to travelers who engage in do-it-yourself booking -- often at the behest of travel companies, which save money as a result -- the self-service nature of the Web leaves consumers vulnerable to getting into situations they might have chosen to avoid if they had known better.
Last month, for example, major adventure travel sites, including Adventureseek .com, Away.com and iExplore, featured tours to Ecuador, including extensive activity in and around Quito, the capital. Nowhere in the itineraries or tour descriptions was it mentioned that only days before the United States State Department had issued a Public Announcement cautioning Americans to put off travel to parts of Ecuador.
The department did not explicitly tell Americans to avoid Quito -- where violent political demonstrations and crime have been on the rise -- but did say that "extreme caution should be taken in tourist areas and crowded marketplaces, especially on the streets of south Quito, the Panecillo, Old Quito, and in transportation terminals. Backpackers are frequently targeted for criminal activity in Quito."
That advisory came from an excellent jumping-off point for travelers wishing to investigate possible trouble spots: the State Department's Bureau of Consular Affairs Web site, www.travel.state.gov. At the top of the right-hand side of the home page is a link for Travel Warnings/Consular Info Sheets. By clicking on it, users arrive at a page that lists three types of information: Consular Information Sheets, Public Announcements and Travel Warnings.
Consular Information Sheets offer basic information about 199 nations, including entry requirements, embassy addresses and phone numbers, and information on traffic safety and medical facilities.
Public Announcements, which carry preset expiration dates, have information about short-term threats to the security of American travelers.
Travel Warnings are more open-ended. In January, for example, in an update of a warning last October, the bureau again cautioned Americans to defer traveling to Israel, the West Bank and Gaza, following the latest Palestinian uprising. Americans should "exercise extreme caution and avoid shopping areas, malls, public buses and bus stops as well as crowded areas and demonstrations," the Web site said.
Christopher Lamora, a spokesman for the bureau, said the government developed such warnings after receiving information from various federal agencies, and, in some cases, with the help of local citizens.
Understandably, tourism officials often view Travel Warnings as overreactions. Noa Artzi, a spokeswoman for Israel's Ministry of Tourism (www.goisrael.com), said in a telephone interview on Feb. 13 that there had been "no special precautions tourists need to take, because everything is normal and safe here." "Tourists aren't traveling in the West Bank and Gaza anyhow, mainly because most of the attractions aren't there."
But the day after Ms. Artzi spoke, a Palestinian drove into a crowd at a bus stop south of Tel Aviv, killing eight people, and last Sunday four people were killed in a terrorist bombing north of the city.
On Feb. 27 the State Department warned Americans to put off travel to the Solomon Islands, particularly Guadalcanal. There, it said, "ethnic unrest during the last two years has devastated the economy and contributed to a general breakdown in law and order. Despite a recent peace agreement, hundreds of automatic weapons remain in the hands of former militants. The Solomon Islands' police force has been unable to restore security in the capital, Honiara."
It is, of course, true that most tourists come and go with no problem, even in regions that have become synonymous with conflict. Thousands of Americans have visited both Israel and Ecuador in the past year, and despite the October kidnapping of five American oil workers in rural Ecuador -- and the subsequent killing of one of them -- the vast majority of tourists traveled without incident.
To help accomplish that, the Web offers an increasing amount of specific advice about situations and areas to avoid. For example, on the Lonely Planet Web site, www.lonelyplanet.com, users can click on the Postcards link, which leads to an online bulletin board where they can get information about crime and practical concerns. For instance, the page devoted to South Africa recently included a posting from a woman living in the country, advising tourists who rent cars to take certain precautions, given the spate of carjackings in the country last year.
Lonely Planet doesn't vouch for the accuracy or usefulness of these missives, but again, they are worth reading for travelers who are weary, or leery, of the florid reviews in guidebooks or on the Web sites of travel operators.
For those looking for up-to-date information, Robert Young Pelton, author of "The World's Most Dangerous Places" (HarperInformation) and host of an hourlong series on the subject on Discovery's Travel Channel, recommends a Yahoo News site devoted to world news (dailynews.yahoo.com/ fc/world/).
Through this link, visitors can search for current and past news reports by country -- and, thankfully, read them in English. Following up on the carjack warning on Lonely Planet, I checked the South Africa section on Yahoo News to see if the incidents have continued this year. There a Feb. 15 article by the South African media company Woza reported that the South Africa police commissioner had found that police and customs officials were involved in major hijacking syndicates in the country.
Search engines are also handy research tools. On Google.com, type in a request for "tourists kidnapped" along with a country name, for instance, and chances are good that you will find what you are -- or aren't -- looking for.
Google is also the new home of the archives of the Usenet discussion groups (groups.google.com), which are essentially bulletin boards for people with common interests. To get to travel-related discussions, go to the rec. group, and click inside the horizontal box next to Go on the upper left side, which will let you jump to the second half of the alphabetical list. There you'll find the rec.travel group, and subgroups related to regions.
That is where Mimi Wong landed recently, while researching an April trip to Indonesia. In an e-mail message, Ms. Wong, who is from Minneapolis, noted that she might have canceled the trip had it not been for the information she gleaned from the Internet. (She said that in addition to the Usenet groups on Google.com, she scoured the Thorn Tree bulletin board on LonelyPlanet.com, which also holds archives of e-mail discussions.)
She wrote that "being able to drill down to a more detailed level and focus on a specific geographic area of Indonesia" and "get first-hand opinions from travelers has helped us make a better decision." Still, she said, "I'm taking a wait-and-see attitude."
Jerry Carlson, an executive with Delta Air Lines, used the Web to similar effect recently while researching a June trip to Bogota, Colombia, with his two children, a daughter aged 21 and a son, 26. Mr. Carlson was looking for more information on avoiding the hazards of Colombia, which is the subject of a State Department Travel Warning. After reading a posting on the Lonely Planet site and listening to colleagues at work, he was "very concerned about kidnapping, robbery, the whole range of things like that."
The Google Usenet site yielded "contradictory" information, he said, so his search will continue on other bulletin boards and news sites. "I'm looking for information on whether and how to hire a private taxi driver who stays with you around the clock, and can keep you out of bad areas and make sure you don't do anything stupid," he said. "I'm sure I'll find something on this on the Internet."
The chances are "99 percent we're going, unless we find something really bad," Mr. Carlson added. He said that after a few days in Bogota, he'll fly back with his son and put his daughter on another plane south. Her next stop: Quito, Ecuador.

HEADLINE: Editors' Choice: Entertaining; 
The Host

BYLINE:  By William Norwich 

 BODY:
Informal polls of society people -- the best kind of poll for society people -- have determined that John Galliher is the favorite host for all seasons in New York. Everyone wants to go back to Johnny's -- his friends call him Johnny -- for lunch or dinner or Saturday-afternoon card parties. (Gin, not bridge.) 
 In boom times, or in times of recession, as well as every permutation in between, the Washington- born social grandee who, before establishing his residence in a two-bedroom flat on the Upper East Side, lived in Paris, then London, has discovered that the way to his rich friends' hearts is through their longing -- the almost touching need the rich have -- for simplicity. In all the cities of the world, "people like the simplicity of an easy entertainment," John Galliher says. 
 It was Louis XIV who apparently started the trend for round tables of six. The Sun King could dismiss his servants and attendants so his friends could dine and talk freely. Emerald Cunard favored the intimate round table for six, as did the Duchess of Windsor. So, too, does John Galliher, except he hasn't any servants to dismiss. Hence, the invention of the Basket.
As nobody ever wants to get up to clear, lest one of the six miss a morsel of conversation, about 30 years ago Galliher got the idea of clearing the dishes into a laundry basket lined with a plastic covered cloth. Later, after the guests leave, the basket is carried to the kitchen. (The current basket was a present from the interior decorator Billy Baldwin.) What about chipped dishes? "I do not have Meissen here," Galliher notes. 
The menu, consolingly, is always the same. Cold tomato souffl 1/8 or lobster salad to start. Then chicken Mica, named for a Romanian friend: large pieces of chicken stewed in a double broth of chicken consomm 1/8, wild rice, small mixed vegetables, and a bit of cream seasoned with rosemary and tarragon. It is cooked ahead of time and kept warm until served. On the table: a jar of Ritz crackers and bottles of wine; guests can pour as they like. Dessert is a homemade concoction of bitter dark chocolate with lots of Tia Maria and Kahlua. Galliher calls this Moca Melting Moments.
There's always music. Galliher makes tapes of favorite ballads and melodies, which play at a soft and pleasing volume. The sweet fragrance in the air? Galliher calls it Charity, a mixture of giveaway scents handed out at the end of charity balls that the dapper one blends in a king-size atomizer.
John Galliher will not risk offense by saying who his favorite guests are today. "But in the former days, very often we had Diana Vreeland, Babe Paley, Slim Keith, Truman Capote and Peter Glenville. Of course Babe had the best chef in town, but she loved coming here even if it was for a spaghetti, because it was relaxed and fun. And these people loved each other and really said the most amazing things because they knew it wouldn't be repeated." He pauses, and remembers: "Except Truman did." -- William Norwich

GRAPHIC: Photos: John Galliher in his Upper East Side apartment, with his great dinner-party innovation: the Basket. (Francois Dischinger); Conversation Pieces: "At a round table, conversation is shared," John Galliher says. "But if there is a shy guest, he or she is just as comfortable as the talkative one." Meanwhile, to jump-start the conversation: 1. A Tiffany silver and-ivory tankard exhibited in the 1900 Paris Exposition (and included in a Sotheby's online auction of the Pabst Brewing Company stein collection, April 12-26; estimate: $200,000 to $300,000). 2. Your new portrait by Maureen Mullarkey (www.studiomatters.com). 3. A sterling-silver Champagne-bottle bubble blower from Links of London, 535 Madison Avenue. 4. Room candles from Greg Jordan, especially his GJ No. 1 aromatic with fig pulp. (212) 570-4470. 5. A copy of the gossip read du jour "Dancing With the Devil," the story of the Duchess of Windsors romantic liaison with Jimmy Donahue, by Christopher Wilson.  The New York Times

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 52

LENGTH: 4858 words

HEADLINE: The Suit 

BYLINE:  By George Packer; George Packer is the author, most recently, of "Blood of the Liberals."

 BODY:
In spring 1997, a wall street lawyer named Harold O. Levy was vacationing with his family on Prince Edward Island, Canada. Recently named to the New York State Board of Regents, Levy had taken along for holiday reading a data-crammed annual publication of the State Education Department known as the 655 Report. As he sat on the beach, what he read made him angrier and angrier. Finally, he jumped to his feet and began walking up and down the sand, shouting to his wife: "You gotta see this! It's unbelievable!"
 The 655 Report revealed all the ways the State of New York has financially shortchanged New York City schools for years by a formula, politically arranged between the governor and the Legislature, so byzantine that the state's education commissioner admitted that even he didn't understand it. Here is one piece of the formula, which has dozens of such pieces: 
 Building Aid Ratio = (1.000 - 1996 FV/1997-98 RWADA x .51 ) 291,500 (state average). 
Plenty of people understand abstractly the inequalities in public education. Hardly anyone reads the report and grasps the details. What Levy discovered from his beach reading, he told me recently, was that "state aid has nothing to do with need and everything to do with spoils and avarice and greed and politics." Rather than basing spending on what school districts need, the state arrives at its aid determinations based on numbers agreed upon in closed-door deals.
Back in New York, where Levy was born, grew up and attended public schools, he immediately invited a fellow lawyer named Robert Hughes to lunch downtown. Hughes was deputy director of the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, which in 1993 brought a lawsuit against the state, arguing that education financing was inadequate. Levy had been skeptical about the case, but now, converted to the cause by data, he told Hughes that the lawsuit needed political backing. In short order, Levy turned the hundreds of pages of the report into a 30-minute presentation, with flip charts and overheads, explaining how the city was routinely underfinanced. He took it on the road to civic groups, businesspeople and eventually to legislators in Albany. Levy had found an outlet for two of his strongest drives: a passion for the public good and a need to be the smartest person in any room. 
In January, in one of the more eloquent decisions on school equality since Brown v. Board of Education, State Supreme Court Justice Leland DeGrasse sided with the Campaign for Fiscal Equity and declared the state-aid formula unconstitutional, ordering the Legislature to find a new way to guarantee a "sound, basic education" to the state's children. 
Harold O. Levy now sits in the chancellor's office on the 10th floor of the Board of Education in downtown Brooklyn. A 48-year-old white Jewish New Yorker from the corporate world, with no experience as an educator or as a politician, whose own two children attend private school, is in charge of the country's largest public school system, 1.1 million children, 84 percent minority and overwhelmingly poor. While the politicians in Albany wrangle over how to answer the court ruling and Governor Pataki appeals the decision, Levy is in a unique position to create alliances that overcome the old divisions between city and upstate. 
Levy has become chancellor in a period when a number of forces are converging in a strange mix of hope and disaster. If ever there was a moment of rough consensus about education, this is it. With a few exceptions, the right, including the Bush administration with its education agenda, acknowledges the need to spend more money on the most disadvantaged schools. The left, again with a few exceptions, acknowledges the need to raise achievement levels, measure results and hold schools accountable for them. In the jargon of the education world, the consensus comes down to standards, accountability and equity. Of course, as Levy himself points out, "The Devil is in the details," and the consensus may turn out to be an inch deep. But the decision in the New York lawsuit elevates one idea to the level of law: higher standards require more spending.
"It historically has been the perception that money spent on the Board of Education goes down a hole," Levy said. "I want to put an end to that." The deal he's offering the public goes like this: I'll bring the snap of the private sector to bear on this bureaucracy, spend money efficiently, produce results. In turn, I need more money to attract better teachers, reduce class size, improve facilities and give poor city kids as much of a chance as their wealthier suburban counterparts.
Levy, who credits his predecessors for their educational initiatives, has introduced a blizzard of reforms: making bilingual education more flexible, connecting all 1,200 principals in the system by e-mail, drastically reducing memoranda and regulations, hiring teachers by alternative routes that circumvent the board's cumbersome process, reorganizing the staff offices and reassigning enough superintendents to send a message to the districts. His controversial decision to give five failed schools the option of being privatized reflects a pragmatic see-what-works approach; it also shows Levy's willingness to go along with part of Mayor Giuliani's agenda in order to get along.
The effect of all these measures on budget and structure has thus far been marginal, and any one person's ability to change what goes on in tens of thousands of classrooms is highly questionable. Levy's real success has been political. He has defused a notoriously vengeful mayor who tried to block his appointment, won the backing of powerful state legislators, kept himself constantly in the press while earning praise from editorial boards and brought some of the city's leading businesspeople into the education debate. 
Several big waves still threaten to crash over New York's schools and sweep away Levy's innovations: the possibility of large numbers of high-school students failing the tough new Regents exams, the possibility of economic downturn and fiscal austerity, the retirement during the next five years of more than half the city's 78,000 teachers, the extreme difficulty of finding talented replacements. But on the level of perception, he has answered the public's expectation of a corporate school boss.
In a managerial age that mistrusts ideological answers of left and right for social problems, Levy seems biographically and temperamentally the man for the moment. He is capable of telling both sides what they don't want to hear. Addressing an educational nonprofit group once, in a few vulgarity-laced minutes he told the members that they had wasted their money. But at another meeting, when a wealthy businessman argued for a free-market approach to education, Levy snapped: "Look, that's nonsense. You really don't understand that schools are different from every other element of our society."
"One thing you can say about Harold," said Jan Atwell of the United Parents Associations, "he's an equal opportunity offender."
Levy avoids hot-button issues like vouchers and instead talks in pragmatic terms about results. But Levy isn't a value-neutral manager. He is, in fact, a liberal -- one who seems to belong to an era before the 1960's, when it was possible to be both public-spirited and Machiavellian. Levy's values are humane; his methods can be harsh. "He's one of these progressive managerial types -- a New Deal technocrat," said Joseph Schwartz, Levy's friend from Bronx High School of Science and Cornell. "I think he really believes in being a good citizen."
In fact, Levy likes to compare his approach with the experimental pragmatism of the New Deal. His tenure as chancellor raises the question of whether urban liberalism can still be a successful governing philosophy. F.D.R., though, had 12 years. With a new mayor and Board of Education coming in next year, Levy's time could be much shorter, and his casual bluntness, refreshing to some, is already alienating sectors whose help he may need.
When Levy's name surfaced in January 2000 for interim chancellor, a lot of people, including his wife, Pat, and some of his close friends, wondered what would prompt a man with two young children and a successful corporate career to seek the job, at a fraction of his former salary, of top bureaucrat in an organization widely considered an administrative sinkhole. A job, the writer Jonathan Kozol told me, that "was invented so someone could die for our sins." A job held by six different men since 1989. Their pictures line the portrait hall outside the chancellor's office like the departed wives of Henry VIII. Why on earth would Levy want to join them?
"Homer, the 'Odyssey,"' he said to me once, with a playful smile and a bit of mischief in his eyes behind wire-rimmed glasses. "Tied to the mast."
Odysseus, refusing the wax that his men put in their ears, wanted to hear the Sirens without being lured overboard by their seductive voices. And Levy wanted to be chancellor out of a commitment to public education, but also for the exhilaration of running something so large and complex. He was casting himself as the hero of his own epic.
"I thought when he came in he was going to be eaten alive," said Carol Kellermann of Learning Leaders, a school-volunteer program. "He's not an educator, not from politics. And instead he has the system eating out of his hand."
But Chiara Coletti, who was press secretary to Levy's predecessor, Rudy Crew, used a different gastronomic analogy to warn about the speed and viciousness with which New York politics can turn on a seemingly popular chancellor. She saw her own boss crumble under pressure when Mayor Giuliani withdrew his favor. In her last months on the job, she kept a postcard of Goya's "Saturn Devouring His Son" by her desk. "We've been very lucky in our chancellors in this city," she said. "But we eat our young."
On a table in Levy's inner office, propped between bookend statuettes of "The Thinker," are these titles: "Can Business Management Save the Cities?"; "Elizabeth I, C.E.O.: Strategic Lessons From the Leader Who Built an Empire"; "How to Read a Poem . . . and Start a Poetry Circle"; the "Oresteia" of Aeschylus; Jesse Jackson Sr. and Jr.'s "It's About the Money!"; and a little red book entitled "Sayings of Generalissimo Giuliani." Next door, in Levy's main office, hangs the portrait of another chancellor, Sir Thomas More, eyes and mouth all focus and resolve -- an intellectual who rose to high position before losing his head on principle. But Levy's attraction to More has nothing to do with martyrdom: "He represents at once great principle and great maneuverability, flexibility, guilefulness, someone who could move in the political world."
Levy dresses deliberately in the uniform of investment banking, down to the white handkerchief in his breast pocket. One Thursday night he told me that he was thinking of going to work the next day in some variation of Friday casual wear; in the morning he was wearing a blue pinstriped suit -- So the press doesn't get distracted," he explained. "I don't want to send the wrong message."
The message is businesslike confidence; he is always in character, and the press seems to love it. Spend a few days or weeks with Levy, as I did in the late fall and winter, and you find yourself trying to keep up with a man who moves from task to task with breathtaking briskness. When I asked him whether it was wise to antagonize the people at that meeting of the nonprofit group, he replied, "I knew precisely what I was doing, and I made the decision in advance because I think that was misspent money." Levy had a way of drawing me into his confidence with an often caustic candor. After exchanging pleasantries with one colleague, he murmured to me, "I don't think much of him -- and he knows it." Levy has a reputation for both brilliance and arrogance, but beneath these lies a muted insecurity the public doesn't see. More given to self-projection than self-scrutiny, twice during our conversations he stopped me to say, "This is very self-indulgent, talking about myself." 
"I don't think he internalizes opposition," said Norm Fruchter, the director of N.Y.U.'s Institute for Education and Social Policy. "Crew internalized everything. Cortines internalized the mayor's antagonism. Levy is impervious. I think he's got a suit of brass armor."
Levy's parents were Jewish refugees from Hitler's Germany, and the tension between their religion and their homeland expresses itself in Levy's character: on the one hand, mastery of detail, respect for institutions; on the other, what he calls (citing Isaiah Berlin) "the inherent subversiveness of the Jewish home."
"Judaism is a part of my identity," Levy said. "My family is German too. And if one takes that seriously, one has to begin thinking about the conflicting notions that that suggests. The Ashkenazic Jew has all kinds of marvelous tensions that are not considered in any rational way. When I went to Oxford, there were many things that I thought about myself as being Jewish and found, no, in fact, it's German."
Joseph Schwartz summed Levy up in this two-word paradox: "establishment outsider."
Levy's maternal grandparents died in the camps. Neither of his parents had a university education. In Germany, his father, Hugo, had been a small-town textile merchant, and in New York he owned a hardware store on East 59th Street. German was spoken in the Levys' lower-middle-class home, on the second floor of a five-story tenement in Washington Heights. Levy grew up an only child; a sister died before he was born. He was not, by his own account, a natural student. When his third-grade teacher told his mother that her son didn't read well, Alice Levy imposed a regime of reading aloud for an hour every night. "She had an egg timer," Levy recalled, his voice rising on a vaguely George Costanza shtick. "And I sat there hating that egg timer for the first three or four months, and by the last three or four months I didn't need it."
He was a student leader at every level of his education, from the monitors squad at P.S. 189 right through the most tumultuous years of the Vietnam War. He was elected student body president at Bronx Science on a civil liberties platform, against a policy of searching lockers. When the Kent State killings prompted a student march through the Bronx in May 1970, Levy argued against shutting down the school and for using class time to do electoral work and letter-writing. When Schwartz and other students occupied Cornell's engineering building in 1972, Levy shuttled between the sit-in and the administration to help negotiate a peaceful end.
It is interesting to note what Levy might have become in those crucial years and didn't: a radical, a neoconservative or a careerist disenchanted with politics altogether. Instead, he became what he remains today: a liberal who believes in institutional reform but not revolution -- a rare species among teenagers in the late 60's. 
Coming from an immigrant family with all the underlying anxiety of a striver, Levy seems to have felt one down through much of his schooling. (Even now there are traces of the precocious teenager who cites a couple of quotes that show he did the reading, but not very deeply.) He first went to Cornell one summer during high school for an Advanced Placement program; he wept when it was time to go back to Washington Heights, and even in recalling the experience in a speech to Cornell alums, Levy's voice broke. "I never thought I would see a place as beautiful as that," he told me. "What it said to me was: Here's a line where I will not be able to overstep. Here's a door I cannot open. I'm allowed to sit at the table for the appetizer only."
When he was accepted to Cornell's School of Industrial and Labor Relations, Levy thought, Now I'll be found out. Instead, he came into his intellectual own. As a freshman he sought out Milton Konvitz, whose "Bill of Rights Reader" had inspired Levy in high school and who introduced Levy to the great ideas of the Western secular and religious tradition, including More's "Utopia." "He gave Harold an intellectual language and integrity," Konvitz's wife, Mary, said. "Harold had no model." When Levy received a scholarship to Oxford over a more polished candidate, an administrator told him, "You need it more."
He received a law degree from Cornell, intending to become a civil rights lawyer. But over time he came to feel that, in that arena, "the great issues had already been resolved," and he decided to learn litigation. He went to Wall Street -- first working at Skadden, Arps, Slater, Meagher & Flom, later at Salomon Brothers, which became a part of Citigroup. He rose steadily through the ranks, ending up as Citigroup's director of global compliance, charged with keeping the company's overseas offices in line with laws and regulations and overseeing a staff of about 1,500. "It always struck me as anomalous that he was in compliance," said Levy's friend Lewis Bernard, a retired Morgan Stanley executive. "He has a great free-ranging intellect, and he's a blithe spirit. Compliance is a nightmare, a set of regulatory prescriptions that you must meet. It's not an area where you can embroider much on the margin. You're trying to restrain the appetite of capitalism."
At the same time, Levy was traveling on a parallel path of nonprofit work that went far beyond the typical lawyer's pro bono services and introduced him to some key political and business figures. In 1995, Chancellor Ramon Cortines asked Levy to head a commission on the physical state of school buildings. Close friends told him that it was a lose-lose proposition, but the report made headlines with accounts of coal-burning furnaces and falling chunks of concrete. Going back to the scene of his own primary education, P.S. 189 in Washington Heights, and finding windowed walls collapsing into classrooms had the effect of a moral revelation on Levy. "For our city's schoolchildren," he wrote, "the lesson these buildings and this school system teach them about their future in the world is clear . . . they have no future, that we do not care about them, that they should fend for themselves and find the shortest way out."
His work on the commission and on the board of University Settlement House on Manhattan's Lower East Side introduced him to Sheldon Silver, the Democratic speaker of the State Assembly. It turned out that Silver's father, a hardware wholesaler on Ludlow Street, had done business with Levy's father. "I'd been cleared to the second generation," Levy said. In early 1997, Silver secured Levy's appointment to the state Board of Regents.
At Christmas 1999, the chancellorship became vacant when Giuliani forced out his former cigar-smoking buddy Rudy Crew. Levy, eager for a new challenge in the public eye, let the president of the Board of Education know that he was interested. On a Saturday morning in January, Silver opened the paper and read that Giuliani was opposed to Levy's candidacy because he was "friendly with Sheldon Silver." This was enough to prompt Silver to make a few calls on Levy's behalf. Over the mayor's strenuous opposition, the Board of Education voted 4 to 3 to make Levy interim chancellor.
On his first day in the 10th-floor office at 110 Livingston Street, Levy was hanging up several suits on hangers collected during his previous incarnation in the corporate world. He noticed the first-class insignia: Mandarin Hotel, Hong Kong; Burgenstock Hotel, Lucerne; Stafford Hotel, London. He went to the window, gazed through the curtain of construction netting down at the traffic chaos of Brooklyn and asked himself, What the hell am I doing here?
For Levy's first couple of months on the job, Giuliani refused to speak to him. But by steering clear of issues that would bring down the mayor's ire and staying neutral on Giuliani's drive to put the Board of Education under mayoral control, Levy managed, with his businesslike approach, to get along. In June, he was unanimously voted permanent chancellor. There is now a "grudging respect" between these two lawyers, Levy told me. "I did what I said I'd do, and he did the same." He smiled. "I'm not saying he wouldn't push me down a flight of stairs if he had a chance."
Levy's early years had seemed a preparation for public service, and when he stayed on Wall Street some old friends were surprised. But Robert Hughes, who helped bring the lawsuit against New York State, pointed out that if education is this generation's civil rights issue, "Harold didn't escape being a civil rights lawyer after all." 
A sleety January morning, predawn dark, the Hudson flowing past the train under trapezoidal slabs of ice: Levy, dressed in uniform, and four aides are putting the finishing touches on testimony he will give to a joint finance committee of the state Legislature in Albany. "I can't say this," he announces, and reads aloud from a tortured paragraph on need-wealth-ratio deciles. "Put this way, it's gibberish. Is the city putting out its fair share? I don't know. What I do know is, I need more. Over to you guys." He rewrites the conclusion, making it tougher. "The message I want to give is, The whole world is watching," he tells me. "I want to say that the judge's decision has changed the moral landscape."
In his State of the State address a few weeks before, Governor Pataki said, "Let's leave the old convoluted school-aid formula on the ash heap of history," and Levy wants to work this into his testimony. "As the governor quoted Karl Marx . . . ," he improvises. "I'm not sure I can restrain myself from that display of intellectual knowledge." One-upmanship is a readily available mode of relating with Levy, and I offer that it was Trotsky, but he won't have it: "It's from the 'Manifesto'!"
At the Board of Education's Albany office, Levy pulls from his briefcase "Plunkitt of Tammany Hall," a gift on behalf of his political education from the real-estate developer Jack Rudin, recording the practical philosophy of the Gilded Age's king of "honest graft." Levy has taken the book along for moral support, and he starts reading aloud with zest from Chapter 2, titled "New York City Is Pie for the Hayseeds": "Did you ever go up to Albany from this city with a delegation that wanted anything from the Legislature? No? Well, don't. The hayseeds who run all the committees will look at you as if you were a child that didn't know what it wanted, and will tell you in so many words to go home and be good and the Legislature will give you whatever it thinks is good for you."
Fortified by Plunkitt and the DeGrasse decision and characteristically high-spirited, Levy heads over to the Hamilton Hearing Room with his team. The room is unusually crowded with legislators and the press. "In the past, the question was, Is the city getting enough?" Levy begins. "And now that debate is over, in my judgment, for all time." He seconds Pataki's remark about getting rid of the old formula, and then, sure enough, he can't resist adding, "Thereby paraphrasing Karl Marx, which I thought was a very sweet moment." Levy skips most of his prepared text and ad libs, warming to his subject, passionate and witty and blunt. After a few minutes, his remarks have had the mental effect of breaking open a few windows in the stuffy room. 
But then something goes wrong. Suddenly Levy is saying: "It does not mean that no oxen will be gored. There will be some who will have to give up money. And I would say to you that that is on the basis of years of accumulated need gone unaddressed. I know that's not a popular thing to say, but it is the truth."
But it's not a truth Levy came before the Legislature to offer. It cuts against the entire rationale of the lawsuit, which argued for leveling the poorer districts up. And by suggesting a zero-sum solution, it undermines the politically delicate task of assembling a coalition of New York City, suburban and upstate legislators to work out a response to the judge's decision. Afterward, under questioning from the press, Levy reiterates the point and then begins to hedge. A few reporters follow him upstairs to Silver's office, where Levy stands by quietly and, it seems to me, slightly chagrined, as Silver, the political pro, explains that the chancellor meant only that he needed more money.
As Levy leaves Albany, what awaits him back downstate are headlines screaming about robbing the rich to give to the poor, suburban legislators circling their wagons, backers of the lawsuit gnashing their teeth that in two minutes Levy had undone all his hard work. "I don't know whether it's self-destructive or some manic confidence," says Norm Fruchter of N.Y.U. "It may be contempt for the official line of things -- he's tired of piety, people are going to have to face this." But on the evening train back to the city, Levy seems just as assured as ever. If he knows he made a mistake in Albany, he's not looking back. "I make decisions and move on," he once said. "I don't second-guess myself. I don't lie awake at night. I sleep at night."
"What I see when I look at you tonight are destroyers of children's dreams," says the black woman in the white robe standing in the Board of Education's meeting room. "You lie, and you lie with a smile on your face as if it's a good thing. I don't think I should even call you human. You're subhuman."
Harold O. Levy -- tied to the mast with board members up on the dais -- listens implacably as New Yorkers take turns denouncing the schools and those who oversee them. At these public meetings, anger catches and spreads like prairie fire, and though the target is failing schools, the unspoken subject of race is "barely submerged," according to a senior member of Levy's staff. But it is Levy's class, not his race, that the parents I talked with said they feel puts him at a distance -- a feeling that Levy has not lessened by keeping his children in one of the city's most exclusive private schools, Dalton, and by demanding a $10,000 monthly housing allowance in lieu of moving out of his Upper West Side residence into the Brooklyn Heights brownstone reserved for chancellors.
Levy is pre-multicultural: in the way he addresses everyone in the same tone, you sense his faith that under our skin we are all basically alike. One evening last month at the Board of Education, he sat down with a group of black elected officials and community activists who were upset at the board's contract with the Edison Project to privatize five failed public schools. Levy heard them out, didn't lose his cool and without giving in managed to establish a degree of good will. "This is family," he told the group. "At the end of the day, we all have to go out and fight the fight of public education."
But Levy's tone doesn't play equally well with all audiences, and if he has a public relations problem, it's less the color of his skin than what one critic calls the "breezy corporate geniality" of his manner, which strikes some as overbearing smugness. His harshest critics are the longtime representatives of parent, community and education groups, who claim that they are ignored, if not despised, while Levy cultivates relationships with the powerful. Robin Brown, the chairwoman of his own Parent Advisory Council, says, "We never know until we read the newspapers what's going on."
"His body language is great for the upper classes and really terrible for working-class and poor people," says Noreen Connell of the Educational Priorities Panel, whose smoky voice and command of fact suggest a woman who has seen chancellors come and go. "I think they're used to chancellors who speak on a symbolic level as well. And Chancellor Levy probably sees it as empty rhetoric. And parents rely on symbolism just to keep hope alive. Because it's really pretty depressing being a poor parent."
Levy was brought to the job for his managerial skill, yet he was never really a manager in the corporate world. He is, however, a very quick study and master of detail who focuses on solving the problem at hand. When a city employee came to him for career advice, saying she wanted to improve public education, he waved away her long-term idealism: "Work to get the State Senate under Democratic control. Do something you can achieve in a couple of years."
Above all, he wants numbers. His hunger for data is so voracious that I once told him he could end up as the Robert McNamara of the urban education war. At 4 one afternoon, Levy calls Andrew Rein into his office: "I want a quick and dirty analysis of data on attendance and performance. I don't want a dissertation." Rein, a senior policy adviser Levy recruited from the Independent Budget Office (one of nearly a dozen new talented, six-figure hires), stays up until 11 running numbers that group the city's schools into quintiles to show a tight relation between high rates of absenteeism and low test scores. The next morning at 10:40, Levy is given three pages of color-coded bar graphs that superintendents can use to lean on schools with poor attendance rates.
