HEADLINE: Open Windows On Distant Worlds; 
In Iran, Expressions Of a Country's Soul

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO; Elaine Sciolino is a senior writer of The New York Times and the author of "Persian Mirrors: The Elusive Face of Iran."

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Iran 

 BODY:
LIGHTS! Camera! Let's go!" Marzieh Boroomand barks at her crew between drags on a Marlboro. Then she focuses on her star, a boy of 11. "Don't sit. Just stand. Don't shake your head so much. Cut, cut, cut!"
 At a rundown teahouse rented out on a stiflingly hot afternoon last fall, Ms. Boroomand is shooting a scene for her latest film, "Sweet Jam," a low-budget comedy about jars of jam that won't open and the campaign of a young boy to seek justice from the factory that made them. 
 Hers is an uphill struggle. She works with only one camera, two klieg lights, big debts and a cast and crew of two dozen. Curious residents of the neighborhood, a quiet middle-class corner of north Tehran, wander on and off the set, and the black flies that call the sticky plastic tablecloths home buzz in front of the camera lens, distracting the cameraman, who bumps into cases of empty Iranian cola bottles stacked along a wall. 
"I work with old equipment, the wrong kind of film and censorship," Ms. Boroomand says as she sips scalding hot tea during a break. "I can't show a married couple in the privacy of their bedroom, so I stay away from love stories. Instead, I try to entertain."
Iran's cinema is a world unto itself, the most creative expression of the country's imagination, so much so that it has earned a reputation as one of the most vibrant and prolific cinemas in the world. As filmmakers scoop up more and more prizes at international festivals, filmmaking has become one of the most popular professions for young people in Iran. They are buying cameras, writing scripts and competing for both the few places at film schools and the privilege of working on the sets of famous directors.
Several film magazines and newspapers are published in Iran, including a slick English-language quarterly, Film International, full of interviews, reviews, news and four-color advertisements. When Bahman Ghobadi, the Iranian Kurdish filmmaker, visited the United States last fall to promote his first feature, "A Time for Drunken Horses," he acknowledged that his primary goal of the film was to win international acclaim.
For many Americans, the Iranian cinema is the most direct glimpse into this complicated culture. More than any other medium, film has helped to break down the dominant Western images of Iran as a country of dour, repressed women swathed in black and bearded young men chanting "Death to America!" -- as a nation powerless to challenge a ruling class of men in turbans and cloaks. The popularity of Iranian films is evident in the number being shown in New York in the next month or two alone. Among them are Jafar Panahi's "The Circle," which is banned in Iran; "The Day I Became a Woman," directed by Marziyeh Meshkini; and a retrospective series, Iran Through the Eyes of Children, beginning March 23 at the Screening Room in Manhattan.
"Films have been transformative in terms of changing the views most Americans have of Iran, especially of the negative image from news reporting of the revolution and the hostage crisis," said Hamid Naficy, associate professor of film and media at Rice University and author of several books on Iranian film and television. "These films are very important in terms of countering the image of Iranians as intolerant and fanatical, and of capturing universal themes -- that it is human to love your children, that people in Iran face some of the same problems that other people face."
The cinema is one of several cultural and political battlefields inside Iran. Along with the press, television, the courts, the universities, Parliament and even the clerical seminaries, the cinema is a place where an ideological guerrilla warfare is being waged between those who want to reform the episodically repressive Islamic system and those who want to adhere to the strict Islamic interpretation that has prevailed for a generation.
Yet the films are not fully representative of life in Iran. And some of the films that are most popular outside Iran, including nostalgic renderings of an idealized past or sentimental films about children, do much less well at home. "Stereotypical impressions are created, that Iran is a harsh place where people struggle for the smallest things in life, where children are prematurely turned into adults," Mr. Naficy said. "Then there is the use of landscape, in a way that gives a highly romantic impression of Iran as primarily rural and traditional, when the largest populations live in urban centers."
Majid Majidi's "Children of Heaven," for example, is set amid flower-filled fields that exist in only a small part of Iran and for only a few weeks. And despite the tundralike setting in "A Time for Drunken Horses," it snows hard in Iranian Kurdistan only a few weeks of the year.
The Iranian cinema has come a long way from the revolution 22 years ago. Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the father of the revolution, railed against the cinema, putting it in the same category as theater, dancing and sexually integrated swimming. The day after he returned from exile in 1979, he said, "The cinema is a modern invention that ought to be used for the sake of educating the people, but as you know, it was used instead to corrupt our youth."
But his lieutenants quickly realized the importance of film for propaganda, if not for entertainment. In 1982, Iran formally banned films that were judged to encourage wickedness, corruption and prostitution.
That policy began to change in the late 1980's, when, as part of a scheme to liberalize the arts, Mohammad Khatami -- then the Minister of Islamic Guidance and Culture, now president -- declared that "cinema is not the mosque." More conservative clerics resisted, and in 1992 Mr. Khatami resigned, writing that he would rather "fight ignorance and backwardness" on his own.
But his election as president in 1997 -- and his call for tolerance and the rule of law -- signaled an even bolder cultural explosion. In a speech that fall, Mr. Khatami proclaimed, "Our cinema is a vivid and clear reflection of the greatness of our culture, people and Islamic revolution." And although a cultural crackdown a year ago shut down most of Iran's reformist newspapers and put many of its best journalists behind bars, most of Iran's filmmakers have been left alone, in part because they have helped burnish the image of Iran around the world.
Today, Iranian films fall into a number of categories. One is the commercially popular junk film -- the slapstick comedy or adventure film about murders or mummies. Another is the propaganda film, the kind that is shown on government-owned Iran Air's foreign flights and that invariably depicts a character gone wrong who is redeemed through prayer and the power of the Islamic Republic.
A third type is the film about innocent children, often in a rural or village setting, with a combination of sentimentality, exotica and unreality that is easy to get past government censors. Jafar Panahi's "White Balloon" (1995), about a little girl trying to buy a goldfish for a New Year's celebration, was a breakthrough film, winning an award at the Cannes International Film Festival and earning nearly $1 million in its United States release.
Still another kind is the emotionally direct film that explores the tensions, restrictions and grimness of everyday life. This type deals with the gritty: suicide, murder, war, mental illness, divorce, infertility, polygamy, tribal oppression, unemployment, adultery, cross-dressing, social inequality, mixed-sex parties, drug addiction, wife-beating, child abuse and, recently, prostitution. Abbas Kiarostami's "Taste of Cherry" (1997) deals with suicide; Dariush Mehrjui's "Leila" (1997) with infertility and polygamy (although I have yet to find an Iranian woman who found this tale of a modern, educated, infertile woman insisting that her husband take a second wife plausible).
"In some ways these films are mirrors as well as sounding boards," said Farideh Farhi, an Iranian-born political scientist who is writing a book about civil society in Iran. "The act of making them represents the will to speak the truth about contradictions besieging Iranian society and reveal in an entertaining way what everyone already knows in their hearts. The audience goes to these films to bear witness, and to gain affirmation for their daily experiences."
Each time filmmakers explore the underside of Iranian life, they risk censorship by the Ministry of Islamic Guidance and Culture -- or worse. Last November, Rakhshan Bani-Etemad and her crew were forced to flee the city of Rasht after they were physically threatened by thugs who objected to her latest film, "Under the Skin of the City," which deals with drug-trafficking and wife-beating among other issues.
But unlike more authoritarian states, this is a world where there are few rules governing what is and is not permitted and where filmmakers defy both the system and their own fears in their quest to create. Still, the necessity to adhere to "Islamic values" means that on one level, there remains an unreality about the portrayal of everyday life in Iranian films.
To comply with the strictures of the Islamic Republic, there can be, on screen, no public affection between men and women, no dancing, no female singers, no sensual music. Female characters must always keep their heads covered and hide the shape of their bodies. Husbands and wives are not allowed to touch, and parents cannot show physical affection to their children once a daughter is 9 and a son is 13. It is thought that such actions might inflame the passions of male viewers.
Yet in reality family life in Iran is extremely intimate. Even the most religious women unveil in private in the company of close male relatives and other women. Husbands and wives touch, and parents and children are affectionate with one another. While Iranians are aware of the distortions of "Islamic filmmaking," foreign viewers often are not.
Some directors, like Mr. Kiarostami, solve the problem by casting few women in important roles and having few scenes inside the home. Others have come up with creative ways to deal with the restrictions. In his 1996 film "Gabbeh," Mohsen Makhmalbaf avoided violating a ban on depicting a woman giving birth on the screen by donning a skirt and playing the role himself. Several filmmakers have begun to use actors who are close relatives, to allow them to show men and women touching.
"The cinema has lots of tricks, and we've had 22 years of the Islamic Republic to learn them," said Parviz Sabri, as he took a break last fall on the set of the most recent film he is directing, "Mani and Neda." "In my last film I was able to show a man and wife asleep in their beds, but I couldn't put them in their pajamas. I had to put them in street dress."
Mr. Sabri's assistant director, Shahin Babapour, said he used three questions to test for every scene: "Is there a scene that can be considered an insult to Islam? Is there a scene that is insulting to the country's folk culture? And are the women wearing too much makeup and showing too much hair?"
The compromises can be particularly frustrating for the actors. "I once played an aspiring singer in a film called 'Help Me,' " said Mahaya Petrossian, a 30-year-old film star who earns enough money to live on her own in an apartment (unusual for single women in Iran) and drive a BMW. "The only problem was that all the scenes of me singing had to be cut."
In "Unforgiven," in which Ms. Petrossian played a young woman confronted with her dying father, "there is a scene in which I'm crying and begging him to forgive me and I couldn't touch him," Ms. Petrossian recalled. "I had to use my expressions and my voice instead. It dupes the audience because in real life a father and daughter would touch." In "Nasreddin Shah, the Movie Actor," a film about the 19th-century Iranian king, lavish period costumes solved the dress problem.
On another level, Iranian filmmakers are relentlessly testing the limits of what is permissible in a largely controlled cultural environment. The Ministry of Islamic Guidance and Culture, which provides considerable financing for Iranian films, can be complicitous in the guerrilla war. Sometimes when a film is banned inside Iran, it is screened at a film festival abroad, creating pressure on the censors to reverse themselves. (That happened with "Taste of Cherry" and Ms. Bani-Etemad's "The May Lady.") Sometimes a film is shown at a private screening once or twice to test the waters. Or a banned film might be shelved for a few months, then submitted to a more lenient censor.
"We Iranian filmmakers are like trapeze artists swinging back and forth without a net," said Mr. Mehrjui, a U.C.L.A.-educated filmmaker. "One of the great contradictions of our cinema in Iran is that we have all these films shot in bizarre places with exotic people that are usually done to hit the foreign market, and they don't do at all well here because they're absurd fantasies. But the government loves them because they are filled with innocent children, free of sin, that challenge nothing in society."
Inside the country, the fluidity of Iran's censorship system was evident one summer evening in 1998 at Tehran's House of Cinema, a private film club, where an invitation-only screening of a movie about the aftermath of the Iran-Iraq war was being held. This was no glittery Hollywood party. No refreshments were served. The auditorium was hot and cramped, the film shown on a small screen from a noisy projector.
"Siavash," the low-budget film being shown, was the first feature film by Saman Moghadam. The Ministry of Islamic Guidance had not approved his film, but it allowed it to be shown just once. The film dealt with the generation gap between the loyal warriors who sacrificed for the revolution and the war with Iraq, and their children who longed for happy lives unburdened by their country's recent history. The film broke a number of barriers: the hero, a young composer and musician in a rock band, played the sort of lively music that would not be allowed in a real-life concert in Iran. And even though the behavior would be technically forbidden, he openly socialized with his girlfriend, a photojournalist who led an independent life. 
"I tried to show the huge divide between the fervent believers and the tired, young generation of today that wants a normal, peaceful life," Mr. Moghadam explained after the screening.
THE censors eventually approved the release of "Siavash," and it played in Tehran's movie houses. It was panned. One review called it "naive, trite and, worst of all, boring."
The tyranny of tradition in a patriarchal society is also a theme that resonates deeply with Iranian audiences, particularly women. "Two Women," directed by Tahmineh Milani, became the biggest box office hit in Iranian history when it was released in the summer of 1999, and it was shown as part of last year's New Directors/New Films Series in New York.
The film tells the story of two college friends, Fereshteh, a poor woman trapped in a loveless marriage, and Roya, a successful career woman with a loving husband. After Fereshteh is forced into marriage by her parents, her husband turns cruel, reneging on his promise to allow her to continue her studies, forbidding her to read books, locking the telephone and accusing her of having a lover.
When Fereshteh seeks a divorce, the judge asks whether her husband stays out all night, beat hers, has bad companions or gambles.
"He humiliates me," she says.
"These are not good reasons," the judge declares.
Never before had the oppression of women by men in authority -- whether husbands or judges -- been so starkly revealed on the screen in Iran, and the film radicalized usually docile women.
Last September, the most popular film in Iran was "Bride of Fire," by Khosro Sinaee, the story of a young, beautiful medical student who is in love with her professor but engaged by her family to a cousin, a rough, illiterate petty trader in a poor tribal area of south Iran.
When the young woman tries to break off the relationship, her fiance tells her: "You have come here and you must follow all the traditions. It's not you or I who decides your life. It's the law of the village." After the wedding ceremony, the bride douses the bridal bed and herself with kerosene and sets the room on fire. At the same time, as the bridegroom is about to enter the bridal chamber, one of the bride's aunts, who married a man she didn't love, shouts, "Congratulations! Congratulations!" as she stabs and kills the groom.
The film, one of the first portrayals of tribal marriage rituals, sparked protests in Iran's small Arab community, including a mysterious fire in a movie theater in the southwestern provincial capital of Ahwaz.
During the 1980-1988 border war with Iraq, the Islamic Republic funded dozens of films and documentaries. Since then, a few filmmakers have dared to take on the trauma of the war and the inability of the Islamic Republic to heal the wounds. The unresolved tensions are dramatically captured in a deeply moving but troubling film screened during Iran's 1999 Fajr Film Festival.
"The Glass Agency," directed by Ibrahim Hatami-Kia, tells the story of Abbas, a soft-spoken war veteran with shrapnel lodged in his neck. After a doctor tells him his condition is life-threatening, Abbas's war buddy Haji, a taxi driver, springs into action. Haji raises enough money for Abbas to travel to London for special treatment. It isn't that easy. At a travel agency in Tehran, the two men are told there are no tickets. 
Enraged, Haji takes the agency -- and everyone in it -- hostage. He demands a ticket. Instead of sympathy for the two men, there is resentment of the privileges war veterans enjoy in Iranian society. At one point, one hostage remarks that veterans indeed are burdened -- by the scholarships, televisions and refrigerators they get from having served at the front. At another, the exasperated policeman negotiating the hostages' release tells Haji: "For a decade we listened to you. It was enough. Now it is a new decade for stability."
Paradoxically, the Islamic Republic as a topic rarely filters into the films. Clerics are seldom featured, except as peripheral characters. "The cleric is one of the taboo issues we can't touch, unless you make him a hero," said Mr. Mehrjui. "Tolerance of the clerical class is so low. One of my dreams is to shoot a film in Qom," the holy city whose major industry is producing clerics. "I'd love to show the clerical class, the clerical culture -- from the inside," he added. "But it's a risky job and I'm afraid I could put a lot of energy into it, only to have it banned."

Through Iranian Eyes
 Many Iranian films will be shown in the New York area in the coming weeks. Following is a selection:

MARCH 23 THROUGH APRIL 5 -- Iran Through the Eyes of Children: a series of films about children at The Screening Room, 54 Varick St., including Jafar Panahi's "White Balloon" and Majid Majidi's "Children of Heaven."

MARCH 23 -- "Friendly Persuasion," also at The Screening Room. A new documentary about Iranian filmmakers, directed by Jamsheed Akrami.

APRIL 13 -- "The Circle," directed by Jafar Panahi, about the lives of Iranian women. Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, 63rd Street and Broadway.

HEADLINE: At Avis, Employees Weigh Their Options 

BYLINE:  By ELISSA GOOTMAN 

DATELINE: EAST GARDEN CITY 

 BODY:
FOR most of Barbara Martin's working life, going to the office has meant driving a mile or so to the squat camel-colored building at 900 Old Country Road in East Garden City, the world headquarters of Avis, the car-rental giant.
 Ms. Martin, 51, started at the company as a secretary and has spent the last 29 years working her way up the corporate ladder to her current post as a supervisor in the claims division. 
 A week and a half ago, Ms. Martin and her 700 colleagues learned that Avis would be moving its headquarters to Parsippany, N.J., where some of its operations will be consolidated with those of its new owner, the Cendant Corporation, the travel and real estate franchiser whose brands include Ramada, Howard Johnson, Century 21 and Coldwell Banker. 
"It's heartbreaking," Ms. Martin said. "So many of us have been here for so long." She that if she is offered a position in Parsippany, some 50 miles away by road, she doubts she will take it. Her husband, a management consultant, has business ties to Long Island, and she was born and raised on the Island. 
Since Avis, founded in Detroit in 1946, moved its headquarters from Boston to Nassau County in 1962, it has loomed large in the consciousness of corporate Long Island. Newsday has ranked Avis Group Holdings as the fourth-largest company on the Island in terms of revenues, $4.2 billion last year. The company has about 20,000 employees worldwide. 
On March 1, Cendant bought the 82 percent of Avis Group Holdings it did not already own. Cendant has 700 employees who also work at 900 Old Country Road, and they will not be affected by the move to Parsippany. 
For financially troubled Nassau County, the news that Avis was leaving comes as a blow.
"For those of us in county government who are busy trying to turn the corner on the problems here, the last thing we need are businesses that pick up and leave and start to go other places," said Lisanne G. Altmann, a county legislator. "Everybody's peeking out the window waiting for the economic downturn to hit here, too. You keep crossing your fingers that this isn't the beginning of it." 
Others argue that changes to the Island's symbolic landscape, significant though they be, may not necessarily have real economic repercussions.
Pearl M. Kamer, the chief economist at the Long Island Association, said this of Avis: "It's been a pre-eminent company on Long Island for many, many years, just as Grumman was. It tends to be a bit disquieting to lose some of our major companies that have long been associated with Long Island."
But while Avis may mean the world to Barbara Martin, Dr. Kamer said that Long Island would probably be no worse for the loss. "I wouldn't read anything more into it in terms of its basic impact on the economy," she said. 
Vincent M. Polimeni, the chairman of the Polimeni Organization in East Garden City, a developer of shopping centers and office buildings, was even more sanguine about news of the move. "Ten years ago it would have been a disaster," he said. "Now, it's really a non-happening."
Avis employees who want to stay on Long Island should have not trouble finding jobs, he said. "There's plenty of work if they want to work," he said. 
Nonetheless, Mr. Polimeni, whose can see the Avis Building from his office on Old Country Road, has his own sentimental bond to the company: his wife was working there as leasing agent when they started dating, and Mr. Polimeni would court her from the other side of the counter. 
"She was cute -- they had those little uniforms, those little red and white uniforms," he recalled. 
Avis plans to phase out its Long Island headquarters in the next year to year and a half. This month, each employee will be called into a supervisor's office to discuss the possibility of working in Parsippany. 
"We're going to ask everyone to come, understanding that everyone isn't going to be able to come," said Robert Salerno, the president and chief operating officer of the Avis Rent a Car System. Those who do not, he said, will be offered "enhanced severance" packages, which will negotiated individually. These packages can include bonuses, outplacement help, training in new job skills, tips on preparing resumes and assistance in making the transition to retirement.
Because the packages are still being negotiated, most employees would speak only on condition of anonymity, fearing that whatever they said could jeopardize their job or bonus prospects. 
"The company was sold, and the big shots got their millions and millions of dollars," said one nine-year employee. "We're all left doing all the work that allowed the stock to do well, and we don't get any of the rewards."
"They said they're going to offer something so that people just don't jump ship now," said the man, who deemed it "highly unlikely" that he would take a job in Parsippany. His children are in school on Long Island, he said, and he called the commute between Long Island and Parsippany "impossible."
A woman who has worked for Avis for 19 years does not plan to move, either. "I was born and raised and will die here," she said. "I'm not moving to Parsippany." 
"I always wanted to work for a major corporation," she said. "I thought it would be more stable. Little did I know, 19 years later . . . ," she said, her voice trailing off. 
Another Avis worker said that as a single mother, she would consider moving if it meant keeping her job. And besides, she could use a change of scenery. 
"I would like to get out of New York, but I don't know about New Jersey," she said. "I've never really been. I got lost in New Jersey one time while traveling, and the part of Jersey I saw I wasn't too keen on." 
For the Avis employees considering the move, Cendant plans to help bridge the psychological gap between East Garden City and the Garden State. 
"We realize this is going to be a stressful transition for some," said Ted Deutsch, a Cendant spokesman. "They're joining a bigger company with broader career options."

GRAPHIC: Photo: About 700 people at Avis headquarters in East Garden City will be affected by the move to Parsippany, N.J. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
The Rules Of 'Luxury Decontrol'

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
 AROUND this time of year, landlord-tenant lawyers say, rent-regulated tenants in apartments renting for $2,000 or more a month will probably find an envelope from their landlord in their mailboxes. Inside that envelope will be a form that asks the tenant whether the combined annual income of the occupants of the apartment exceeded $175,000 in each of the last two years. 
 How the tenant responds to that question -- indeed, whether the tenant responds to that question -- could mean the difference between paying a regulated rent or being thrust into the world of free-market rentals.
Marcia Hirsch, general counsel for the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the state agency that administers the rent laws, said that under the high-rent, high-income deregulation -- or "luxury decontrol" -- provisions of those laws, rent-regulated tenants whose rent is $2,000 or more a month, and whose total annual household incomes exceed $175,000 a year for two years in a row, can lose their regulated status. Between 1994 and 1998, the only years for which figures are available, Ms. Hirsch said, about 1,959 apartments were deregulated in this manner. 
Ms. Hirsch said that this form of deregulation should not be confused with high-rent vacancy deregulation, which occurs when the maximum legal rent that can be charged for a vacant apartment is $2,000 or more. Since the landlord is not required to register deregulated apartments, Ms. Hirsch said, it is not possible to determine with certainty how many apartments have lost their regulated status in this way.
Ms. Hirsch said that for the division to issue an order of deregulation under the high-rent, high-income rules, the property owner must demonstrate to the agency -- either through admission by the tenant or through evidence ultimately provided by the State Department of Taxation and Finance -- that the income of the apartment's occupants exceed the threshold.
The process begins, she said, when the owner sends the tenant an income certification form sometime between Jan. 1 and May 1. 
The form requires the listing of tenants and co-tenants named on the lease, whether or not they occupy the apartment as their primary residence, as well as all others who use the apartment as their primary residence. 
The form also requires the tenant to indicate whether the annual income of all tenants and occupants combined was more than $175,000 in each of the two preceding years.
"It's a 'yes' or 'no' question," Ms. Hirsch said. "You don't have to say how much your income is or even provide us with Social Security numbers," she said, adding that the term income is defined by law as the amount reported on the tenant's or occupant's New York State income tax return as "federal adjusted gross income." 
Completed income certification forms must be returned to the landlord within 30 days. 
Once the form is returned -- or if the tenant fails to return the form within 30 days -- the ball is in the landlord's court.
Peter Schwartz, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said that if the tenant acknowledges income in excess of $175,000 for the two preceding years, the landlord is entitled to an order of deregulation. 
In cases where the tenant fails to return the form in 30 days, or when the tenant returns the form and the landlord disputes the information on it, the landlord can contest the certification with the Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
For a landlord to get an order of deregulation, or to contest a tenant's income certification, Mr. Schwartz said, the landlord must file by June 30 what is known as a petition by owner for high income rent deregulation.
In cases where the owner contests the tenant's income certification, Mr. Schwartz said, the Division of Housing and Community Renewal sends a notice to the tenant requiring verification within 60 days of the information in the original certification. When that information is received, he said, the division contacts the State Department of Taxation and Finance and asks that agency to check its files to see if the income listed on the tenants' and occupants' New York State tax returns match the incomes listed on the certification. 
If they do, and the total is below $175,000 for each of the two years, the landlord's petition is denied. If they do not, and if the tax information discloses income in excess of $175,000 for the last two years, an order of deregulation is issued.
Mr. Schwartz said, however, that the procedure used to verify the income of tenants with the Department of Taxation and Finance is far from foolproof.
"If the tenant doesn't indicate his name and mailing address on the income certification form in the same way he indicates it on his tax return, or if the tenant hasn't filed current tax returns, the Department of Taxation and Finance may not be able to make a match," he said. "And if there's no match, the D.H.C.R. denies the owner's application."
Ms. Hirsch said that to help avoid that problem, her agency recently started requiring tenants to provide a photocopy of the mailing label on their tax returns, with the Social Security number crossed out. She said the division would consider holding open cases for tenants who have requested additional time to file their tax returns.
Errol Brett, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that the certification procedures have at times caused confusion among tenants. Mr. Brett said that since the verification form sent to the tenant by the Division of Housing and Community Renewal is similar in appearance to the income certification form sent by the landlord, tenants sometimes fail to return the second form because they believe it is merely a duplicate of the first.
That, however, can have severe consequences.
"Failure to respond to the petition from D.H.C.R. is considered a default that can lead to deregulation," Mr. Brett said. 
In fact, he said, since the landlord can appeal decisions made by the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the process can easily stretch out over a year or more, resulting in a second year's batch of certifications and verifications being sent to a tenant even before a final determination has been made on cases from the preceding year.
"And when these things start crossing in the mail, people start to get confused," Mr. Brett said.
Ms. Hirsch said that as a result of recent court cases addressing that problem, the division no longer automatically enters an order of deregulation when a tenant fails to file a form on time. Instead, she said, disputes are decided on a case-by-case basis after the tenant has been given an opportunity to provide reasons for the failure to file.
But William Gribben, a Manhattan lawyer who represents tenants, said that notwithstanding the court cases and the division's new policy, tenants should be extremely diligent about completing and filing every form.
"You might get a break if you didn't file on time because there was a fire in your apartment, but you may not be so fortunate if you failed to file because you just lost track of the paperwork," Mr. Gribben said. "I can tell you I've had people sitting in front of me with tears in their eyes after their apartment was deregulated because they missed a filing deadline."

HEADLINE: COUNTY LINES; 
A Chef's Dream Withers

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
RICHARD DiGIACOMO, a chef, has a phone that won't stop ringing. Sometimes it's Con Edison demanding money; other times it's just a wrong number. "If all the rings were reservations," Mr. DiGiacomo said, "I'd be a millionaire." 
 Mr. DiGiacomo owns his own restaurant, a dream to which he's devoted his life. A former liquor salesman, he took a job as a waiter because this particular restaurant let waiters cook meals at the tables. He saved enough money to send himself to the Culinary Institute of America. Then he worked in other people's kitchens as everything from sous-chef to banquet cook, but there was always his dream. 
 So he patched together $70,000 in financing from friends, family and personal savings. To economize, the 37-year-old even moved back in with his mother, which "isn't great for the dating life," he said. The money allowed Mr. DiGiacomo to take over the lease of a restaurant in Harrison and all its equipment, right down to the spatulas. He was left with $25,000 in working capital, thinking he'd never have to touch it.
He renamed the restaurant Bistro Two Three Five (it's at 235 Harrison Avenue) and threw the doors open. Those first two nights, the restaurant teemed with friends and family. Crowds equaled bliss, because Mr. DiGiacomo was wagering not only all his money, but also his sense of self.
That's why he was tense on night three, when the crowd was light. And had a knot in his stomach by the third week. Then there was the problem with the liquor license. The previous owners had lost theirs, and Mr. DiGiacomo was surprised at what a "foot-dragging process" it was to get a new one.
Though he couldn't sell wine, he didn't want to disappoint people, so he gave it away. "But some people took advantage," Mr. DiGiacomo said. "They'd drink the equivalent of two bottles."
Mr. DiGiacomo's real problem, however, was his lack of business experience. "Not being a good businessman, you just write checks," he said. "There's the insurance bill, the this bill, the that bill." After two months, he went to the bank to get money to pay the dishwasher and saw that he had only $200 left. 
"I thought we were finished," he said. His credit cards, though, kept him going.
"I used to have A credit," he said, "and now it's a Z." In front of customers though, he always had to be cheery: "They can't know I might be on my last leg," he said. 
The food Mr. DiGiacomo offers is good and the portions generous, but with funds so limited, time wasn't a friend and advertising was out of the question. He resorted to a series of promotions, none of which proved a magic bean. Mr. DiGiacomo teamed up with a local liquor store to offer a wine tasting and four-course meal for $35, "but if I made more than 50 cents a person, I'd be surprised." Jazz night drew people, but not enough to pay the musicians. He had successful private parties, but didn't feel right booking too far in advance, not knowing what the future held. 
It is this sort of inherent decency, coupled with a slightly befuddled quality, that seems to make Mr. DiGiacomo a magnet for mothering. A customer brought flower pots to decorate the entry and though they promptly blew down the street, she was not discouraged. When Mr. DiGiacomo wrote up a Valentine's Day menu called "The Main Event," she told him that bachelors should never be allowed to write Valentine's Day promotions and rewrote it herself as the "Aphrodisiac Dinner," with appetizers like "Love and Envy Salad" and an entree called "Fulfillment Filet Mignon." 
An investor even offered to wait tables and, thankfully, Mr. DiGiacomo gets some leeway on the rent because "my landlord and landlady like the food here," he said. In addition to sinking more money into the restaurant, his mother comes in to set flowers on the tables, and takes home the napkins and hand towels to wash and fold. 
Recently, two years after opening, Bistro Two Three Five was full a few times, but the next night just four people would show. Friends know how badly Mr. DiGiacomo feels and offer to meet him for a beer, but he doesn't go.
"I hate to admit why," he said, "but it's a combination of no money and being depressed." At this point, his biggest fantasy is simply "breathing room." He has reluctantly started to read the Help Wanted ads.
But for today, at least, that long-held dream to own a restaurant is one Mr. DiGiacomo is living, as best he can.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY; 
To Boutique Hoteliers, Small Is Beautiful

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
 A VISITOR to New York with literary affinities might find congenial surroundings at the Library Hotel at the corner of 41st Street and Madison Avenue. Drawing its theme from the New York Public Library's main branch, a block away, the entire 60-room hotel is organized with the Dewey Decimal System as its inspiration. 
 Each floor in the hotel is dedicated to one of the major categories of the Dewey system, including technology, religion and history, and the designation of each floor is projected onto the wall facing the elevators. Every room on a floor is labeled with a subcategory, like Slavic languages or Native American religions. The rooms are even numbered according to the system, with a bit of literary license taken, with Slavic languages in 400.001 and Native American religions in 1200.005.
And, yes, there are books on the chosen subject in each room. 
While library science may not be to every traveler's taste, the hotel is an indication of the lengths to which owners are willing to go to distinguish their properties from others in a crowded market. The Library is one of a wave of so-called boutique hotels that have emerged in Manhattan in recent years, with more on the way..
About half a dozen boutique hotels have opened over the last year or so, adding about 1,000 rooms to Manhattan's base of about 70,000 rooms. Among the nonboutique hotels that have opened in the same period are the Embassy Suites in Battery Park City, the Sofitel on West 44th Street and the Hilton Times Square. 
Projects already under way are expected to add another 1,800 rooms this year.
These new rooms are coming to market at a time that the seemingly relentless upward surge in occupancy rates seems to have come to a halt and the rate of increase in nightly room rates has been slowing. 
According to figures compiled by PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm, the occupancy rate in January was 3.3 percentage points below a year earlier and February was down 4.9 percentage points. The average room rate was up just 0.7 percent in February over the same month a year ago, after growing 6.9 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, to an average of $259.39 a night.
Boutique hotels are different from the large hotel companies with well known brands like Marriott and Holiday Inn, which offer standard rooms and services and have a national reservation system to direct travelers from city to city.
The boutiques are largely owned by individuals or groups of investors and operate independently, relying on their style and level of service to attract visitors grown tired of standardized hotels. They tend to be more expensive, as well, with a small room with a double bed at the Library renting for $295 a night and a larger room with a queen-sized bed costing $325 a night.
These rates are before combined city and state taxes that amount to 13.25 percent plus a surcharge of $2 a night, according to the Hotel Association of New York City.
Although both the big companies and the boutique operators rent rooms by the night, they are not really in the same business, said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, a company that specializes in hotels.
"I define a boutique hotel as one with less than 200 rooms with a high degree of design and a high degree of service," he said. "They are intended for more sophisticated travelers who are more willing to take a chance with their travel experience."
COMPANIES like the ones that operate Hilton or Holiday Inn hotels built their reputation on the basis that the rooms and services would be almost the same, no matter where a property was located, much like fast food franchises, Mr. Fox said. But he said, many affluent travelers are looking for alternatives to chains and seeking out independent hotels for the same reason they try to find little-known ethnic restaurants: something new and different.
"A boutique hotel is like a small restaurant where the maitre d' recognizes you," said Henry Kallan, owner of the Library and operator of three other boutique hotels in Manhattan: Elysee, at 60 East 54th Street; Casablanca, at 147 West 43rd Street; and Giraffe, at 365 Park Avenue South. "If you stay at a place like that three or four times, the staff gets to know who you are, and they don't need a computer to do it."
Computers, of course, are a key to the ability of high-end hotel chains to keep track of customers' individual preferences, like a certain newspaper or type of breakfast, so that they can be provided when a customer checks in, even if it is for the first time at a specific location.
"When people come to New York, they have a desire for design; they want something different," said Lawrence Pomeranc, whose Pomeranc Group recently opened 60 Thompson, a 100-room hotel at that address on Thompson Street between Spring and Broome Streets in SoHo. "People want something more than standard, even if it is a high standard."
The development of boutique hotels -- the name irritates many hotel operators, but it has stuck -- is credited to Ian Schrager at properties like the Morgans and Royalton hotels in the 1990's. These properties combined compact, highly styled guest rooms with public spaces and restaurants that attracted people from some of the city's more fashion-conscious industries, like publishing.
Mr. Schrager has since extended the boutique concept to other cities in America and Europe and has also developed properties like the Hudson on the West Side of Manhattan as a lower-cost alternative to Midtown hotels. 
The 60 Thompson is in a part of the city that was not considered a prime market for hotels until Hartz Mountain Industries successfully opened the SoHo Grand Hotel four years ago at 310 West Broadway and followed it with the TriBeCa Grand at 2 Avenue of the Americas early last year.
Emanuel Stern, the president of Hartz Mountain, said the hotel market had softened in terms of its occupancy rate since the beginning of the year in Manhattan. "The SoHo Grand is off 6, 7, 8 points compared to last year," he said, adding that the TriBeCa Grand had not been open long enough to make year-to-year comparisons.
He said that the Manhattan hotels had been budgeted for an increase in room rates this year, but that it might not be possible in the current atmosphere. "I will be satisfied if I can hold the rate this year," he said.
Unlike many other boutique hotel developers who have had to adapt existing office buildings to hotel use, the Pomeranc Group was able to put up a new building at 60 Thompson Street, on what had been the site of an ornamental metal shop. "We bought the site, got some air rights and designed the building," Mr. Pomeranc said.
As a result, the 100 guest rooms at 60 Thompson are larger than some in buildings on more constricted sites. The operators are trying to make that a marketing advantage, by including a couch in each room, in addition to the bed and chair. "It used to drive me crazy when I had to lie on the bed to watch television," Mr. Pomeranc said. "Now I can sit on the couch."
Mr. Pomeranc and his brother Jason, the designated hotelier for the Thompson property, said they tried to make the design distinctive, but understated. Three different colors of marble were used for the bathrooms, which Jason Pomeranc said are one of the signatures of the property. Wood was used on the floor of the lobby, which because of zoning rules is on the second floor of the building.
"It gives a warm feeling, but it is not very practical," Jason Pomeranc said.
Morris Moinian, the developer of the Dylan hotel at 52 East 41st Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, had to work with an existing building, but said the property's history made it easily adaptable to a 108-room boutique operation. The building was erected about 100 years ago to house the Chemists Club, and many of the turn-of-the-last-century touches have been preserved.
"This was a glamorous private club, so we have hand carved plaster, stained glass windows, a grand staircase and a ballroom," he said. Mr. Moinian said he added four stories to the original 10 in the Beaux-Arts building as part of the renovation.
Because of its origins as a private club, Mr. Moinian said, Dylan's rooms are larger than those found in some boutiques. "Every room in the hotel has a foyer," he said. "There are so many hotels in New York where you open the door and it hits the bed. At Dylan there is a vestibule."
And the ballroom would be difficult to duplicate in a renovation of a more conventional building. "The ballroom has a 35-foot ceiling and a 6-foot fireplace," he said. "You just don't see that in an office conversion."
History of a different sort is being preserved at the Bryant Park Hotel, across 40th Street from the park, which is just to the west of the Public Library. The hotel is in the old American Radiator Building, a 26-story landmark whose facade of gold and black and black bricks fired in manganese had to be preserved.
The developer is Philip Pilevsky, an early financial backer of Mr. Schrager in the Morgans and Royalton projects. Now operating the Philips Hotel Group, Mr. Pilevsky said the Bryant Park Hotel would be marketed to "people who want the cutting edge of style and service." They are expected to pay about $500 a night.
The property is expected to attract people in the entertainment industry, for whom a 73-seat screening room was built in the subbasement by digging 45 feet into the bedrock under the building. Also below ground will be the Cellar Bar, one of three bars in the hotel.
The building has been converted to a 130-room hotel, including 20 suites and two penthouses. Making use of the building's location, 11 of the rooms have terraces overlooking Bryant Park. Some of the public spaces and a few guest rooms have already been opened; the hotel is expected to be completely in operation by the end of the month, Mr. Pilevsky said.
IN a particularly challenging conversion, Mr. Kallan had to shoehorn the Library into a vacant office building that is just 25 feet wide and 100 feet long. He said many hotel operators were reluctant to bid on such a structure, but said "finding a building in the right location in Manhattan is not easy to do." 
"You have to have a vision and an understanding of what can be done in limited space," he said.
Space limitation notwithstanding, he said every bathroom in the hotel includes a bathtub in addition to a shower. "Some boutique designers think Americans are so busy they only take showers," the Czech-born Mr. Kallan said. "As far as I'm concerned, if the bathrooms only have showers, it is not a full service hotel."
The location near the Public and Pierpont Morgan libraries suggested the name of the hotel and Mr. Kallan credits Jordan Jacobs, the son of the architect Stephen B. Jacobs, with developing the Dewey Decimal theme."We ended up spending $85,000 on books, which is a little crazy, not to mention all the labor involved," Mr. Kallan said.
Operators of boutique hotels say service is as important as style in persuading travelers to pass up even luxury chain hotels for their operations. "We tried to fix all the things that bothered us when we traveled," Lawrence Pomeranc said. "When someone calls the hotel, they should not have to wait through 20 rings on the phone -- it should be answered by the second ring," he said. "Nobody wants to wait 40 minutes for room service; 20 minutes should be the maximum."
Long lines to check in and out of convention hotels are irritating to many travelers, boutique hotel operators say, as are voice mail systems that require callers to push button after button to reach the right department. "In our hotels, check-in takes two minutes, so no one has to stand in a line cordoned off by a rope waiting to check in," Mr. Kallan said. "And they speak to people, not voice mail."
The appeal of boutique hotels has grown to the point that some giants of the hotel industry are trying to grab a share of the market. In the last two years Starwood Realty Trust, the owner of the Sheraton and Westin brands, has established a line of W hotels in existing, converted and new properties.
The W hotels are not necessarily boutiques, said Guy Hensley, Starwood's senior vice president for W hotels, but they are more highly styled than some other properties. "They are for customers who are more discerning about style," he said. "These are the people who shop at Pottery Barn and Restoration Hardware, and they don't want to stay in a hotel so standardized they don't know what city they are in."
There are 13 W hotels nationally. In New York, two former Doral hotels on Lexington Avenue near 39th Street have been converted to the W Court and W Tuscany, and the W New York is at Lexington and 49th Street. The former Guardian Life Building on Park Avenue South at 17th Street has been converted to the W Union Square. And the new building at 47th Street and Broadway that was originally planned as a Planet Hollywood hotel will open as the W Times Square later this year.
Mr. Hensley said that because the W hotels are part of Starwood, with its national reservations system and frequent traveler incentive programs, they have a better chance of economic success than stand-alone operations. "It's tough to make money with a 100-room independent hotel," he said.
Most boutique hotels include a restaurant, which usually provides room service for the guest rooms as well. The restaurant space and attendant services are usually leased to a restaurant operating company or a noted chef and, in keeping with boutique style, a simple steakhouse will not do.
"Restaurants in flag properties are all the same," said Lawrence Pomeranc, referring to chain hotels, whose brand names are referred to as flags by those in the business. "Regardless of which one it is, you get basically the same experience."
Boutique hotels, he said, "incorporate a restaurant that is more quality oriented and with an ethnic spin." The spin at Thom, the restaurant at 60 Thompson will be Vietnamese-American, developed by Jean-Marc Houmard and Michael Callahan, who were previously responsible for the restaurants Indochine, Republic and Bond Street.
At Dylan, the restaurant is named Virot after its chef and owner, Didier Virot, who was formerly associated with Jean Georges. The Library will have an Italian theme at its first-floor restaurant, Bottega di Vino, which will feature an extensive wine cellar and hundreds of books about wine.
HOTEL operators and analysts are divided about the outlook for the boutique hotels entering the market in recent months. Although bookings have softened since the end of last year, they are coming off record highs and remain strong historically.
Bernard Goldberg, whose Gotham Hospitality Group developed five boutique hotels before selling them in 1998, said some owners are trying to lock in their gains by selling hotels. "There is a lot of product on the market now that was not available before," he said. "It looks like some people are trying to cash in."
He said one attraction of the hotel business is that in good times it is the best use of real estate in terms of income per square foot. But, someone else noted, in the hotel business, you have to re-lease your space every night.
Independent boutique hotels may lack a national reservations system, but they have a fatter profit margin than some chain operations, noted Sean Hennessey, director of the New York hotel practice for PricewaterhouseCoopers.
He said that the city average of revenue per available hotel room, a standard measure of income, was $186 last year. But for boutique hotels the figure was $216, perhaps as a result of higher room rates and lower corporate overhead.
Boutique hotels opening now "will face more challenges than when the W hotels opened into a strong market last year," Mr. Hennessey said. Over all, he said, the boutiques opening now "will not be dramatically worse off" than those that opened earlier, but he said he expected some of the independents "to convert to a national flag over the next year."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Debbie Genn, Jonathan Rulnick

 BODY:
Debbie Shulamit Genn and Jonathan Amichai Lev Rulnick are to be married today in Woodbury, N.Y., by the bridegroom's father, Rabbi Arthur D. Rulnick, at the Woodbury Jewish Center, where he is the spiritual leader. The bride's uncle, Rabbi Daniel Epstein, is also to take part in the ceremony. 
 Mrs. Rulnick, 28, works in New York for United Jewish Communities, an organization formed through the merger of the United Jewish Appeal, the Council of Jewish Federations and the United Israel Appeal. She is the assistant to the director of Partnership 2000, an economic, educational and social development program in Israel. She graduated from Hebrew University in Jerusalem. 
 Her mother, Rena Genn of Karkur, Israel, is an educational administrator at Pardess Hanna Agricultural High School in Pardess Hanna, Israel. The bride's adoptive father, Reuven Genn, teaches Jewish history there. He is also an information analyst at Comverse, a telecommunications company in Tel Aviv. The bride's father, Eli Michael Solomon, was killed while serving in the Israeli Army during the Arab-Israeli war of 1973. 
Mr. Rulnick, 25, is the director of student affairs at the Israeli Consulate in New York and a candidate for a master's degree in Near Eastern studies at New York University. He graduated from Emory. His mother, Dr. Adrienne Rulnick, and father live in Syosset, N.Y. Dr. Rulnick is the director of university alumni relations at N.Y.U.

HEADLINE: CITY LORE; 
The Kingdom of the Map

BYLINE:  By ANDREW FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
YOU would think that Alice Hudson, chief of the map division at the New York Public Library, would have an inflexible view of New York City geography. Maps are color-coded rulebooks, after all. Monitoring them must be like being on solitary border patrol.
 With a single map, that may be true. But when one is charged with looking after more than 400,000 maps, they mock the need for order. History in Ms. Hudson's incredible map room becomes layered, shifting. 
 Sitting in her office in the back of Room 117, a modest wood place with stone ornament and a view of bustling Fifth Avenue, Ms. Hudson may at any time say something like: "This is the old reservoir. We're sitting inside the old reservoir." 
What she means is that, according to her maps, the 42nd Street library was built in 1911 on the site of the old city reservoir. One starts to have a kind of vertigo then, realizing that Canal Street used to be a real canal, that part of Central Park supplanted an established black and Irish community, and that scores of other sites had pasts far different from their presents.
"I can remember driving in Westchester once and saying, 'All of Manhattan used to be like this,' " Ms. Hudson said. "Rooks and rills and brooks and dirt roads and gardens and farms. On the old maps you can see, the city is just a pink triangle. The Bowery was lined with old, beautiful farms."
Ms. Hudson keeps some of her maps in rows of gray cabinets with thin flat shelves, each with its own two silver handles. Other cases are military green and locked. She calls them recycled World War II tanks. They protect rarities like the vellum-bound Dutch maps of the world from the 1660's. There are also maps made of sticks and shells, maps on cloth and maps on silk scarves given to soldiers in the field. There are maps of airports and sewers, of firehouses and bulkheads. Some of the maps are beautiful, some ugly. 
For Ms. Hudson, who has become a poet of place, the history of all these maps is the history of New York.
"Sometimes it's the sameness of the city that strikes me," she said. "There were ethnic neighborhoods early on clustered together in the same places they are now."
Ms. Hudson, who supervises a staff of eight, has lively eyes, an irreverent wit, blond hair and two perfect shocks of gray at her temples. She talks of maps with great gusto. She has a bumper sticker that says, "Without geography, you're nowhere."
Since taking over as chief of the division in 1981, she has worked tirelessly to promote the collection, which was founded in 1898 but only became its own library division during World War II, when it played a significant military role. 
Now, 7,000 people use the room each year. The collection, the largest in any public library in the country with the exception of the Library of Congress, has doubled during her tenure. It now includes 24,000 atlases and books, with maps from across the world, although the focus is strongly New York City.
In recognition of her accomplishments, the Fund for the City of New York will present Ms. Hudson with its annual Sloan Public Service award this week. Seven other city workers will also receive the honor.
Raised in Oak Ridge, Tenn., Ms. Hudson, 53, visited New York the same summer, 1964, the Beatles stormed into the city. A teenager, she worked as a page during that time in the bowels of the Donnell Library Center, on 53rd Street.
Her love of maps started during her school years. She loved them not only for their information but also for their beauty. "They're so visual," she said. "I'm a television baby."
She leans down and slides open a drawer. "This is a rule," she said, balancing big, weather-beaten sheets in one hand as she digs carefully in the drawer with the other. "Whatever you want is always in the bottom folder."
Finally she finds it, Egbert Viele's water map from 1874, one of her most popular. "People from construction sites will come in and wonder why they're standing in a lake," she said, spreading the map on a wide reading table. The answer is that Manhattan has lots of landfill.
"As of 1874 a huge piece of landfill was already there," she said, tracing a sizable area on the map marked "made land" with her finger. "It started with the Dutch. They brought their experience from Holland."
In 1970, at 23, Ms. Hudson started to work for the map division, a place where curiosity can sweep one away. She is not immune. A recent project is to compile maps of the shoreline. "So much of our experience of the harbor in New York is negative, going through it, over it, going somewhere else," she said. "I started thinking about carefully pursuing a map of the shoreline of all the boroughs." Similarly, she says, "There are a lot of underground waterways in Manhattan and no one knows they're there."
Ms. Hudson has also started a list of prominent African-American historical sites, as revealed by early city maps. There is Weeksville, for instance, a vibrant 19th-century community of freed slaves in Bedford-Stuyvesant, as well as a thriving black area on West 99th Street in Manhattan that disappeared when a two-block stretch of West 99th was swept away in the 1950's to build Park West Village. 
Maps of the American West are another enthusiasm. Ms. Hudson's division will display some of these maps in an exhibition called "Heading West: Mapping the Territory," that is to run through May 19 at the 42nd Street library.
Ms. Hudson's maps help unlock the mysteries of the city. An obscure parallelogram created by Christopher, Bank, Greene and Hudson Streets in the West Village turns out to follow the lines of Madame Warren's farm, as outlined on an 1874 map. Oddly shaped buildings near Columbia University and in Lower Manhattan are products of property lines of old farms drawn to give access to roads to Boston and the Hudson River. 
Old place names also float back to the surface on these maps -- Great Barn Island for Wards Island, Brookland for Brooklyn and Montgomerie's Ward, which cut across Lower Manhattan in 1730.
 SOME sloping streets used to be gentle hills that had their own windmills. An 1811 map shows a never-built military parade ground and arsenal that was to have occupied the swath from 23rd to 34th Streets, between Third and Seventh Avenues. The Harlem Marsh ran along 106th Street from Fifth Avenue to the East River.
Ms. Hudson's maps can even revive questions of historic justice: an 1856 map shows the homes, roads, churches and gardens of Seneca Village, a black and Irish working-class community between 81st and 86th Streets that was destroyed to build Central Park.
Ms. Hudson's visitors include novelists, television people, urban archaeologists, conspiracy theorists decoding the World Trade Center bombing, amateur detectives searching for buried tunnels, construction men, railroad enthusiasts looking for old lines, earthquake hobbyists looking for fault lines and families hunting for the name of the church their grandparents attended.
Builders, architects and developers are among the regulars. In fact, Ms. Hudson said, she and her staff have a front-row seat to most development battles in the city, from the West Side Highway to waste-transfer stations. Often both sides use the same maps to reach drastically different conclusions. She must remain neutral. 
"That's New York," Ms. Hudson said. "It wants to be new. We just give them the maps and they have to fight it out."
As she walks around the room, Ms. Hudson likes to run her fingertips fondly over old fabric maps. "It's like these maps are alive," she said. "Modern maps are not the same." She stops at a cloth one. "This will be in better condition than we are in 200 years," she said.
By the time one leaves the map room, it is clear that, bewildering as it seems at first, all these maps do faithfully represent New York. After all, this is a city that shifts for a living. In the end, that is what the vertigo is, knowing that all those cities are still out there, piled on top of one another.
"You could write a novel with these maps, short stories," Ms. Hudson said. "They tell me wonderful stories."

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Cry From the Past As Times Get Harder

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM McDONALD 

 BODY:
PLEASE help me I'm hungry. Please help me I'm hungry. Please help me I'm hungry."
 The little old woman went on like that, over and over, to anyone and everyone marching by in the long, cheerless walkway between the shuttle platforms and the East Side subway lines at Grand Central. But no one stopped. No one gave her anything, not so far as I could see. 
 This was a tough crowd. Almost everyone wore the stone face common to the subway: a neutralizing mixture of resignation and anticipation, of self-absorption and auto-pilot alertness. In the subway you want to be aware of your surroundings only as much as you need to be to get to the surface as quickly as possible. Thus it was this evening rush hour. People wanted to go home, to dinner, maybe to a restaurant. It had been a long day. Please. We were, it's fair to say, famished.
"Please help me I'm hungry."
The woman had a preturnaturally high-pitched voice, almost childlike. She stood no taller than five feet and looked almost stout -- amply fed, one might think -- bundled up in her long, woolen gray coat buttoned to the neck. She wore a kerchief about her head, tight as a tourniquet, reminding me of the grim photographs of the Bosnian refugees, the ones of women with devastation in their eyes. All she said was, "Please help me I'm hungry," mechanically, making almost no eye contact with anyone. I'm sure I wasn't the only one who thought she might be a little touched in the head, possibly not even hungry.
But haven't we been here before? Didn't we deal with "the plight of the homeless" in the 80's and early 90's, before the market boom?
Back then the homeless were everywhere. An army of the wretched camped in our midst in boxes. Good citizens were dismayed and disgusted. There were news articles about them, too, about their outrage, compassion, guilt, fear, anxiety, indifference.
We were told, as if we needed to be told, how people would choose to give or not give on the basis of an on-the-spot calculation, weighing sympathy against risk, inconvenience and the chance of being conned.
So, yes, we have been through this before. The news, if it even is news, is that none of it ended, not with a boom, not with a whimper. If you are hearing a whimper, it is coming from the 10,000 children who are still homeless in this city, sleeping in miserable shelters, eating poorly, missing school. Maybe it's a sign that the joy ride is gearing down when children who live out of a bag make the front page again, as they did in this paper recently, under the headline "Homeless Shelters in New York Fill to Highest Level Since 80's." Children are one of two groups with the biggest increases, the article said. The other is women.
"Please help me I'm hungry."
Maybe the old woman is someone's mother. Maybe she once had a young girl's sunny hopes and expectations, and look what awaited her. You wonder about these lost souls. Or sometimes you do. More often, probably, you walk on. You can't give to every panhandler. Besides, you've written checks to charities. And if you do drop some change into a cup, you don't have to pay the person much more mind. You've done your part, helped someone get through the night and, not incidentally, unburdened your conscience. Acting humanely has its satisfactions.
Yet this is yesterday's news, too. And because it is, that's telling. New Yorkers, except for the thoroughly insulated, have become so habituated to the rituals of reaching out to the homeless or steering clear of them that no one seems to talk about such things anymore. A kind of hopeless public acceptance has become as entrenched as the homeless themselves, as rote as the old woman's spiel. The subway car intrusions go on, illegal or not. The blanket-shrouded men still sleep on the grates. The gaunt, mangy fellow I pass almost every day is still cadging quarters down the street after, what is it now, a decade? And for all the times I've reached into my pocket, I still feel a small piece of myself dying when I shrug off an appeal for help, no matter how I rationalize.
"Please help me I'm hungry."
The old woman's plea stayed with me after I had hurried to make the uptown No. 6. I should have given her something, I thought, even allowing for the not-so-remote possibility that she was not as desperate as she seemed, that she had been mouthing a time-tested line guaranteed to extract pity and spare change.
So, gullible or not, I resolved to do right the next day. I even put some dollars in my coat pocket beforehand so that I wouldn't have to fumble with my wallet in plain view. Well, the next day came, the shuttle pulled in, the crowd spilled out and, as people funneled into the walkway, I began searching for the woman in the kerchief. She was not there, of course. And I have not seen her since.
