HEADLINE: A Healthy SAT Debate 

 BODY:
The SAT will be taken by two million people this year and is required for admission at the vast majority of of the country's four-year colleges and universities. The test has dominated the admissions process for more than half a century and is likely to do so for decades to come. Even so, administrators at some selective colleges have discarded the SAT, on the grounds that it distorts the educational process and screens out minority students and others who perform perfectly well in college. Defenders of the test range from those who see it as a vital yardstick in a time of grade inflation to those who view it as a flawed but necessary component of the sorting process and the true believers who see it as a sacred index revealing everything one needs to know about an individual. Given the confusion, the emerging debate about how best to use the SAT is a healthy and potentially useful development. 
 The College Board, which sponsors the SAT, does what it can to dispel myths and misinterpretations. It has issued a statement that SAT's are not a measure of innate intelligence and do not measure book learning or motivation, creativity and special talents -- all factors that affect success in college. The SAT is rather a test of mental dexterity, one element among many in predicting college performance. 
 But the public as a whole ignores these caveats. Educational rating services evaluate colleges based partly on average SAT scores. Bond-rating companies even take scores into account when judging a college's creditworthiness. The obsession with doing well on the test has bled down into sixth grade, where 12-year-olds are doing practice problems when they should be getting a basic education.
The debate about the usefulness of this test was renewed last month by Dr. Richard Atkinson, the president of California's public university system. Dr. Atkinson recommended to the university faculty and Board of Regents that the system discard the SAT as soon as it can develop an admissions test that is directly tied to the college preparatory courses students are required to take in California. While the new test is being developed, Dr. Atkinson wants the faculty to abandon the SAT I, which tests abstract reasoning and is a partial predictor of first-year performance in college, and substitute the SAT II. That test is more directly calibrated to the specific subjects students are required to master in high school. This line of thinking has emerged in several states, where education officials are favoring achievement tests that are more clearly keyed to what students are held responsible for in high school. 
Criticism of the SAT has spread in recent years. But the Atkinson statement was particularly dramatic because he presides over a widely admired public university system. He is also a testing expert and a former director of the National Science Foundation. Over all, about 390 of the country's 1,800 four-year colleges and universities do not require SAT scores for their applicants. If the University of California decides to stop using the test, it will be the first public university system to do so. But several quality liberal-arts institutions -- including Bowdoin, Bard, Connecticut College, Bates and, most recently, Mount Holyoke -- no longer require SAT scores. Mount Holyoke had long since counted the SAT as about 10 percent of the admissions process, relying instead on high school transcripts, graded papers, letters of recommendation and an evaluation scheme that rates high schools in terms of academic rigor.
However it turns out, California's debate will have served a valuable function if it relieves a growing national obsession with tests and helps the country put the SAT in perspective.

HEADLINE: In America; 
Fewer Students, Greater Gains

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Lisa Goldstein teaches second- and third-grade pupils at a public school on Manhattan's Upper East Side. She has taught classes with as many as 32 children, and classes with as few as 18. Not surprisingly, she's found that fewer is better.
 "It's my experience that when the classes are smaller the children progress at a much faster pace," she said. "Even the little things make a difference. In a smaller class you have fewer children saying, 'I have to go to the bathroom,' or 'I don't feel good today.' Smaller classes are so much more manageable. And they're especially important in these early grades because at that age the children really need a lot of individual attention." 
 Several important studies, some of them conducted over many years, have shown that class size reduction in the early grades has many benefits, including higher pupil achievement in reading and math. Smaller classes have been shown to be particularly beneficial for poor and minority students.
The most celebrated study, Tennessee's Project STAR, showed that students in smaller classes tended to achieve higher grades, had better high school graduation rates and were more likely to attend college.
Just last week a Princeton economist, Dr. Alan Krueger, disclosed the latest findings from Project STAR, which included the following:
* While students were in small classes, the black-white academic achievement gap narrowed by 38 percent. Some of this improvement was lost when the youngsters returned to normal-size classes, but not all of it.
* Smaller classes increased the likelihood that black students would take the ACT or SAT college entrance exams from 31.8 to 41.3 percent. A paper written by Dr. Krueger and a colleague, Diane Whitmore, a Princeton doctoral candidate, asserted, "If all students were assigned to a small class, the black-white gap in taking a college entrance exam would fall by an estimated 60 percent."
Smaller classes may not be the cure for everything that ails the public schools in the United States, but they sure seem to be helpful, especially for disadvantaged kids. Leonie Haimson, an educational consultant in New York City who is a staunch advocate of smaller classes, noted recently that class size reduction is one of the few programs that research has conclusively shown to boost student achievement and to narrow the academic gap between blacks and whites.
So why, you might ask, has President Bush, in his heralded education plan, eliminated all federal funds targeted for class size reduction?
Good question. Mr. Bush is scrapping the Clinton administration's smaller class size initiative. The Bush proposal would fold the funds currently targeted for class size reduction into block grants to be forwarded to the states and used at the discretion of local authorities.
This is happening at the same time that the president is insisting on an elaborate system of testing to measure student performance. Does it make sense to demand higher performance while simultaneously undermining one of the cornerstones of improved performance?
Senator Patty Murray, a Democrat from Washington State, offered an amendment to the president's proposal last week that would, as she put it, "continue the progress we have made over the past two years" by providing $2.4 billion in the next fiscal year to help recruit and hire teachers for the express purpose of reducing class sizes in grades one through three.
"Study after study shows that smaller classes help children," said Senator Murray.
Her amendment died in committee.
President Bush has said that improving public education is one of his top priorities. But his focus has been mostly on raising standards and demanding more accountability.
He would do well to keep in mind something that Senator Edward Kennedy said last week: "Tests and accountability are simply the measure of reforms -- they are not the reforms themselves."
Higher standards and increased testing are meaningless if we don't provide the real-world resources that enable children to learn more.

HEADLINE: Oil Is a Matter Of National Security 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your March 5 editorial "A Narrow Energy Bill," which opposed my National Energy Security bill: 
 The legislation would establish a balanced and comprehensive energy policy -- a policy necessary to meet our growing energy demands and reduce our dependence on foreign oil. 
 We rely on foreign markets to provide 56 percent of our oil -- and that will rise to two-thirds by the end of the decade, putting much of our own fate and future, including how we heat our homes and schools, in the hands of foreign governments, often hostile to American interests.
We must not only encourage the use of alternative fuels and increase energy efficiency, but we must also boost our own domestic supplies. With rising energy costs expected to cut 2 percent off our economic growth, we simply cannot afford the alternative.

FRANK H. MURKOWSKI
Washington, March 8, 2001

The writer, an Alaska Republican, is chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee.

HEADLINE: Japan Is Shackled by Deflation, Blocking Its Hope for Recovery 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, March 12 

 BODY:
As Japan shows signs of falling back into recession, behind many of its woes lies deflation, a rare but devastating drop in the prices of goods and services that is starting to feed on itself. Deflation is chipping away at asset values, increasing credit risks, pinching wages and salaries, and preventing the economy from generating any sustained growth after a decade of stagnation.
 Stocks are trading at the same prices of 15 years ago, and land values in major cities, which back many of the loans made by Japanese banks, have fallen 65 percent from their peak in 1991. 
 Excluding fresh foods, prices in Japan dropped 1.1 percent last year, the greatest decline since World War II. In Tokyo, core prices fell a stunning 0.4 percent last month alone, the 18th month that prices have fallen. 
"A crisis of pernicious deflation, which could destroy people's lives, is looming," declared the Yomiuri Shimbun, the most conservative of Japan's major daily newspapers, in a front page editorial last week.
Although today's reported 0.8 percent rise in gross domestic product for the final quarter of last year slightly exceeded expectations, Japan has recently been hit by a rash of bad news. "The economic outlook has worsened more quickly than we anticipated," Kazuo Ueda, a member of the policy board at the Bank of Japan, said in an interview late last week. And with growth slowing in the United States and elsewhere, many experts fear that another slump in Japan, the second-largest economy on the globe, spells big trouble for the rest of the world.
Just last week, the government reported that household spending in January was actually at a lower level than a year earlier. It disclosed that machinery orders, an important indicator of investment, fell nearly 12 percent in January from the previous month. And Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, shocked Tokyo on Thursday when he told Parliament that the government's books were close to a "catastrophic situation."
Over the weekend, Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori met with senior members of his party to signal his intention to step down next month, and Japan's leaders are now preoccupied with their inability to find a new prime minister.
The human costs of deflation are meanwhile becoming more visible. When Hitoshi Matsushita started pondering his impending retirement seven years ago, his first concern was putting a roof over his head. "I was living in company housing," he said. "I thought buying a place would be convenient for my future."
In 1994, prices for housing had already started to decline after Japan's bubble economy had burst. The 76 million yen, or about $636,000 at current exchange rates, that Mr. Matsushita paid for his apartment looked like a bargain.
But real estate prices have continued to fall, leaving the home now worth at most 40 million yen -- and Mr. Matsushita still owes the bank 30 million yen. "I can only work until I'm 70, and at that point, I guess my life will crash," said Mr. Matsushita, who is now 66. "Right now, I'm desperate."
Paradoxically, deflation was welcomed not so long ago in a country where prices are so much higher than anywhere else. It was also regarded as a sign that Japan was finally opening its doors to international competition.
Many still see it as a force for accelerating economic modernization. One result is a heated debate over whether deflation is good.
Examples of falling prices and greater competition abound. Consumers are all but stampeding to Starbucks outlets here, where a tall caffe latte sells for 320 yen, a bargain compared with prices at the dying kissaten, traditional Japanese coffee shops infamous for selling thimble-size cups of coffee for more than twice that amount.
Then there is Uniqlo, a chain of Gap-like apparel stores that is perhaps the most popular store in Japan at the moment. Importing most of its products from China, Uniqlo is putting enormous pressure on its competitors here.
"I have a Bally's leather briefcase, a Burberry's leather briefcase and a Coach doctor's bag, but I switched to a nylon brief case from Uniqlo because it is much easier to use, very functional, and most of all, it was only 2,900 yen," said Koki Konishi, an executive at a car company, who also buys boxer shorts there at two for 900 yen, or $7.63, and T-shirts, three for 1,000 yen ($8.47).
Given Japan's aging population, stable or even slightly declining prices are seen by many as desirable because they preserve the value of the savings of the elderly. Deposits held in postal savings accounts nominally earn a scant 0.11 percent a year, but deflation has lifted the real return by almost 2 percentage points over two years.
"The older a society is, the more anti-inflation it is because higher savings balances are hurt by inflation," said Vincent J. Truglia, co-head of the sovereign risk unit group at Moody's Investors Service.
Citing just such cases, the Bank of Japan has long been deflation's biggest cheerleader. The bank's governor, Masaru Hayami, insists that this particular variety is "good deflation," with suppliers of goods and services able to offer more for less.
But outside the central bank, many economists and even some top government experts warn that Japan risks being sucked into a dangerous deflationary spiral that may only worsen as companies are forced to cut prices and wages repeatedly.
"We have gone beyond the point where the deflation we are seeing can be attributed to globalization and greater competition," said Takatoshi Ito, deputy vice minister for international affairs at the Ministry of Finance. "Deflation is now the mirror image of falling demand, and that's not good deflation."
Critics of the central bank say that Japanese consumers have no reason to spend despite lower prices. Not only has the value of their homes plummeted, but unemployment is at a postwar peak of 4.9 percent and is expected to climb more.
"If incomes don't rise in nominal terms -- and they aren't -- you are having to run faster to meet your mortgage obligations," said Jesper Koll, chief economist at Merrill Lynch in Tokyo. "And it is not just Mrs. Watanabe who is feeling strapped. Every sector here, whether we talk about the banks, corporations, households or the government is highly leveraged." 
Even though prices are falling, many incomes are falling faster. Corporate earnings rose 28 percent last year, leading economists to predict a 5.5 percent increase in winter bonuses. Instead, bonuses shrank by half a percent, as companies spent their hard-earned cash to offset their increasingly painful debts.
A number of economists, however, argue that Japan needs more deflation as a form of shock therapy: fewer debts, greater efficiency and a reallocation of labor, they say, is precisely the bitter medicine the economy must swallow. "If deflation continues, inevitably it will put further downward pressure on wages, and if wages are cut, then prices will have to fall, too," said Tadashi Nakamae, an outspoken economist who runs his own consulting firm. "I think Japan needs to accept that. Later, it will be offset by higher growth."
The question is whether Japan can tolerate the pain of waiting patiently for such benefits of deflation to appear. Already, textile manufacturers are urging the government to curb the imports that underpin Uniqlo's success.
Meanwhile, officials at the Ministry of Finance, which once supported the Bank of Japan's monetary policy, are growing increasingly worried about deflation's devastating impact on the national budget. They are pushing the Bank of Japan to lower its already low interest rates, print more money, buy government bonds, do anything short of dropping bank notes out of helicopters to combat deflation.
And even Mr. Hayami, the top central banker, has begun suggesting that, if the economy continues to deteriorate, the bank may abandon its staunch resistance to buying government bonds to expand the money supply. That may come too late, however, to prevent a very grim future for Mr. Matsushita and his family, along with millions of Japanese who owe more on their homes than they are worth.
He and others in his apartment complex have sued the government, which owns it and had dropped the price of unsold units to dispose of them. But they will have a hard time proving their case, for they are victims less of bureaucratic bungling than of powerful market forces.
Mr. Matshushita had planned to use 50,000 shares of Yamaichi Securities stock he accumulated during three decades of work to pay down his 63 million yen mortgage. At one point, his stake was worth 1.5 billion yen, about $13 million.
But Yamaichi went bust, shattering his dreams of a leisurely old age. Now Mr. Matsushita works as a security guard at night and part-time in a convenience store during the day. "I might sell this place, and if I'm lucky, I might then have 10 million yen in hand to rent a little house in the country and live off of my pension money," he said. "My living standard will go down, but I still have some hope."

HEADLINE: Visiting Chinese to Urge Bush Not to Sell Arms to Taiwan 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, March 11 

 BODY:
Deputy Premier Qian Qichen, the highest-ranking Chinese official to visit Washington in two years, is expected to urge President Bush next week not to sell more advanced weapons to Taiwan. 
 Mr. Qian, a former foreign minister, continues to play a key role in Taiwan policy and will be visiting just weeks before Mr. Bush must decide which weapons the United States will sell Taiwan this year. 
 Under the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, the United States is obligated to provide Taiwan with equipment to defend itself, and in April the two sides conclude their annual arms sales talks, one of the most fractious issues in Chinese-American relations. 
Beijing is concerned that Mr. Bush will take a more aggressive stance than his predecessor, and is bothered by Mr. Bush's rhetorical shift toward describing China as a "strategic competitor," rather than the "strategic partner" seen by the Clinton administration.
Perry Link, a China scholar at Princeton University, said: "Qian is a skilled diplomat and smooth talker and wants, I think, to smooth things out with the new Bush people, try to get them as far as possible back to where the Chinese government had the Clinton people, both in general -- viewing China as a partner more than an adversary -- and on the particular issue of arms sales to Taiwan." 
Last year, President Clinton deferred making a decision on selling Taiwan Arleigh Burke-class destroyers equipped with Tomahawk cruise missiles and Aegis radar systems. 
But Taiwan's request for the ships remains on the table. The Aegis system could someday be adapted for use in the kind of naval theater missile defense which Mr. Bush supports but China vehemently opposes.
Taiwan has indicated that it may also ask the administration to sell it four Kidd-class guided-missile destroyers, which are less powerful than the Arleigh Burke ships but would nonetheless be the largest and most powerful in Taiwan's Navy.
Either class of ships would represent the most significant weapons transfer by the United States to Taiwan since Mr. Bush's father sold it 150 advanced F-16 fighter aircraft in 1992. China charged that the sale breached a 1982 joint communique in which Washington vowed not to increase the quantity or quality of arms sold to Taiwan.
Mr. Qian was quoted Friday by the state-run, English-language China Daily as saying the Taiwan issue was "not only a problem left over by China's civil war, it is also the result of U.S. military intervention as the United States has kept selling advanced weapons to Taiwan."
Those comments followed a warning on Tuesday by Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan that the United States should recognize the "serious dangers involved" in providing more weapons to Taiwan.
Mr. Qian is likely to emphasize that a relaxation of tensions between China and Taiwan could be undone by more arms sales.
Beijing has supported a series of low-level official contacts with Taiwan politicians. Direct shipping links have also begun with the Taiwan islands of Quemoy and Matsu. 
Mr. Qian has made overtures to Taiwan by softening Beijing's language on its terms for re-unification.
"What we adhere to is one China that embraces the mainland and Taiwan," China Daily quoted him as saying on Friday. "We understand the aspirations of Taiwan compatriots to maintain the status quo."
Mr. Qian said he would also discuss with American officials China's opposition to the proposed development of a missile defense system. 
The United States will be eager to hear how China proposes to spend its increased military budget. Beijing announced last week that military spending would rise 17.7 percent this year, compared with a 12 percent increase last year.
Mr. Qian's five-day visit to Washington and New York will begin March 18. His visit coincides with the March 19 session of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva, where Washington is expected to support a motion condemning China's abuses of human rights.
He is scheduled to see Mr. Bush on March 22, and is likely to ask him if he will visit China for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to be held in Shanghai in October.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo; 
Divergent Voices Heard In Bush Foreign Policy

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11 

 BODY:
First, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell suggested that the administration would continue tentative steps toward normalizing relations with reclusive North Korea. Less than 24 hours later, President Bush offered a warier view, and officials scrambled to quash the notion of real fissures opening in the new foreign policy team. 
 But the gap in tone between the president and his senior diplomat raised the question of whose voice was dominant in foreign policy, and in the longer term, which opinions would prevail. 
 It is still early, Bush officials say, adding that they are busy reviewing policies -- from Iraq to North Korea, from missile defense to Taiwan -- in order to decide in which direction to head. 
The early, very public disagreements could put factions in the Republican Party at odds with one another, leaving Mr. Bush to pick a policy and risk alienating some faction, and possibly allies overseas.
Beyond discordant notes over Korea, where some 37,000 American troops are stationed, and over Iraq, where his father fought a war 10 years ago, Mr. Bush faces looming questions in areas like the Balkans, where American troops are also deployed. He and his foreign policy team must decide whether to deploy a missile defense system, and determine a policy on the Middle East, where American leadership has often proven crucial. 
In the last week, General Powell, the first of Mr. Bush's foreign policy appointments, appeared to march to a different drummer from that of his colleagues -- Vice President Dick Cheney, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser -- in areas of importance to Republicans. 
The Secretary of State used his recent Middle East trip to articulate a new look at Iraq that concentrated on tightening sanctions involving arms and money while easing sanctions that affected ordinary Iraqis.
But when General Powell returned home, he heard complaints from conservatives in Congress asking why he had been so soft. Where was the policy to overthrow President Saddam Hussein? The secretary slightly adjusted his statements, saying the administration was in contact with the Iraqi opposition group, the Iraqi National Congress, and was studying "other things" that might be done. 
The pressure on the State Department to become more serious about removing Mr. Hussein is likely to mount from both the White House and the Pentagon. 
Mr. Cheney has built a cohesive group of foreign policy experts, a group that may become a decisive power center.
The vice president, who is viewed as more conservative, and General Powell, who is seen as more pragmatic, served together in the administration of Mr. Bush's father -- Mr. Cheney as defense secretary and General Powell as the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff -- and the two men acknowledged their different political outlooks then.
John Hannah, who worked at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, where there is support for the overthrow of Mr. Hussein, is among the foreign policy experts working for Mr. Cheney. Last week, Mr. Hannah met with people who have long favored the use of force to get rid of the Iraqi leader. 
At the Pentagon, Mr. Rumsfeld and his deputy, Paul B. Wolfowitz, signed a public letter in 1998 calling for Mr. Hussein's overthrow. So did several people now in competition for senior Pentagon jobs, including Peter Rodman of the Nixon Center; Zalmay M. Khalizad of the Rand Corporation; and Doug Feith, a former deputy assistant secretary of defense.
On North Korea, General Powell remarked to reporters the day before the South Korean leader, Kim Dae Jung, arrived last week that the administration would pick up talks with North Korea that the Clinton administration left incomplete. The remark was interpreted as meaning the new administration would move forward on missile negotiations. 
The next day, the general said "we have to not be naive about the nature of this threat" of North Korea. Then, Mr. Bush, who had been briefed for his meeting with Mr. Kim by Ms. Rice, said it was not clear that the North Koreans were "keeping all terms of all agreements." 
After two days of back and forth, the State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said General Powell had always agreed with the administration policy of "realism," "emphasis on North Korea's proliferation activities" and "verification." 
One reason for the different tones between General Powell and Mr. Bush was that the general was unaware of how strongly Mr. Bush felt about North Korea and its Communist government, several State Department officials said.
Foreign policy experts said it was well known that there were different voices in the administration, and it might be too early to predict permanent splits.
"I don't think there is a proven case of deep fissures," said Leslie H. Gelb, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations. "The main reason you see the disputes in public is that senior people don't have their teams in place and they haven't had a chance to meet on a sustained basis to work out their policies."

Deflation Shackles Japan, Blocking Hope of Recovery
As Japan shows signs of falling back into recession, what is behind many of its woes is deflation, a rare but devastating drop in the prices of goods and services that is starting to feed on itself. Though some economists have championed deflation as a road to economic modernization, the question is whether Japan can tolerate the pain. A1

HEADLINE: BUSH FACES FIGHT ON PLAN TO LIMIT OR CUT PROGRAMS 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11 

 BODY:
Even as he battles to win legislative approval for his $1.6 trillion tax cut, President Bush faces an escalating fight in Congress over his proposal to cut or restrain spending on a wide swath of government programs.
 Not only are Democrats in Congress opposed, but some of Mr. Bush's fellow Republicans have also signaled that they will have difficulty going along with his plan to provide increases for the military and education while cutting or freezing many other departments. 
 Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, has said overall spending on government programs outside Social Security and Medicare would probably have to increase next year by more than the 4 percent sought by Mr. Bush.
"Can we, in fact, do all the things that have been recommended with 4 percent growth?" Mr. Domenici asked at a Budget Committee hearing this month. "I don't know if we can." 
Mr. Bush has made holding down spending one of his primary goals. His ability to do so at a time of budget surpluses will be a political challenge as daunting as persuading Congress to go along with his tax cut.
Hovering over the issue, especially in the minds of Democrats, are recollections of the aftermath of the fiscal decisions of the 1980's. In 1981, President Ronald Reagan cut taxes and sought large increases in Pentagon spending, as Mr. Bush is likely to do in coming years. But Mr. Reagan also allowed spending on many domestic programs to grow.
The results were surges in the budget deficit and the national debt and economic and political scars still apparent two decades later.
"People in both parties are fundamentally concerned about the Reagan precedent, that this tax cut will be followed by an increase in military spending, unsustainable new programs and an expanding debt," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey.
White House officials say the political and economic situation today is very different from the one Mr. Reagan faced. The projected surplus of $5.6 trillion in the next decade, they said, provides a considerable buffer against slipping back into the red. In 1981, the government ran a $79 billion deficit.
They also said Mr. Bush was prepared to take on his own party if necessary to limit spending increases, even if it meant vetoing appropriations bills. Spending increases of the size approved by the Republican Congress and President Bill Clinton in recent years, including last year's 8 percent increase in discretionary spending, "would not only destroy the budget surplus but would require, in the end, an increase in taxes," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser.
Mr. Bush's budget outline calls for $46.1 billion in additional discretionary spending next year, with the biggest shares going to the Pentagon and the Education Department.
But he would offset some of that increase by cutting $20.5 billion from other programs, leaving his budget for government operations outside Social Security and Medicare at $660.7 billion next year, a 4 percent increase over this year.
Democrats said Mr. Bush was dedicating too much of the surplus to his tax cut and not enough to the issues that voters thought were important.
"The president's tax cut is so big that it shortchanges the rest of the budget, providing inadequate resources to even our nation's top priorities, like education," said Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the senior Democrat on the Budget Committee.
In drafting a spending plan for next year, Mr. Domenici is clearly keeping in mind the political trade-offs between tax cuts and new spending. Appearing on the CBS program "Face The Nation" today, he predicted that the Senate would pass the main part of Mr. Bush's tax plan, a reduction in the marginal income tax rate.
But Mr. Domenici suggested that other aspects of Mr. Bush's proposal, like eliminating the so-called marriage penalty and inheritance taxes, might face stiffer tests.
Democrats tend to push harder than Republicans for spending, but reining in spending has been hard regardless of the party in control.
Not only do many members of Congress see a case for increased spending to address particular issues, but even programs that do not have wide support often have determined backing from powerful constituencies. More than $8 billion of the cuts that Mr. Bush is relying on would come from what is usually referred to as pork barrel spending -- money earmarked by members of Congress for local projects or one-time appropriations that have a way of becoming permanent.
Faced with getting a budget through a Senate in which each party has 50 seats, Mr. Domenici is considering adding money to Mr. Bush's requests in a variety of areas.
Among them are agriculture, which Mr. Bush would cut by 7.7 percent, and the creation of programs to provide prescription drug coverage for retirees, which analysts in both parties say will cost far more than the $153 billion Mr. Bush wants for it. Lawmakers are also considering more money for science and energy programs like the United States Geological Survey, for which Mr. Bush's budget plans cuts.
History suggests that members of both parties are likely to support even higher military spending next year than Mr. Bush has proposed.
Mr. Domenici also has to keep in mind programs with powerful patrons, like the Maritime Guarantee Loan Subsidy program, which provides low-cost loans to shipbuilders. Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, whose state has one of the nation's largest shipyards, Ingalls, is among the industry's staunchest supporters.
The White House could even come under pressure on programs that Mr. Bush would not cut. Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, visited a veterans hospital in Philadelphia on Friday with Anthony J. Principi, the secretary of veterans affairs. Afterward, Mr. Specter said that a $1 billion increase, which Mr. Bush proposed for the department next year to bring its budget to $23.4 billion was not enough.
At the same time, interest groups and lobbyists are trying to protect or expand other programs. A coalition of large corporations, some of them among the most generous contributors to Republican campaigns, is trying to defeat the administration's plan to cut 25 percent from the budget for the Export-Import Bank, which subsidizes exports for companies like Boeing and Caterpillar.
Mr. Bush's support is firmer in the House, home to many of the most ardent Republican budget cutters. Representative Jim Nussle of Iowa, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, said in an interview this week that holding discretionary spending to a 4 percent increase next year was "very doable" because increases in the last few years had bloated the budget.
But even in the House, some Republicans admit having heartburn over the prospect of cutting farm aid, transportation projects and other programs that must be trimmed if the president's tax cut is approved and money for the Pentagon and education is increased.
Asked if he could support cuts in agriculture spending, for example, Mr. Nussle left himself some wiggle room. He said that before any decisions are made, Congress should review farm aid policy from top to bottom, in much the same way that Mr. Bush has ordered the Pentagon to re-examine its long-term needs.
"I believe we can adopt a budget that does not immediately break into the surplus piggy bank," Mr. Nussle said. "But if discipline breaks for one, it breaks for all."

HEADLINE: Ford Promotes Executive From E-Business 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 11 

 BODY:
In a vote of confidence in Internet marketing by a giant of the old economy, the Ford Motor Company has increased considerably the responsibilities of the president of its electronic commerce operations.
 On Friday, Brian P. Kelley, the 40-year-old president of Ford's ConsumerConnect unit, which handles e-business, was put in charge of Ford's brand management, dealer relations, auto parts sales, market research, advertising purchases, and some sales and marketing activities, while retaining oversight of electronic commerce. 
 Replacing Mr. Kelley as president of ConsumerConnect will be Karen C. Francis, 38, who was the general manager of the Oldsmobile division of General Motors until a year ago, when she quit and went to Internet Capital Group, which invests in electronic commerce businesses. She also becomes a vice president of Ford, and will report to Mr. Kelley. 
Run almost entirely by men until two years ago, Ford announced separately on Friday that it would put all of its North American assembly plants under a woman, Anne Stevens. She will also be promoted to vice president on April 2. Ms. Stevens, 52, had been the executive director of vehicle operations in North America, and becomes the highest-ranking woman ever on the manufacturing side of a Detroit automaker.
The naming of Ms. Stevens and Ms. Francis as vice presidents means that 9 of Ford's 51 vice presidents will be women, compared with only two at the beginning of 1999 and one at the start of 1998.
Mr. Kelley effectively replaces Robert L. Rewey, a Ford group vice president who, with varying titles and a slight widening of duties, has overseen most of the company's marketing and sales operations since 1988. Mr. Rewey, 62, had been expected to retire this year.
Mr. Kelley said that in his new role, he expected Ford to continue selling cars only through its dealers, and not to sell cars directly to the public over the Internet. Dealers and their allies among state regulators have strenuously opposed direct sales.
But at a press conference at Ford's headquarters in Dearborn, a southwestern suburb of Detroit, Mr. Kelley also noted that, "E-business is a tool that a company like Ford can use in all our processes."
The move makes Mr. Kelley one of the youngest and fastest-rising stars in Ford's senior management. He joined the company only 16 months ago from the General Electric Company, where he was a vice president of the appliances division and its general manager for sales and distribution.
Mr. Kelley already had the rank of corporate vice president at Ford, and that rank did not change today. He became the vice president for global consumer services, while Mr. Rewey had been group vice president for global consumer services.
Under Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive since the beginning of 1999, Ford has gradually flattened the top tiers of its management, allowing some executive vice presidents and group vice presidents to retire while giving their responsibilities to vice presidents.

HEADLINE: Rating Life: Live Fast, Die Young 

BYLINE:  By ERICA GOODE 

 BODY:
A longer life is a better life. Or so common wisdom assumes. But is a longer life that is filled with modest pleasure and accomplishment better than a shorter life of intense happiness and success?
 Not necessarily, according to research by a social psychologist at the University of Illinois, Dr. Edward Diener. In a series of studies, Dr. Diener and colleagues found that when people were asked to judge the desirability of a life, they gave far more weight to how the life ended than to its duration. 
 "Respondents rated a wonderful life that ended abruptly as better than one with additional mildly pleasant years," the researchers report in the March issue of Psychological Science.
Dr. Diener and his colleagues labeled this phenomenon the "James Dean effect" after the 24-year-old actor, whose successful film career was cut short by a fatal car crash in 1955.
Similarly, a life ending abruptly after years of hardship and sorrow was rated as less desirable than the same life elongated by additional, less difficult years, a finding the researchers called the "Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn effect," after the Russian writer, who remained melancholy though he moved to the West and left his years in a prison camp behind.
The findings, Dr. Diener said, run counter to the idea that longevity and life quality are inextricably linked, a common view of policy makers and proponents of classical economic theory. The researchers noted that the United Nations used longevity as one of three criteria for determining quality of life. But their data, they said, "contradict a simple hedonic calculus in which years of pleasure and pain are summed."
"Our society is living longer," Dr. Diener said, "and the issue is, if you live longer, what are those last years like, and is length itself a good thing?"
The research grew out of studies by Dr. Daniel Kahneman of Princeton, who demonstrated in studies that in evaluating their own experiences, people tended to pay less attention to how long an event lasted than to how the experience ended, and to peak moments, either good or bad, that stood out in their minds.
In one well-known study, for example, Dr. Kahneman and a colleague found that patients who received colonoscopies recalled feeling more pain during shorter procedures than they did during longer procedures that included a period of lesser discomfort at the end. This held true even though both shorter and longer procedures involved the same amount of pain, the researchers found. 
The new studies, Dr. Diener said, show that this "peak and end" rule appears to apply "not only to things of a short duration like a colonoscopy but maybe to bigger things like the duration of a lifetime."
Dr. David Schkade, a psychologist at the University of Texas business school, said, "What's very nice about this is its extension to people's judgment about things they didn't participate in."
"That's actually a substantial advance," Dr. Schkade said, "because it's not always true that phenomena that govern what people do or experience personally map onto what people will think about someone else's experience."
In the studies, Dr. Diener and his colleagues asked their subjects -- college undergraduates and middle-aged adults -- to read and evaluate accounts of the life of a fictional woman named Jen, a woman who had never married and had no children. In one study, for example, some subjects read a story that described Jen's life as "extremely happy, with enjoyable work, vacations, friends and pleasant leisure. In another version, Jen's life was described as "very depressed and angry, with a monotonous job, no close friends and leisure filled with solitary viewing of television."
While all the subjects were told that Jen died suddenly and painlessly in a car accident, in some accounts five extra years were added to her life. In the positive account, the years were described as "pleasant but not as good as before." In the negative version, the extra time was characterized as less unpleasant than before.
Though the participants in the studies preferred shorter happier lives to to longer, less happy ones, however, Dr. Diener conceded that things might be somewhat different if the subjects were faced with a similar choice in their own lives."When it's tomorrow and you're going to get five more years that are so-so," he said, "you might take it, of course."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Scientists named a phenomenon for James Dean, who died at 24.

HEADLINE: For Japan Sunk in Gloom, No Cheer in Growth Data 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 12 

 BODY:
The Japanese economy sidestepped a recession late last year, according to new figures, but that news failed to dispel concerns that it is sliding toward a crisis brought on by political immobility and a slowdown in its largest export market, the United States.
 The government reported today that Japan's gross domestic product grew 0.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 2000, largely because of surprisingly strong demand among businesses for information technology and telecommunications goods. Government spending and housing were also somewhat stronger than forecast. 
 The figures mean the government will almost certainly achieve its goal of 1.2 percent economic growth in the fiscal year ending March 31. But officials took little comfort in the report, noting that consumption, which accounts for some 60 percent of economic activity here, dwindled in the quarter, and that suggestions of a general downturn are visible in monthly indicators released since then. Machinery orders fell 11.8 percent in January, for instance, and contract rates for condominiums are falling fast. 
The better-than-expected G.D.P. figure also did nothing to cheer the stock market, which was battered to its lowest level since April 1985 after the plunge in American markets on Friday. The benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index fell 456.53 points, or 3.62 percent, to close at 12,171.37 today, and the yen slid in value to 120.52 to the dollar.
Economists said that the strength in business demand in the fourth quarter probably reflected optimistic spending plans put in place before the economy started to cool. Companies like Toshiba, Fujitsu and NEC have pared their earnings estimates for 2001, which will probably lead to curtailed spending this year.
A decline in exports shaved three-tenths of a percentage point off the growth figure, highlighting both Japan's inability to rely on sales abroad to cure its economic woes and the ravages of deflation: export volumes rose, but falling prices eroded their value. "Ultimately, the Japanese economy has always had a large safety net called the U.S. market" to count on for growth, said Ronald Bevacqua, chief economist at Commerz Securities. "At this point, that's gone."
The figures released today are preliminary and may be subject to revisions of one percentage point or more, making gauging the economy's true currents difficult. "The gross domestic product is very volatile, and so it is not always in line with actual economic trends," said Masaaki Kanno, chief economist at J. P. Morgan in Tokyo. 
Mr. Kanno prefers an index compiled by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, showing economic activity basically flat from October through December, down from growth of 0.3 percent in the previous quarter. "I think it is likely to weaken further in the first quarter," Mr. Kanno said.
Japanese policy makers have the same concerns, and are rushing to adjust fiscal and monetary policy and to address the woes of Japan's tapped-out banking system. On Friday, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party proffered its first emergency rescue plan for the economy that did not include plans for expensive public works projects; instead it called for cutting capital gains and inheritance taxes, easing the disposal of bad loans and creating a private-sector fund to buy the stock portfolios of struggling Japanese banks.
Still, the package will be tricky to put into effect given the political atmosphere here. Whether or not Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori resigns next month and is replaced by a caretaker -- Mr. Mori spent the weekend denying that he had signaled such a move, though most analysts here expect it anyway -- the ruling party's main focus over the next few months will be on avoiding a trouncing in elections to the Parliament's upper house in July. 
That goal collides with what is perhaps the most significant plank of the proposed package, the one aimed at a speedy resolution to the debt overhang that has plagued the Japanese banking system since the early 1990's. Encouraging banks to write down their bad debts would almost certainly increase unemployment, which would anger voters already furious over a series of scandals that have plagued the party and over various errors of judgment committed by Mr. Mori.
Winning the cooperation of the Ministry of Finance will also be an uphill battle, because the plan would probably reduce tax revenue at a time when the ministry is determined to reduce Japan's ballooning budget deficit.
"These ideas represent a direction we have not seen before in Japan, but I'm worried about the implementation," Mr. Bevacqua said. "And even if they are implemented quickly, they do nothing more than put a floor under the stock market and economic sentiment. They don't make a recovery."
The Bank of Japan is willing to do what it can to help, but its scope of action is somewhat limited. Short-term interest rates are already so low that there may not be much to be gained by cutting them the rest of the way back to essentially zero, though such a reduction seems likely at the bank's next policy meeting on March 19. Other options for easing monetary policy that bank officials mention include purchasing government bonds, coupling a rate move with a commitment to keep short-term rates at zero until some specified development occurs, and increasing the nation's money supply.

HEADLINE: Ericsson Sees Quarter Loss, Company's First in 9 Years 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 12 

 BODY:
LM Ericsson, the big Swedish electronics company, warned today that it would lose money in the first quarter on flat sales, as demand for mobile phone handsets and networks slowed sharply last month.
 The announcement by Ericsson darkened the mood already hanging over the telecommunications industry, and Ericsson stock fell 25 percent in the United States amid a wide sell-off in telecommunications and other technology stocks. 
 Today's sales and profit forecast was a revision from predictions made by Ericsson just three months ago, and it raised concern among analysts that the slowdown in the mobile phone industry was becoming worse. Ericsson has now added a slackening in demand for phone networks to a list of problems previously centered at its mobile handset division. 
The disclosure of the dismal outlook follows similar warnings by Ericsson's principal mobile phone rivals, Nokia of Finland and Motorola of the United States. And it comes on the heels of reduced revenue or profit forecasts by technology giants like Cisco Systems and Intel.
Ericsson, based in Stockholm, attributed its expected loss in part to the American economic slowdown that is causing many of its customers to reduce capital expenditures.
But the company's troubles are further-reaching. Ericsson also cited slowing demand in Western Europe, as that market nears saturation, and bloated inventory levels worldwide -- problems that may suggest further disappointments for other makers.
"The thousand-dollar question is how long will this process of operators' cutting capital expenditures continue," said Thomas Langer, an analyst with WestLB Panmure. "It raises the possibility of a second wave of profit warnings and lowered expectations for the year."
Kurt Hellstrom, Ericsson's chief executive, underscored that uncertainty today in a conference call with analysts, saying, "In the current unstable economic environment, we have limited visibility."
Analysts had come to expect lagging performance in Ericsson's handset business, where it trails its big rivals. The unit lost $1.7 billion last year, as the company struggled to refine design and supply problems. In January, Ericsson said it would stop making mobile phones, hiring outside manufacturers instead, as a step toward returning the unit to profitability.
By contrast, Ericsson has secured a leading position in the market for building mobile networks, where it is the world leader. Fifty-five percent of Ericsson's sales now come from building infrastructure, compared with 18 percent from selling mobile handsets. Analysts had championed its leadership here, betting that Ericsson would benefit as telecommunications operators begin spending billions on networks to support new services.
Instead, delays in rolling out next-generation technology, coupled with the economic downturn, have cut demand for increased network capacity. Mr. Hellstrom said Americans were spending less time talking on their mobile phones. In Western Europe, he said, telecommunications service providers are finding diminishing returns from subsidies they offer to lure new customers.
"There is less demand in growth in airtime," Mr. Hellstrom said, "and that reduces the need to build out infrastructure."
The broad downturn is now expected to contribute to Ericsson's first quarterly loss in nine years. For the three-month period that will end on March 31, Ericsson said it expected to lose four billion to five billion Swedish kronor ($405 million to $507 million), with sales flat compared with the 2000 quarter.
In January, Ericsson's guidance to analysts was for flat profits and a 15 percent increase in sales. The company is scheduled to report earnings on April 20.
In Stockholm today, shares of Ericsson fell 17 kronor, to 64.5 kronor. On the Nasdaq market, its American depository receipts -- each representing one B share of the company -- fell $2.09 to $6.28 in trading of nearly 40 million units. The A.D.R.'s have fallen nearly 44 percent so far this year.
"It is the rapidity and sheer size of the decline, especially in the infrastructure business which is their bread and butter, that is shocking," said Per Lindberg, an analyst with Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein.
Worrisome, too, is the possibility that telecommunications operators, already burdened with debt from their bids for next-generation licenses, may skimp when it comes to building the networks to support those new services. While a small part of Ericsson's business today, these next-generation networks are expected to contribute heartily to future growth. Mr. Langer said several European operators are discussing ways in which they might share a network, though it is unclear whether regulators would allow such bundling.
Problems are already evident in the much-anticipated technology that provides users with a continuous connection to the Internet, technology that is supposed to feed demand for as-yet-untested services. Mr. Langer now expects these next-generation phones to be introduced in the fourth quarter, as opposed to the current quarter -- a delay, he said, that is sure to crimp Ericsson's prospects.

HEADLINE: Harvard's New President 

 BODY:
Harvard could not have picked a president whose personality is more different from his predecessor than Lawrence Summers, the economist who served as treasury secretary at the close of the Clinton administration. The departing president, Neil Rudenstine, though a spectacularly successful fund-raiser, was a private, soft-spoken man. Mr. Summers is so willing to express strong opinions that for years even his supporters fretted that his bluntness and arrogance offended more people than they persuaded. Yet his formidable attributes make him a fitting choice, especially at this point in history. 
 The precociously brilliant Mr. Summers got his doctorate at Harvard, became the youngest tenured professor in the university's modern history and won the nation's top prize for young economists. His government experience included stints as chief economist of the World Bank and as undersecretary, deputy secretary and ultimately secretary of the Treasury Department. 
 This diverse background gave Mr. Summers a leg up on the other finalists. It could also help make him a strong voice on educational issues that resonate far beyond Harvard. The number of top educators who speak out today seems distressingly small, either because they are swamped raising money and running complex institutions or because they fear offending key constituencies. Richard Atkinson, president of the University of California, showed what can be done by focusing on the inadequacies of SAT exams. Mr. Summers, with his bluntness and familiarity with the public arena, would seem well suited for this role.
Mr. Rudenstine, who raised $2.6 billion and helped drive the endowment above $19 billion, is leaving the university in a very healthy state, so Mr. Summers may have some breathing room before he will need to raise a lot more. His own priorities include improving undergraduate education and strengthening the sciences, two areas where some academics feel Harvard has lost ground. He also stressed the need to recruit younger faculty and maintain diversity. In an era of globalization and the Internet revolution. Mr. Summers hopes to help define how major universities can reach wider audiences without diluting their quality.
Mr. Summers has never run an academic institution. But he has run a department with 150,000 people, and according to friends has softened the sharp edges that irritated some people. His experience suggests he may also have the vision to lead Harvard through an era of global and technological change. 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 21, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 11 and an editorial on March 13 about the selection of Lawrence H. Summers to be president of Harvard referred imprecisely to his achievement of tenure in 1983 at age 28. At that time, he was the youngest tenured professor in Harvard's modern history. But 10 years later Noam D. Elkies, a mathematician, was granted tenure at age 26.

HEADLINE: Keithley Sees Lower Sales and Earnings 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SOLON, Ohio, March 12 

 BODY:
Keithley Instruments Inc., a maker of machines that test semiconductors, said today that its quarterly sales and earnings would be lower than the company had forecast because customers were spending less on new equipment. 
 Keithley's share price plunged $5.81, or 28 percent, to $14.95, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Makers of semiconductors have scaled back production and spending to cope with weakening demand for consumer electronic products as the economy slows. Companies like Keithley, which is based here, and Teradyne Inc., which last week lowered its sales and earnings forecasts, have been hurt as a result. 
"They had order cancellations, and that's why the outlook changed so quickly," said Vincent Glinski, a securities analysts with Jesup & Lamont Securities. "In the long term, the semiconductor industry has to start ordering equipment, but you're not going to see that until August or September." 
Keithley now expects sales of $40 million to $43 million for the quarter which ends March 31 and is the second quarter of the company's fiscal year, according to its chief financial officer, Mark Plush. Keithley previously had forecast sales greater than the $44.5 million the company reported for the first quarter, he said. 
Pretax earnings will be less than the $11 million the company reported for the first quarter, Mr. Plush added. He did not provide a per-share estimate.

HEADLINE: Astronomers See Threat To Research In Budget Plan 

BYLINE:  By JAMES GLANZ 

 BODY:
Astronomers are worried that an initiative buried deep in the Bush administration's budget proposal for 2002 could threaten their ability to do the kind of basic scientific research that has led them to discovery after discovery over the past decade.
 The budget proposal directs that a high-level panel be formed to assess the advantages of radically changing the financing and management of astronomy that relies on ground-based instruments, like optical telescopes and arrays of radio dishes. 
 Rather than leaving those research programs under the umbrella of the National Science Foundation, a federal agency largely dedicated to basic science, the panel would consider the advantages of moving them to NASA. Many astronomers regard NASA as a mission-oriented agency that emphasizes hardware development over the quality of its scientific research, and they fear that their brand of curiosity-driven research, with few immediate practical applications, could be lost in the shuffle there. 
"N.S.F. astronomy has had many extraordinary successes," said Dr. Joseph H. Taylor, a Nobel Prize-winning astrophysicist at Princeton University.
"I don't know why it would be a good idea to rip all that apart and put it into another agency that's not very well organized for supporting that kind of enterprise," Dr. Taylor said.
The move comes after what Chris Ullman, a spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget at the White House, calls "a binge" of recent funding increases for the National Science Foundation that well outpaced inflation. The Bush administration's request would increase the foundation's $4.4 billion budget only slightly, by an amount that would not keep pace with inflation.
As the equipment needed in making astronomical discoveries becomes more and more expensive, Mr. Ullman said, it makes sense to explore shifting the programs to NASA's $14.3 billion budget. "A very independent panel is being named to flesh out the issue and make some recommendations," he said.
The foundation spends roughly $175 million a year on ground-based astronomy, said Dr. Robert Eisenstein, its assistant director for mathematical and physical sciences.
But last year, an influential panel of scientists led by Dr. Taylor and Dr. Christopher McKee, chairman of the physics department at the University of California, recommended that a list of astronomical instruments costing at least $4.7 billion be built over the next decade, which would be roughly a billion-dollar increase over similar spending in the last 10 years.
Most of that money would go to NASA projects like a successor to the orbiting Hubble Space Telescope. The rest would be spent on National Science Foundation projects. 
Dr. Edward Weiler, NASA's associate administrator for space science, said that the administration's proposal took the agency by surprise, but that he saw potential advantages. But he added, "My greatest fear is that a decision is made to put ground-based astronomy into NASA without the dollars and the manpower to go with it."
Dr. Eisenstein said he believed more fundamental issues were involved. "N.S.F. really supports completely unfettered investigations," he said, while "NASA has a more mission-oriented approach."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
 Nasdaq Falls Below 2,000 As Stock Indexes Plummet
Major stock market indexes plunged through several important psychological barriers in a broad sell-off. The Nasdaq composite index, the leading gauge of technology stocks, fell 6.3 percent, dropping below 2,000 for the first time in more than two years. The Nasdaq closed at 1,923.38, down 129.40 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the broadest of the major market indexes, declined 4.3 percent, or 53.26 points, to 1,180.16. It is now down more than 20 percent from its peak last March, meeting Wall Street's definition for a bear market, the first since 1987. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 4.1 percent, or 436.37 points, to close at 10,208.25. All 30 stocks in the Dow Jones index fell. Page A1.

If the bull market of the 1990's is finally over, the bear market that has replaced it is so far a very unusual one because the damage to the stock market has been so concentrated. Floyd Norris: Market Place. A1.

Ericsson Sees Quarterly Loss
LM Ericsson, the Swedish electronics company, warned that it would lose money in the first quarter on flat sales, as demand for mobile phone handsets and networks slowed sharply last month. The announcement by Ericsson darkened the mood already hanging over the telecommunications industry. American depository receipts of Ericsson fell $2.09, to $6.28. In Stockholm, shares of Ericsson dropped 17 kronor, to 64.5 kronor. C6.

True North Reassures Analysts
True North Communications, the seventh-largest agency company, said it was comfortable with estimates by analysts for its first-quarter performance despite the sudden softening of the economy as well as a restatement of earnings. Advertising: Stuart Elliott C8.

Lobbyists Near Bankruptcy Bill Goal
A lobbying campaign led by credit card companies and banks that gave tens of millions of dollars in political donations to members of Congress and contributed generously to President Bush's 2000 campaign is close to its long-sought goal of overhauling the nation's bankruptcy system. Legislation that would make it harder for people to wipe out their debts could be passed by the Senate this week. A1.

Alliance to Develop Diabetes Drugs
Abbott Laboratories and Millennium Pharmaceuticals said that they would pool their efforts to develop drugs and diagnostic tests for diabetes and obesity. The agreement is the latest example of a broad-ranging alliance between a big pharmaceutical company and a genomics company. C7.

Hershey Names a Chief Executive
As part of its continued effort to expand beyond the candy bars that bear its name, Hershey Foods hired a chief executive from the top ranks of one of its biggest competitors in the snack food industry. Richard H. Lenny, left, quit his job running the biscuit business at Nabisco to take the position, adding to a growing list of coveted executives who have departed the company in the wake of its merger with Kraft. It is the first time in its 107-year history that Hershey has gone outside of its tight knit corporate community to find a leader. C4.

New Newspaper Circulation Rules
The Audit Bureau of Circulations finalized the new system governing how newspapers measure and report their circulation to advertisers, overwhelmingly ratifying procedures that will give advertisers more information about who is buying a newspaper and giving publishers more latitude in counting discounted copies as "paid circulation." The new rules, given preliminary approval by the audit bureau's board in November, allow publishers to count as paid circulation any copy sold for a minimum of 25 percent of its basic price. C8.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Workers Vote With Wallets On Job Safety

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
WHEN Congress rescinded new ergonomics regulations last week, Democrats and union leaders said it was a victory for business at the expense of labor. Actually, it was more like a victory for workers' wallets at the possible expense of their bodies.
 Politicians like to pretend that their reforms are rescuing workers from predations of capitalists, but the capitalists generally do not get stuck with the bill. They prefer to pass the costs along, either through higher prices for their products or lower pay for their workers. 
 When workers' compensation programs were instituted for coal miners early last century, the costs of the benefits and premiums were offset by cuts in workers' pay. So were the costs of the parental leave benefits mandated last decade. 
Would workers now take lower pay in exchange for ergonomic safety rules? If you asked workers, especially ones in white-collar centers like New York who are unaccustomed to intrusions from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, a lot would probably object to any cut in salary. 
In fact, many economists would tell you that workers have already made the choice against safety. If they were really willing to take the pay cut, it would presumably make business sense for employers to oblige them. Instead, workers apparently prefer the money, which is why many keep doing risky jobs, like lumbering or fishing, rather than take safer ones that pay less.
But even if the workers themselves have chosen money over safety, are they better off? No, says Robert H. Frank, an economist at Cornell University. He believes that government safety regulations are needed not to protect workers from their employers, but to protect workers from their own individual desires.
Dr. Frank compares today's workers to hockey players in the era before helmets were required. It was rational for an individual player to eschew a helmet, because he felt he could see and play better without it. But the players were collectively better off by being required to wear helmets, because they all avoided injuries without being put at a relative disadvantage.
Similarly, Dr. Frank argues, it's rational for an individual worker to sacrifice safety for income, because he wants extra money to compete against other workers for a better home, better schools, higher social status. But if all the other workers are making the same sacrifice, they'll all have extra money, too, and their competition will drive up the cost of homes and schools and status. 
Collectively, Dr. Frank argues, the workers would be better off taking lower pay in exchange for safer working conditions. The fewer injuries would benefit them all, while the universal diminution in income wouldn't put anyone at a competitive disadvantage.
By that theory, at least, the unfettered marketplace cannot be trusted to provide the optimum level of worker safety. But in practice, can OSHA be trusted to do any better? 
THE new rules, while relatively restrained by OSHA's past standards, still seem designed to enrich legions of lawyers and consultants. They require employers with as few as 11 workers to set up ergonomic programs and keep excruciatingly detailed records. As a veteran of one of these repetitive-stress injuries myself (I got tendinitis from typing), I can see why skeptics worry about the rules' potential for fostering fraud and malingering. The injuries can be so subtle that they are hard to diagnose or treat.
"The science on these injuries is close to junk science," said Robert W. Hahn, director of the American Enterprise Institute-Brookings Joint Center for Regulatory Studies. "Until we have a better idea of the cause and effect of these injuries, and of the benefits of intervening, we shouldn't be issuing regulations."
Cass R. Sunstein, a professor at the University of Chicago Law School who has collaborated with Dr. Frank, has his doubts, too, although he isn't as harsh on OSHA. "This doesn't seem to be a case of crazy overregulation," he said, "though reasonable people can certainly object that the numbers are too fuzzy to justify this particular approach at this time." 
Dr. Frank, while favoring government intervention to protect workers, prefers using some form of taxes (like an increase in the premium for workers' compensation insurance) instead of issuing rules. "When the government tells you how to achieve the desired result, you generally get a mess," Dr. Frank said. "It's better for them to penalize you for not getting a result, and let you figure out how to solve the problem."

HEADLINE: Minnesota Health Plans to Standardize Treatments 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Five health plans that cover almost every resident of Minnesota will announce today that they are supporting standard treatment and prevention procedures for 50 common ailments like lower back pain, high blood pressure, diabetes and bladder infections.
 This is the first time all the major health plans in a state have collaborated to endorse a set of standard guidelines or protocols. Their support represents a major step toward the adoption of national "best practice" medical standards based on recognized scientific evidence. 
 The protocols, which will be continuously adjusted by panels of doctors as new medicines and procedures appear, are available on the Internet (www.icsi.org) to consumers nationwide. The standards do not dictate how doctors must treat patients, but both patients and doctors will be aware of what the recommended treatments are. 
The Minnesota health insurers are endorsing standards that have been developed by 21 physician groups that include 3,200 doctors, 36 percent of all the physicians in the state. The doctors who did the work included staff physicians of the Mayo Clinic, Park Nicollet Clinic and HealthPartners in Minneapolis and St. Paul, as well as five hospitals. 
The health plans joining HealthPartners as sponsors of the new standards are Minnesota Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Medica, PreferredOne and UCare Minnesota, which provides primary care coverage by University of Minnesota doctors for Medicare and Medicaid patients.
The new standards address concerns about patient safety and consistency of care that were articulated last week by the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Science.
In a report published Thursday, the Institute of Medicine urged Congress to commit $1 billion over five years to support projects to improve the health care system and "address both quality and cost concerns." The protocols also emphasize preventive care -- for example, a reminder to a doctor or nurse that a patient who shows up with a knee injury may not be up to date on a mammogram or tetanus shot -- said Dr. Gordon Mosser, an internist who is executive director of the Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement in Bloomington, Minn. The institute is supervising the groups that are working on the protocols and running seminars to help doctors organize their offices to put the standards in place. 
"This is a fabulous development," said Carolyn Pare, chairwoman of the Buyers Health Care Action Group, representing 50 self-insured Minnesota employers with 140,000 employees and dependents. She said the institute's protocols were "the gold standard" for her group. 
"Minnesota has always been ahead of the curve on managed care," said Jim Foreman, managing director for health and welfare at Towers Perrin, the consulting firm. "The rest of the country will sit up and take notice" of actions there.
The Minnesota standards began to be developed several years ago. Dr. Mosser said 20 studies on the standards had been published, including papers that showed sharp increases in the number of pediatric immunizations for 2-year-olds and cost savings for women who were treated appropriately for urinary tract infections. 
Smaller communitywide efforts to spread the use of best-practice standards are under way in other states. "We have seen health plans embrace the idea of community partnership in projects that aimed at a particular disease," said Susan Pisano, a spokeswoman in Washington for the American Association of Health Plans.
In New Mexico, all of the health plans, hospitals and doctors have agreed to use a standard guideline in treating diabetes, she said. "What you see here in Minnesota is taking that to another level, an entire state, 50 different protocols for an entire range of illnesses."
The Chicago Business Group on Health, a group of large employers, is planning to organize communitywide protocols on prevalent diseases. "We've learned that a lot of efforts to establish best practices don't spread," said James Mortimer of the Chicago group. 
Indeed, getting doctors to give up familiar routines and embrace the guidelines was a challenge, Dr. Mosser said. "The health plans routinely want to do this, but the medical groups and hospitals don't trust them. They come to the table warily. They think, 'You are trying to cut my income.' " The institute's approach has been to arrange for groups of doctors to do the work of developing the guidelines. 
Fostering cooperation in other medical communities may also prove difficult. Dr. Arnold Milstein, medical director of the Pacific Business Group on Health, an employer coalition, said, "In most most parts of the country, each health plan is coming up with a different set of quality measures, resulting in a Tower of Babel." 
Dr. John Wennberg, a scholar at Dartmouth Medical School who has been studying variations in medical practice for decades, said the Minnesota standards represented only one step toward reducing medical costs. He said one "huge problem" across the country was that doctors still vary widely in their willingness to perform or not perform nonemergency surgical procedures. 
Dr. Yank D. Coble of Jacksonville, Fla., a trustee of the American Medical Association, said the A.M.A. had posted 2,000 guidelines on treatments for different diseases on the Internet. Because patients rarely have identical problems, the guidelines "are guidebooks, not cookbooks," he said.
Still, most of the cost of health care arises from a small fraction of the diseases, said Uwe E. Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton University. "If you had protocols for 200 of the most frequent problems, you would probably cover 90 percent of the cost," he said. 
Several employers hailed the new standards. Bruce E. Bradley, director of managed care plans at the General Motors Corporation, an active member of the Leapfrog Group of employers trying to improve medical care and rein in health care costs, said: "It's very important that we take the best possible science and processes and get them disseminated. It's the core issue in health care." 
Paula Roe, senior vice president of Wells Fargo & Company, which is based in San Francisco and has substantial operations in Minnesota, said: "As a very large employer, we value the work of the institute tremendously. This is not an issue where we seek competitive differentiation of one plan over another. A best practice is a best practice is a best practice." 
Dr. Robert Nesse, vice chairman of the Mayo Clinic at Rochester, Minn., said the Minnesota institute had "spread the ideas of teams" to improve health care processes similar to those that Mayo has long used internally. 
Dr. Donald Berwick, a Harvard Medical School professor who heads the nonprofit Institute for Healthcare Improvement, said the Minnesota institute was a national leader in persuading doctors to switch to "evidence-based care." He added, "I'm thrilled at any extension of its impact."
