HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
After the Fall

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
The first thing we do, let's kill all the spokesmen. Not really; but officials at both the White House and the Federal Reserve have been making things worse. On one side, we have Ari Fleischer et al. doing their best to spread panic, in the belief that fear sells tax cuts. On the other side, we have Fed officials offering upbeat assessments that, far from building confidence, only add to the sickening sense that the central bank doesn't get it.
 Monday's plunge in the markets was driven in part by more bad corporate news. But it also reflected the market's judgment about how the economy is doing. And despite the partial recovery yesterday, the case for really dramatic interest rate cuts has gotten considerably stronger. 
 Right now we are in a race between the natural forces of recovery and the self-reinforcing forces of contraction. The manufacturing slump that began last year was mainly an inventory cycle: companies produced too much, and then cut back their production in an effort to get rid of the excess. If that were the whole story, the economy would soon bounce back of its own accord. But it isn't the whole story: the manufacturing slump, falling stock prices and a general climate of nervousness are undermining both consumer and business confidence.
The Fed's position has been that the natural rebound once excess inventories are worked off will outrun the decline in confidence, and that confidence too will rebound once there is a clear improvement in economic indicators. Under that scenario, the Fed wouldn't want to cut interest rates too much; cutting rates drastically in the face of merely temporary weakness would risk fueling a future inflationary boom.
But what if declining confidence wins the race? Then the decline in confidence would feed on itself. The odds are that the Fed would eventually succeed in turning things around; but a lot of damage would have been done in the meantime. And there's the small but scary possibility of a Japanese-style trap, in which even cutting rates all the way to zero turns out not to be enough.
Even a few weeks ago the Fed's sunny scenario seemed fairly plausible. But since then a drumbeat of bad news has changed the odds. Numbers on employment have held up pretty well so far, but surely they are a lagging indicator. Given the evidence that consumer spending is starting to fall, and the anecdotal evidence of canceled or postponed business investment, it's hard to avoid the sense that contractionary forces are pulling ahead in the race. And the decline in the markets both reflects growing pessimism and strengthens the case for that pessimism.
I've done a very rough calculation on what Monday's fall in stocks might do to consumer spending. This is real fuzzy math, but it suggests that one day's stock decline might well depress consumer spending more than a whole year of the new, accelerated version of the Bush tax cut would increase it. Which brings us to the question of policy.
It goes without saying that the Fed must cut interest rates next week. And too small a cut will be almost as bad as no cut at all. If confidence is not to plunge, business needs a big rate cut, one that shows that the Fed understands the gravity of the situation.
What about tax cuts? George W. Bush continues to sell his plan as a recession-fighting measure, but his plan is almost perfectly designed not to serve that function. Or as a headline in The Wall Street Journal put it, "Tax-Cut Talk Is Big; Relief Would Be Small." In order to keep down the headline cost of their plan, Mr. Bush's economists delayed most of the big tax breaks until late in the decade. And they cannot do much to accelerate those breaks without making it obvious to everyone that they are planning to raid Medicare and Social Security.
On Monday, former Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin suggested a smaller, "front-loaded" tax cut that would cost far less but would put much more money into consumers' pockets in the near term. This could help a bit more. But the ball is mainly in the Fed's court.
There are times when policy makers should be judicious, when they should resist being rushed by events. This is not one of those times.

HEADLINE: Kmart and Saks Report Drops In Net Income 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 13 

 BODY:
The Kmart Corporation and Saks Inc. reported lower fourth-quarter profits today as consumers, mindful of a slowing economy, reined in spending.
 Most retailers have felt the pinch as rising fuel costs, falling stock markets and news of thousands of job layoffs in recent months have curbed shoppers' appetites for everything from holiday gifts to spring clothing. 
 The discount retailer Kmart reported a 40 percent decline in fourth-quarter net income and said its future sales might be vulnerable to economic weakness as well as disruptions from operating changes in the company. 
Net income for the retailer, based in Troy, Mich., for the quarter ended Jan. 31, was $249 million, or 48 cents a diluted share, compared with $412 million, or 77 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
Kmart's results were a penny above the Thomson Financial/First Call consensus estimate of 47 cents a share, but were hurt by a weak economy and costs associated with efforts to improve store operations.
Net sales rose 4.8 percent, to $11.64 billion from $11.11 billion a year earlier. Sales at stores open at least a year, a crucial measure of performance, rose 2.1 percent.
Saks, the department store operator that runs the Saks Fifth Avenue stores, said its fourth-quarter profits fell more than 20 percent, dampened by increased markdowns to clear racks of merchandise at year's end.
The retailer, based in Birmingham, Ala., said recently that it would not spin off its Saks Fifth Avenue business because of poor conditions in luxury retail.
It said today that its operating income before certain items dropped to $111.3 million, or 78 cents a share, from $142.3 million, or 99 cents a share, in the quarter a year ago.
Wall Street analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected Saks to post a profit of 73 cents a share for the period.
Sales for the quarter rose 4 percent, to $2.12 billion from $2.04 billion a year ago.
Shares of Kmart fell 6 cents, to $9.09, in New York Stock Exchange trading, while Saks shares ended off 20 cents at $12.75.

HEADLINE: Delta Air Lines Now Expects to Post Loss for the Current Quarter 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 13 

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines said today that it expected a loss of as much as $110 million this quarter instead of the profit that analysts had forecast because business travel fell as the economy slowed and flights were eliminated.
 The expected loss, estimated at 70 to 90 cents a share in the quarter ending this month, was disclosed in a letter filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Analysts had forecast a profit of 46 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. 
 Delta reduced flights after some pilots refused to fly on overtime while contract talks continued. The cuts and the decline in the number of high-paying business passengers because of a threat of delays caused by the dispute will cost the company as much as $350 million in revenue this quarter and $250 million next quarter, Delta said. Passenger traffic is slowing as companies reduce costs.
"Fasten your seat belt, it's going to be a bumpy quarter," said Ray Neidl, an analyst at ING Barings. "We knew the earnings estimates were too high."
"The current economic downturn has resulted in weaker business traffic, exacerbated by customer concern over a possible strike by Delta pilots," Joseph C. Kolshak, Delta's director of investor relations, said in a letter dated today.
Russ Williams, a spokesman for the airline, said it was too soon to comment on third-quarter revenue.
Shares of Delta fell $1.64, or 3.8 percent, to $41.46. 
Delta, based in Atlanta, and the Air Line Pilots Association are awaiting a decision from the National Mediation Board on whether they can be released from further contract talks, which could start a 30-day cooling-off period before a possible strike. The board called the two sides to a meeting in Washington on Thursday, the union said.
Passenger traffic at the nation's 10 largest airlines fell 1.3 percent in February compared with the month a year earlier, according to reports filed by the airlines.
Delta obtains much of its revenue from flights on the East Coast, where it faces increasing competition from low-fare carriers like Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways, said Brian Harris, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
Delta is struggling with higher fuel prices that have hurt the industry for more than a year. While fuel prices have fallen from a year ago, Delta's filing with the S.E.C. said its fuel costs per gallon would be 21 percent higher than in the quarter a year earlier.
Jet-fuel prices for delivery in New York harbor have averaged 84 cents a gallon this quarter, compared with 94 cents in the period a year ago.

HEADLINE: Make Russia a Better Neighbor 

BYLINE:  By Anatol Lieven and Celeste Wallander; Anatol Lieven is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. Celeste Wallander is a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
American economic and security interests in the former Soviet Union are fundamentally linked. An economically stable Russia, integrated into the Western economy, would be far less likely to want to damage Western interests or dominate its neighbors, like Georgia, Ukraine and Moldova. Stable and prosperous neighbors would in turn support Russia's new generation of political and business leaders who seek success in the global market through domestic economic reform.
 How could we help build such improved relationships? There is one way the West could help Russia, and at the same time reduce Russian pressure on its neighbors: debt relief. Russia owes $48 billion of former Soviet debt to the Paris Club, the association of creditor nations that includes Germany and the United States. In recent weeks, Moscow has threatened to default on this year's payments and has demanded forgiveness or renegotiation. 
 As the Western creditors have pointed out, Russia's complaints about its 2001 payments are unreasonable. Given the robust state of the Russian economy, the $3.4 billion due this year is well within Russia's budget. By 2003, however, Russia will owe $17.5 billion. Since its entire state budget in 2001 is only $42 billion, it will indeed be quite impossible for Russia to pay at that time. If we insist on the full sum, Russia will default.
Since the West will be forced to renegotiate Russia's debt sooner or later, we should try to get something in return. The most obvious goal should be to reduce Russia's ability to control its neighbors.
Over the past five years, economic pressure, not military dominance or internal subversion, has become the most important source of Russian regional power. Russia is too weak to exert the kind of military pressure it exercised against Georgia in 1993. Furthermore, any direct military intervention would cause Russia terrible damage internationally.
But Russia exerts influence over its neighbors through other means. Georgia, Ukraine and Moldova, in particular, have run up enormous unpaid debts to Russia, mostly for gas supplies. Ukraine owes at least $1.4 billion for gas; Gazprom, the state-controlled Russian natural-gas monopoly, claims that the actual amount is more than $2 billion. Moldova owes $861 million for gas, and Georgia owes $179 million. None of these countries can afford to pay these sums. Indeed, their debt burdens are strikingly comparable to the debt burden on Russia: last year, the annual Georgian state budget was barely $400 million. 
In recent months, Georgia's inability to pay its loans has led to repeated shut-offs of gas, considerably worsening Georgia's already severe electricity crisis. This pressure contributed to the recent declaration by Eduard Shevardnadze, Georgia's president, that his country may drop its (vain) hope of becoming a NATO member and instead aim at neutral status.
In the case of Ukraine, Moscow has sought to swap its neighbor's debt for equity in Ukrainian state-owned industries, which is likely to leave Russian businesses in control of much of the Ukrainian economy. Already, the debt burden has forced the Ukrainian government to agree to unify the Russian and Ukrainian electricity grids.
By international standards, Russian pressure seems fair enough. Why should Russia provide its neighbors with what is in effect heavily subsidized gas and get nothing in return? After all, the West has also told Russia that failing to pay its debts violates international financial rules, and that default would bring Western economic retaliation.
On the other hand, Russia has no right to expect generosity from the West while taking a ruthless line toward its own debtors. The United States and its European partners should therefore offer to forgive Russia all or part of its debt, while demanding that in return Russia act similarly toward the debts of its neighbors.
We could then use this window of opportunity to help these countries develop alternative energy sources -- assuming, of course, that the elites of these countries can summon up enough honesty and competence to move seriously in this direction.
Too much of the American approach toward the former Soviet Union has consisted of rhetorical declarations without real content. By contrast, linking Russia's debt to that of its neighbors would be both very effective and entirely legitimate. It is precisely this kind of practical, sober policy -- rather than empty geopolitical obsessions -- that should characterize our policy toward Russia and, indeed, the rest of the world.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Declined 0.2% In February 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
Retail sales fell 0.2 percent in February after surging a month earlier, government figures showed today. 
 Reduced spending on furniture, gasoline and restaurant food paced the decline, to $274.5 billion last month, the Commerce Department said. Sales rose 1.3 percent in January, almost double the previous estimate. Excluding automobiles, which rose, sales dropped 0.3 percent after rising 1.3 percent in January. 
 While the February level of retail sales was in line with forecasts, analysts expect waning consumer optimism and eroding stock prices to weaken sales in coming months. That is why investors are betting that Federal Reserve policy makers will cut the benchmark interest rate a half percentage point on March 20, the third such reduction since Jan. 3.
Spending "will be slowing as the year goes, and the Fed will want to make sure the economy stays on track," said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. in New York. Still, the two months combined show consumers are "providing moderate support to the economy," he said. In addition to autos, sales of building materials, clothing and medicine increased last month.
Analysts are forecasting a rise in consumer spending in the first quarter of 2 percent to 3 percent, measured at an annual rate. Spending in the fourth quarter grew at 2.8 percent pace, the slowest since mid-1997, and at 7.6 percent in the first quarter of 2000.
February's report showed sales at auto dealers increased 0.2 percent after rising 1.3 percent a month earlier. Sales of cars and light trucks rose to 17.5 million units at an annual pace in February, up from 17.2 million in January, industry figures showed earlier this month. That was the highest sales level since September.
Sales at department stores and other general merchandise stores rose 0.3 percent in February after a 1.5 percent increase in January, the Commerce Department report showed.

HEADLINE: Transportation Chief Supports Fees to Ease Airport Crowding 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
Secretary of Transportation Norman Y. Mineta said today that he favored charging airlines more for flights at the most congested hours as a way to spread out the traffic and cut delays, although that might make fewer seats available at the times most customers want to fly.
 Mr. Mineta, meeting with reporters in his office this afternoon, also said that air traffic delays would recur this summer but that if there were no widespread strikes he was optimistic. 
 "It won't be hunky-dory, but I think we'll be in better shape than last summer," Mr. Mineta said. 
He cited improvements to the Federal Aviation Administration's command center, in Herndon, Va., which since the beginning of last summer has been intensively working with the airlines, hour by hour, to coordinate traffic and reduce delays.
The idea of varying charges to reduce congestion, as is now done on some highways, is now under consideration at La Guardia Airport, which is supposed to submit to Mr. Mineta's department this month a list of ideas that might be put into effect in September.
The aviation agency, which is part of the Transportation Department, has said that whatever is done in New York could also be used at O'Hare in Chicago, Reagan National outside Washington and other crowded airports.
"Congestion pricing," as economists call it, is normally used to flatten out peaks in demand, although at La Guardia the idea would be to drive some traffic to other airports entirely, because the airport is busy from early morning until late evening, and to reduce the number of landings and takeoffs to a level that does not virtually guarantee delays.
"If I were emperor, I'd impose it," Mr. Mineta said.
But given his powers as a mere secretary of transportation, Mr. Mineta acknowledged, the idea's prospects are uncertain.
Airports in the United States have always charged landing fees based on aircraft weight. Recently some aviation experts have put forward the idea of charging a flat fee, which would encourage airlines to use bigger planes, thus moving the same number of passengers in fewer flights.
The airlines, however, have been moving toward smaller planes, offering more frequent service, which may be more convenient for travelers but has contributed to delays at some airports.
Another idea is to fix the number of allowable flights and auction them to the highest bidders, or, perhaps, auction fewer to airlines performing jobs the government wants done, like serving small cities, and the rest to the companies that would pay the most.
Extra money could be used to add capacity elsewhere in the aviation system, or perhaps to buy off the airlines that now have landing rights at crowded airports, aviation experts say.
Mr. Mineta, sketching boxes and lines in blue felt-tip on a white pad of paper as he spoke, said, "I've always been on the capacity side, building runways, building highways, building ports."
But adding capacity to the air traffic system takes years, he said, and "this is one area where maybe we're going to have to do something on the demand side."
Aviation experts say, however, that this might have unintended consequences.
Barbara Beyer, president of Avmark, an aviation consulting firm, said ticket prices on peak-hour trips probably would not change. Those, Ms. Beyer said, are already set by "what the customer will bear." 
"The real impact comes on the low-fare carriers and the new entrants," she said.
Big airlines will spread extra costs over all their customers, she said, while small airlines do not have a huge customer base with which to do that.
"The little guys basically couldn't stand that level of pricing," Ms. Beyer said.
At the Air Carrier Association, a trade association of discount carriers, Edward P. Faberman, who represents the group, said that while raising fees was one way to reduce traffic at places like La Guardia, "you can't base who is going to operate there by who has the deepest pockets."
Mr. Faberman argued, "You can't say to a carrier that wants to put in three round trips a day to one hub that it has to bid against the largest carriers in the world."
Big carriers will bid high for slots they do not even need, he said, adding that "history has shown they will pay any amount of money to keep out competitors." 
Richard S. Golaszewski, a consultant who is advising the aviation agency on how to use economics to smooth out delays, said airlines with national or international systems were likely to bid more. "I think the slots are worth more to a network carrier than a point-to-point carrier like many of the new entrants," he said.
But changing the price structure could send enough carriers to other airports to create new alternatives; in the New York area, for instance, Stewart, near Newburgh, could become viable, and Kennedy International Airport might develop into a strong airport for domestic flights.
Mr. Mineta, in his first meeting with reporters since his confirmation as transportation secretary, also said he did not favor privatizing air traffic control, a step some airline executives have called for as a way to speed modernization.
"To me, safety is a governmental responsibility," Mr. Mineta said. He also said that the air traffic system should be financed by user fees on the airlines, but that the aviation agency could not do this now because it still lacked an accounting system that it could use to figure out its costs. It now hopes to complete such a system by next year.
"I'm really disappointed that it's taking this long to get a good cost accounting system in place," Mr. Mineta said.

HEADLINE: Multiracial Identification Might Affect Programs 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13 

 BODY:
The surprisingly large multiracial response on the 2000 census could have major implications for monitoring and enforcing civil rights, tracking poverty, ensuring racial balance in public schools and providing aid to minorities, sociologists and federal officials said today. 
 Civil rights advocates say the new figures could expand the number of people covered under civil rights laws, but that in turn could increase the number of legal challenges claiming the nation's minority population was improperly inflated. 
 At the Health and Human Services Department, officials responsible for providing health care on or near Indian reservations ponder whether they should plan to care for the 2.6 million people who identified themselves exclusively as American Indians or the 4.1 million people who said they were at least part Native American. 
And the Education Department is already girding to revamp how it tracks pupil enrollment and student progress in reading, writing and science by race. "I can see it gets a little bit fuzzier," said W. Vance Grant, a statistics specialist at the Education Department. 
The new information and the corresponding issues it raises illustrate the consequences of the decision by the Office of Management and Budget to allow people for the first time to identify themselves on census forms as members of more than one race. People could choose from six racial categories, which present a matrix of 63 possible racial choices, compared with 5 a decade ago. 
But the new options mean that data from the 2000 census is not directly comparable with information from previous censuses or with other statistical systems that use the traditional racial categories. 
Roderick J. Harrison, a former chief of racial statistics at the Census Bureau, said tracking vital statistics like birth and death records by race could be skewed if data from both counting systems were intermingled.
"Multiple-race data are going to be particularly hard to collect and collect consistently across different collections systems," said Mr. Harrison, the director of data for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research organization that specializes in minority issues. 
Data from the 2000 census released on Monday produced some surprises. For example, nearly two million black Americans say they belong to more than one race, more than what many government demographers and civil rights officials had projected based on surveys in 1996 and 1998.
Census officials said they were at a loss to explain exactly why 5 percent of black people, or about double what had been expected, said they were multiracial. About half of that group, or 784,000 people, said they were white and black. 
"We really didn't expect that number," Claudette Bennett, the chief of the racial statistics branch at the Census Bureau, said in an interview today. "We just don't really have a good handle on it right now." 
As a result, the Census Bureau plans to survey 50,000 households this summer to find out who identified themselves as belonging to more than one race and why, Ms. Bennett said. She said the survey would be conducted from a nationally representative sample of all races.
Some experts attribute the larger number of blacks identifying with more than one race to an increase in interracial marriages and a greater recognition by younger blacks of their multiracial ancestry. 
And some civil rights advocates, citing the history of race mixing among African-Americans in this country, say the numbers of self-identified multiracial blacks should not be that startling.
"I don't think that's significant," Kweisi Mfume, president of the N.A.A.C.P. "Quite frankly, it's an expression by people of their mixed ancestry." 
In any case, the new data underscores that race is an elastic concept that changes depending on when, how and where you ask the question: What race are you? 
A University of Michigan study in 1995 found that when 20,000 adolescents of all races were asked about their racial identity, about 7 percent said they were mixed race when asked in an anonymous survey at school. But when asked at home by an interviewer, often with a parent present, only 3.5 percent of the children said they were mixed race. 
"Your identity is a dance between what you think you are and what other people think you are," said Prof. David R. Harris, a University of Michigan sociologist who conducted the survey.
Thirty years ago, Professor Harris said, social norms dictated that a person was a minority if he had "one drop" of minority blood in his background. "Nowadays, kids see Mariah Carey, Derek Jeter or Tiger Woods, and they're much more likely to see themselves as mixed race rather than simplify it in the old one-drop way," he said.
As the nation looks at its racial makeup more carefully, the self-examination is taking place family by family. Take Terri Ann Lowenthal's 11-year-old daughter, Joelle, for instance. Ms. Lowenthal is white; the child's father is black. When Joelle was born, Ms. Lowenthal checked "black" for her race on the 1990 census. 
For this decennial count, Ms. Lowenthal, a private census consultant and former staff director of the House Subcommittee on the Census, said the family talked about the issue and left it up to Joelle, who checked both black and white.
Some sociologists and demographers say it may be only a matter of time before the traditional racial classifications lose currency. 
"Over time," said Hugh B. Price, president of the National Urban League, "we may see those categories lose their salience as a more complex picture emerges."

HEADLINE: Hospital Mergers Stumbling As Marriages of Convenience 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
When corporations merge, certain things usually result: a snappy new name, a single person running the show, consolidated departments. A big production is made of uniting the partners, culturally and financially, just as in a marriage of people.
 Except when the partners are hospitals. 
 Several years after merger mania swept the hospital industry in New York and around the country, most major health care institutions that went to the altar appear to have been joined in legal documents and back-room functions only.
Few clinical programs have come together. None of the medical schools that serve the hospitals have been joined. Promises of financial triumph have been largely unrealized. Patients rarely have any idea that their hospital has joined with another, because each has kept its own name. (Quick: What is the other half of Mount Sinai Hospital?) And referrals to the other center are as unusual as egrets in Midtown. 
Hospital executives cite several reasons, generally claiming that full-service hospitals are badly needed in every neighborhood in Manhattan. More fully combining these institutions, they say, could dilute the high quality of care many New Yorkers now expect.
"These places are two major centers unto themselves," said Dr. Herbert Pardes, chief executive of New York-Presbyterian, which was formed in late 1997 by the merger of New York Hospital and Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital. "We want to keep both of the centers strong."
The executives also point to the merger of the hospitals at Stanford University and the University of California at San Francisco, which fell apart after less than two years, when the two centers tried to meld too many operations too soon. As for the financial problems, most blame outside forces.
But the basic reason that hospitals have not merged more fully is that doctors, unwilling to give up power or any areas of care in their hospitals, will not stand for it. And hospitals are one of the few businesses in America in which the employees call the shots.
"If you merge two hospitals, you have a large number of prima donnas who are used to taking orders from no one," said Robert I. Field, the director of the graduate program on health policy at the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia. "While having all of certain procedures in one place might mean higher quality, each hospital still tends to remain a cost and profit center and are not willing to give things up." 
The goal of the mergers -- New York and Columbia-Presbyterian Hospitals; Beth Israel Medical Center with St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center; and Mount Sinai with New York University Medical Center -- was, of course, to save money. 
With managed-care companies slicing away at reimbursements, hospital executives believed the best way to fight back was by becoming bigger. Opportunities to combine certain departments and functions abounded.
Indeed, some money was saved. Behind-the-scenes functions like laundry services and legal departments consolidated. Contracts with managed-care companies have become more equitable, hospital executives and industry experts agree. And little by little, researchers from centers that were once rivals have come together in one capacity or another.
But combining major clinical programs and melding cultures has not happened, hospital executives and staff members agree, and there are subtle signals that some of the hospitals are actually growing apart. 
New York-Presbyterian, for instance, changed a line of its logo recently that referred to the merged group as a "hospital," making it plural again. And the giant board of trustees for Mount Sinai N.Y.U. recently broke apart, with each center getting its old trustees back and a small committee formed to oversee the larger entity. 
"We are really two ships in the ocean, run by the same ocean line company," said Dr. Michael Gruber, head of neuro-oncology at N.Y.U. He and others see missed opportunities, particularly at a time when academic medical centers are in dire financial straits. 
"In a way, I am disappointed," he said. "I would like to be able to offer our brain tumor program to Sinai, and I am sure they have programs that are superior to ours. I mean, what was the purpose of the merger in the first place? To consolidate the laundry or improve medical care?" 
When merger mania hit the hospital industry in the mid-1990's, these and other centers were quick to join in. 
A few scattered programs were brought together, among them children's heart surgery at New York Hospital and Columbia-Presbyterian; the plastic surgery residency programs at Mount Sinai and N.Y.U.; and Beth Israel and St. Luke's-Roosevelt, which came together in 1997 under Continuum Health Partners, now have one chairman of radiology.
Trustees of the hospitals, many of them business leaders, pushed for more consolidation. But hospital executives were quick to point out that in mergers around the country in which clinical programs were combined, many embittered doctors left and programs fell apart.
Doctors in academic medical centers -- large hospitals affiliated with a medical school that combine teaching, research and patient care -- are often not even employed by the centers, but rather have admitting privileges. They yield enormous power because they bring in the patients -- and the revenue. "I work for the doctors," said Peter A. Kelly, chief executive of Continuum. "They don't work for me." 
And many hospital executives fear that if they give up a single department, their status will erode. "If you don't offer full services, you can't train residents fully," said Dr. John A. Kastor, who wrote "Mergers of Teaching Hospitals in Boston, New York and Northern California" (University of Michigan Press, 2001). "But it is also an ego trip, because any hospital that doesn't offer every service is not a real hospital, in its view."
Some health care experts and board members have grumbled, for instance, about the overlap in liver transplant centers at Mount Sinai and N.Y.U. "Board members might say, 'We should consolidate them into one; wouldn't that be efficient,' " said John W. Rowe, who until recently was head of Mount Sinai N.Y.U. "But what will happen is one director will leave and will go to New York Hospital and take his patients with him."
Partners HealthCare System, the consortium of Massachusetts General Hospital and Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, is considered the model marriage of academic medicine. The two came together in 1994, and countered resistance by moving slowly to bring departments together. There are meetings every six months to review strategies and performance, and capital is spread carefully across both centers, said Dr. Samuel O. Thier, the president of Partners HealthCare.
"The pace you come together at is critical," Dr. Thier said. "Whenever we tried to move a little too quickly to centralize something, there were enormous anxieties."
One big point in Partners' favor was that the two hospitals had only one medical school between them (Harvard). There was such fear at N.Y.U. that it would become subordinate to Mount Sinai that some of the N.Y.U. faculty sued to stop the merger, which was consummated in 1998. 
Some bitterness is still evident. When Mount Sinai N.Y.U. announced that it was going to pull apart its boards, some people read, and spread, that the first step in a total breakup was imminent. "If one of us does not show up at a joint meeting, people misread the body language," said Barry R. Freedman, the interim chief executive of the centers. "We have to make sure we are communicating at all times." 
Culturally, the centers seem nowhere near married. Dr. Mary McCord, a pediatrician at Columbia-Presbyterian, said a telling moment came this fall after months of being told she and her colleagues would soon receive red identification tags, (New York Hospital colors) and then were issued blue tags (the Columbia color). "Since then, there seems to be less pressure to try and create a joint culture," she said.
The hospital centers that have merged in New York have so far saved $30 million to $50 million. (By comparison, Partners has saved $250 million.) But each hospital barely broke even or lost money last year, and each has had to lay off some workers and trim budgets. Poor cash flow is often in evidence. The copy machine in Mount Sinai's library sat broken last summer, adorned with a sign explaining that its vendor had not been paid. "We have suffered with our vendors," Mr. Freedman said. 
Beth Israel's bonds fell to junk status over the summer because of cash-flow problems, and the board of trustees bailed the center out by generating $15 million in contributions. 
"If you look nationally, there are a lot of question marks about a lot of mergers," said Bruce Gordon, an analyst at Moody's Investor Service. 
These financial troubles have been brought on largely by factors outside the mergers, including huge reductions in Medicare payments to hospitals by the federal government in 1997 and increased pressures from managed-care companies.
Many hospital executives argue that unified, they have weathered the economic turmoil better. Hospital executives say they have been able to obtain better terms and higher rates from managed-care companies, something managed-care executives concede is true. Both groups are tight-lipped about the amount, but experts put the increases at 5 percent to 10 percent annually. 
"We were a hair away from a divorce with one managed-care company on a Friday afternoon," said Dr. Pardes of New York-Presbyterian. "And then we got a double-digit increase in reimbursement from them."
Mr. Kelly said he believed Continuum would become stronger by taking steps like restructuring its debt and, yes, perhaps merging more departments. "I can't wait, and keep my fingers crossed that the state and federal governments will give us the dollars we need," he said.
In the meantime, some hospitals that flirted but ultimately remained single during the merger explosion have little regret. 
"We were never really convinced that it was the right strategy for us," said Gladys George, the chief executive of Lenox Hill Hospital, which was courted by several hospitals. "We are large enough to offer 99 percent of the services, but small enough to be able to respond quickly to changes in the marketplace." 
One big move: Lenox Hill recently acquired Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, and has moved to, yes, consolidate plastic surgery and ear, nose and throat business.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bankruptcy Bill to Offer Debtors Fewer Fresh Starts
For many Americans whose financial troubles are expected to drive them into bankruptcy next year, the route to a new financial start would be far more complicated under a bill that appears likely to become law.
 The bill, now before the Senate, would overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system and eliminate the concept that many types of debts -- notably credit card debts and other loans that are not secured by a house or anything else of value -- can be wiped out by a trip to bankruptcy court. For many debtors, the idea that bankruptcy offers a new start from their troubles will disappear altogether. Page A1. 

U.S. Bans Animals From Europe
Reacting quickly to evidence that foot-and-mouth disease has spread to France from Britain, the Agriculture Department banned imports of animals and animal products from the European Union. The move was intended to avert an outbreak in the United States of the virulent animal virus. A1.

For Brazil, which has had problems with the disease in the past, some say the chances that the international market will open to more of its beef have grown slimmer despite hopes for a solid year. World Business, Section W.

Delta Predicts Quarterly Loss
Delta Air Lines said that it expected a loss of as much as $110 million, or 70 to 90 cents a share, this quarter instead of the profit that analysts had forecast because business travel fell as the economy slowed and flights were eliminated because of a contract dispute with pilots. The cuts and the decline in the number of high-paying business passengers will cost the company as much as $350 million in revenue this quarter and $250 million next quarter. Shares of Delta fell $1.64, to $41.46. C7.

Suit Accuses MetLife of Sex Bias
Five women filed a lawsuit against MetLife, one of the nation's biggest insurers, accusing the company of sex discrimination in hiring, promotions, pay and job assignments in the company's national sales force. C4.

Generic Version of Drug Ordered
A federal judge ordered the Food and Drug Administration to immediately approve the request of Mylan Laboratories to sell a generic version of buspirone, a popular anti-anxiety drug made by Bristol-Myers Squibb and sold under the name BuSpar. C9.

Test of Blood Substitute to Resume
Alliance Pharmaceutical said that researchers investigating why patients receiving Oxygent, its blood substitute, had more strokes and other adverse reactions during heart surgery than those in a control group who did not get Oxygent have concluded that flawed surgery preparation procedures were the cause. As a result, Alliance plans to resume clinical testing of Oxygent. C4.

Higher Fees Urged at Busy Airports
The secretary of transportation said that he favored charging airlines more for flights at the most congested hours as a way to spread out the traffic and cut delays. A16.

Calm in Crisis Is in Her Blood
JoMei Chang, chief executive of Vitria Technology, an e-business software maker in Sunnyvale, Calif., said the road for her company had been bumpy of late. But she added: "The worse the situation is, the calmer and cooler I get." When she and her husband, Dale, started Vitria, she said, they debated whether to take venture capital financing. "We ended up investing our own money," she said. "I never regretted that." The Boss. C6.

Credit Suisse Profit Increases 11%
Credit Suisse Group said its net profit rose 11 percent in 2000, slightly exceeding analysts' forecasts. World Business, Section W.

Motorola to Eliminate 7,000 Jobs
Motorola, the mobile phone maker, said that it would eliminate 7,000 more jobs as it tries to strengthen its cellular phone unit amid an industrywide slowdown in sales. C4.

HEADLINE: Deserted by His G.O.P., Nassau Executive Won't Run Again 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., March 13 

 BODY:
Tarnished by the fiscal crisis afflicting Nassau County, lagging in opinion polls and abandoned by his fellow Republicans, Thomas S. Gulotta, who has been the Nassau County executive since 1987, announced today that he would not seek re-election in the fall.
 In doing so, Mr. Gulotta became another casualty of the budget crisis that has led one of the nation's wealthiest counties to the brink of bankruptcy in boom times. The crisis has caused credit rating agencies to downgrade Nassau's bonds to near junk, spurred the state to step in with a $105 million bailout and a fiscal oversight board, and left the county's once-omnipotent Republican machine in disarray. 
 Mr. Gulotta, 56, seemed in good spirits as he announced his plan to step down when his term ends, teasing reporters and kissing his wife, Betsy. He insisted that his decision was not influenced by politics. "Without the need to evaluate political considerations, and for personal reasons, I will not seek re-election as county executive," he said, sitting behind his desk in his office here.
Even as he made the announcement, Mr. Gulotta was working to contain a new crisis arising from the county's fiscal troubles. Many corrections officers, upset that a tentative contract was rejected Friday by county lawmakers who were worried that Nassau could not afford it, stayed home from work today, forcing the sheriff to lock down the jail. Page B5. 
While Mr. Gulotta's planned departure was greeted with relief by his fellow Republicans -- who have long considered him unelectable but feared that his $2.5 million war chest would scare off potential Republican challengers -- it was also a reminder of how far the party's fortunes had fallen in recent years. Republicans lost control of the county's legislative branch in 1999 for the first time in more than 80 years, and, more than a year after breaking with Mr. Gulotta, the party has yet to settle on a candidate for his post.
"The fact that he has become so unpopular, plus the fact that his own county chairman had to tell him not to run, plus the fact that there's no obvious person to succeed him -- those three things add up to the death knell of the traditionally powerful political machine in Nassau," said Howard A. Scarrow, a political science professor at the State University at Stony Brook. "That era has certainly come to an end."
And it brought a subdued end to a 24-year political career that Mr. Gulotta seemed almost born into. His father, Frank A. Gulotta Sr., was a popular figure who became the first Italian-American to rise through the ranks and win countywide office, as district attorney in 1949, and who later became a State Supreme Court justice. Thomas Gulotta, who was first elected to the State Assembly in 1976, went on to become the presiding supervisor of the Town of Hempstead and then Nassau County executive. He was undefeated in 11 races.
His popularity plummeted in the last two years, as the county began to run huge deficits, which critics attributed to his budgets. They complained that he spent lavishly on county services while holding down taxes and going into debt to make up the difference -- a practice they derided as Gulotta-nomics.
Almost as soon as Mr. Gulotta made his announcement today, the post-mortems on his tenure began pouring in. Republicans, who have been maneuvering for months to persuade him to bow out of the race, were gracious in victory, stressing their good wishes for Mr. Gulotta.
"While there are those that may take issue with some of his policy decisions, it is clear to me that he wanted what was best for Nassau County," Joseph N. Mondello, the county's Republican Party chairman and a longstanding rival of Mr. Gulotta's, said in a statement.
Judith A. Jacobs, a Democrat and the presiding officer of the County Legislature, said that Mr. Gulotta's "uneven stewardship" helped create the fiscal crisis, but added that he should not take all the blame. "It's important for everyone to realize that he was not a sole practitioner all these years," she said. "He was rubber-stamped by Republicans in many of his decisions."
In the last year and a half, though, Republicans in the County Legislature broke with Mr. Gulotta very publicly. In 1999, when they still controlled the Legislature, Republican lawmakers made a public show of ripping up his budget, and later repealed a real estate transfer tax he had tried to impose to raise $60 million. This January, all nine Republicans in the Legislature urged him not to run for re-election.
The news that Mr. Gulotta has decided not to run is bad news, though, for Democrats running for his seat in November, who hoped he would divide the Republican Party with a bitter, costly primary.
The Democrats, who face a costly and possibly bitter primary themselves, all tried to yoke the Republican Party to Mr. Gulotta.
"The county executive's race is going to be a referendum on 30 years of Republican domination," said Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli, one Democratic candidate for county executive. His rival, Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of Glen Cove, made the same point. "I have said since I first announced my candidacy in January that Tom Gulotta is only the face of the problem," he said. 
Bruce R. Bent, a financier who is so far the only person to express an intention to seek the Republican nomination, said he believed that Mr. Gulotta was simply accepting the inevitable. "The polls were what the polls were," said Mr. Bent, referring to a Newsday poll this month that put Mr. Gulotta's approval rating at just 15 percent.
For months Mr. Gulotta appeared to toy with the idea of running again. He placed ads praising his achievements on television, sent out mailings to residents, lost a bit of weight and joked just last week that he was "in fighting shape." Today, though, he said he had been leaning toward bowing out all along.
He said he regretted that he was not given more credit for the county's drop in crime, its rising home values and its low unemployment rate. And he made an appeal for civility in public life. 
"What we have to understand in public life, and I think I've tried to understand, is that everybody's a human being," he said. "No one is in office to hurt people. You're a human being, you make mistakes, you try to learn from those mistakes, and you do what you can to correct those errors and move ahead. And that's what this administration has been about."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With his wife, Betsy, at his side, Thomas S. Gulotta, Nassau County's executive since 1987, announced yesterday that he would not run for re-election this fall. (Kevin P. Coughlin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Seven-Year Lawsuit; 
Battle Over Monroe Photographs Rips a Family Apart

BYLINE:  By JOYCE WADLER 

 BODY:
Every artist hopes to leave a legacy, and for Sam Shaw, who died two years ago at the age of 87 and had spent much of his life photographing film stars, it was his pictures of Marilyn Monroe. Monroe with Joe DiMaggio or Arthur Miller -- both of whom Mr. Shaw counted as friends; Monroe standing over a subway grate with her white skirts billowing, a shot that would become one of the most reproduced photos of the century, an American pop icon.
 There is another part of his legacy: the $100 million lawsuit Mr. Shaw brought against his son and onetime agent, Larry Shaw, which is still going after six and a half years, an American classic of a different sort: the lawsuit that will not end. A blood feud, nasty as a bad divorce, with sisters against brother, brother slugging a nephew, an 18-year-old granddaughter, in an affidavit, claiming that Larry Shaw's screaming at her grandfather made it impossible for her to study. 
 In the suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in 1994, Sam Shaw charged that his son, who is also a photographer, made deals and pocketed fees without his knowledge, stole photographs, and refused to return them. Sam Shaw also claimed in court papers that he had hired his son as his agent only because he "wanted to support Larry" to keep him off drugs. 
"I may be 82 and he is my son," Mr. Shaw said, "but I decided that I do not want to do anything with my son, who is a crook." 
With Sam Shaw's death in April 1999, his daughters and executors, Meta Shaw Stevens and Edith Shaw Marcus, have taken up the suit. (Larry Shaw was cut out of his father's will.)
At issue are the photos of the Shaw collection, which include, in addition to Monroe, photos of film stars like Sophia Loren and Audrey Hepburn, from the 50's, and of jazz performers, including Louis Armstrong. The Monroe photos, however, are where the money is.
The Shaw story is also the story of siblings, once close, who now disagree about everything: the number of images in dispute (Larry Shaw's lawyer says 15,000 photos or contact sheets are involved; the lawyer for the Shaw estate insists "hundreds of thousands" more images are missing), who took the photos, even the age of the defendant.
Larry Shaw, who gives his age at 63 and sticks by his story (even though his sister Mrs. Stevens suggests he is one year older), accuses his father of "Kafkaesque distortion." He says that Sam Shaw gave him the rights to the Monroe photos in writing, and that the suit came about because his sisters were jealous of his relationship with his father.
"I think once my sisters and the lawyers found out there was money to be made on my father's Marilyn Monroe photographs, the merchandising rights of which had been assigned to me in 1992, that changed everything," Mr. Shaw says in his home in Piermont, N.Y., an old house with a tattered bohemian air, where stacks of photographs dominate the living room and his wife, Susan, and lawyer, Michael J. Marino, occasionally leap into the fray. "It's economics, I think." 
"When he died, my sisters never told me. I didn't find out till two weeks later he was dead. They didn't tell me he was sick in the hospital."
His sisters, in the Manhattan office of their attorney, William S. Greenawalt -- the fourth lawyer to take up their case -- do not deny it. 
"When Sam was in the hospital and had a stroke he called in security and left very clear instructions if Larry was to come they were not to let him in," says Mrs. Stevens, 62, who lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, and, like her sister, spent most of her working life raising a family. "Of course we didn't know he was going to die. But we hadn't spoken to Larry, at that point, for a few years." 
"Over this period of time, Dad would say, 'I'm going to do a kaddish on him,' " says Edith Marcus, 55, with whom Sam Shaw lived in Tappan, N.Y., referring to the Jewish prayer for the dead. "I would say, 'Dad, don't do that.' Then, talking to a relative, I found out he did."
How much the photos they are fighting over are worth is unclear. "The collection, apart from Monroe, does not have a great deal of commercial exploitative value," says Larry Shaw's lawyer, Mr. Marino. He estimates its value at $3.5 million, a figure a curator at the International Center of Photography, Carol Squiers, thinks is high.
Sam Shaw began his career as a photographer in the 1940's, shooting coal miners and farmers for Collier's magazine. In the 50's, he moved to film. He created the photo of Marlon Brando in a ripped T-shirt for "A Streetcar Named Desire." Later, he produced several of the films of John Cassavetes. 
When Sam Shaw met Monroe, on the set of the film "Viva Zapata," she was a bit player who had been hired to be his driver. A few years later, Mr. Shaw designed and photographed the flying skirts shot, for "The Seven Year Itch." Though a number of other photographers were present when the shot was made as a publicity stunt on a Manhattan sidewalk, Mr. Shaw shot Monroe in the pose in a studio and reserved the best position for himself in the street. Mr. Shaw's relationship with Monroe was close. When her marriage to DiMaggio was breaking up, Larry Shaw says, Monroe called his father in the middle of the night for advice. 
Larry Shaw followed his father into photography because, he says, "it was easy." He did, he says, plead guilty in the late 60's to a drug sale charge, for which he received a suspended sentence of three years. He also says he and his wife, Susan, had been "drug abusers" years ago. He portrays himself as a child of the 60's.
"There was a period of a few months, six or seven, where I did a lot of cocaine," Mr. Shaw says. "Then it becomes something where you can't get up, and I just stopped."
He also says he had a serious career as a photographer. In the early 60's, his credits included Look, Life, and Playboy. Sometimes father and son worked together in what Larry Shaw called a partnership. In 1985, according to Larry Shaw, he and his father merged all their photographs into one collection and "at least 25 percent" of the photos were his. Larry Shaw acted as agent for the collection. In 1992, while his father was attending an exhibition of Monroe photographs in Portugal, Larry Shaw requested and Sam Shaw sent a fax assigning his son the rights to "promote, market and publish" his Monroe photos worldwide. 
Sam Shaw insisted in court papers that he and his son had never been partners. Larry had been, in the beginning, his "gofer," his "charmer" -- someone he used to put his subjects at ease. Larry, his father said, in a phrase that rang bitter, "could be a very charming fellow."
"My business relationship with Larry developed in part out of my knowledge that Larry is himself a talented photographer and lighting technician," Sam Shaw said in court papers. "But mostly out of my desire to help him straighten out his life." 
He also said the Monroe authorization was to have been used only during the few weeks he was out of the country.
All agree, however, that father and son fought, particularly over the Monroe photos. The elder Shaw claimed that his son screamed at him if he did not agree to projects; later he was outraged to learn of projects that he claimed he had not approved: coffee mugs, screen-savers, T-shirts, and whiskey bottles of Monroe; other photos on postcards. In one case, Sam Shaw said, his son "threw incredible tantrums."
Her brother tells another story. His father often claimed to know nothing about projects, he said, even after he had signed a business agreement.
Two years after the Monroe fax, Sam Shaw sued Larry Shaw, Larry's wife, Susan, his onetime lawyer, Martin Bressler, and a number of other business associates. (Mr. Bressler countersued, charging that Sam Shaw had brought a frivolous lawsuit with malice, and was later awarded $50,000.)
Over the years, the bitterness has escalated. In 1996, Edith Marcus's son, David M. Marcus, a lawyer who was then 25, tried to subpoena a business partner of Larry Shaw's at a trade show at the Javits Convention Center. Larry Shaw -- who claims he was provoked -- punched his nephew so hard he hit the ground. In 1998, Sam Shaw joined with a group of photographers in a copyright action against several note card and postcard publishers, including Larry Shaw and his son Jakob Shaw, then 24, who had briefly been involved in a postcard business with his father. (The suit was dismissed on jurisdictional grounds.) 
The disputed Monroe photographs and a number of others are now in the hands of a court-appointed receiver, who recently made a deal involving a limited edition of Monroe photos, in a boxed gift set, at $2,400 each, an agreement that could bring $500,000. This might appear to be the sort of thing that would make all concerned happy, but no. 
"We opposed the project," says Meta Stevens. 
"A very low-end project," Edith Marcus says. 
The attorney for Sam Shaw is claiming that some formerly undisclosed Monroe pictures are turning up on posters and calendars in Europe. Meta Stevens claims valuable negatives are still unaccounted for.
In April, the Shaw family is due back in court.

HEADLINE: Empty Billboards Are a Sign of the Times 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The billboard frenzy that swept New York City over the last four years is now leaving casualties from Times Square to East Harlem and down to NoHo.
 In 1997, a single sign could rent for more than $2 million a year in Times Square, making it "the Super Bowl of outdoor advertising," industry executives said. Suddenly, every landlord and developer wanted to cash in. They began putting up billboards and video screens on virtually every available surface in the city, from telephone kiosks and scaffolding to the sides and tops of skyscrapers. 
 But over the last four months, some spaces have gone begging for advertisers. It has become apparent that advertising budgets are shrinking and that the supply of billboards has outstripped demand. Some spots have been left blank, and others languish with outdated ads for movies. 
George Stonbely, president of Spectacolor Communications, a company with nearly 60 signs in Times Square, said prices for some billboards are down 25 percent. "There are new locations at lower rates," he said. There's plenty of room in Times Square for clients who only want to spend a half million a year."
Mr. Stonbely has a joint venture with the Eller Media Company, which signed an $83 million deal at the height of the billboard boom last year that gave it control of 30,000 square feet of signs on the 52-story W hotel at Broadway and 47th Street. Workers are putting up a sign for Absolut vodka, but it only spotlights the many blank spots on the hotel's 300-foot steel signpost. 
At the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and 39th Street, the actress Cameron Diaz smiles down from a billboard alerting moviegoers to the release -- last November -- of "Charlie's Angels." A 12-by-20-foot billboard for AngryMan.com lingered at 106th Street and Second Avenue long after the company closed its Web site. And the three giant billboards that cover most of the 15-story Knickerbocker building at the southeast corner of 42nd Street and Broadway are emblazoned with ads for "Attila," a cable movie that was shown in January.
Advertisers, landlords and sign companies say that the slowdown in the national economy is affecting advertising budgets not just for outdoor signs, but for newspapers, magazines and other media as well. 
The billboard business has also been affected by the disappearance of dot-com companies, which had spent millions of dollars on billboards and signposts in a bid to quickly establish a high profile. 
Internet-related spending nationally on outdoor ads, which had soared to $101 million in 1999 from $13 million a year earlier, was up 50 percent in the first nine months of 2000 before nearly coming to a halt, because of a sharp downturn in the stock market. Many of those companies have since gone out of business.
Still, total spending on outdoor advertising rose more than 8 percent in 2000, to $5.2 billion, according to the Outdoor Advertising Association of America. New York City outpaced the nation with a 16 percent increase, to $290 million.
"There are some blanks and old ads," said Jason Perline, president of Atlantic Outdoor Advertising and a 35-year veteran of the business. "Demand has waned since the first of the year. For the last two years it was a seller's market, thanks to the dot-coms. Right now, there's a lot of wheeling and dealing."
Although billboards and spectacular neon signs have formed a crowded thicket in Times Square since the early 1900's, advertisers and New Yorkers fled what had become a seedy crossroads in the 1970's. Only Japanese companies hoping to raise their profile in this country were willing to put their names up in lights. In an effort to revive Times Square in the 1980's, the city imposed zoning rules that required builders to erect large, flashy billboards on new towers. And when the economy surged in the 1990's, Times Square once again became a dazzling kaleidoscope of commerce and images. Suddenly, Merrill Lynch, Jockey, Cadillac, Planters Peanuts and Absolut put up billboards. 
In 1995, Lehman Brothers bought the nearly vacant 1 Times Square for $27.5 million, just as the long suffering neighborhood was rebounding, and sold it less than three years later for $110 million. The higher price was based solely on its value as a signpost.
Success in Times Square spread to other parts of the city, where signs suddenly proliferated, like in residential neighborhoods, along the West Side Highway and at the Queens-Midtown Tunnel entrance. Signs became so widespread that the City Council recently tried to crack down on the size and placement of billboards, an effort that has prompted at least one industry lawsuit.
Mr. Perline and other executives say the business is in no danger of collapse. The visual clutter of electronic video screens and computer-enhanced advertising images on vinyl sheets will continue, they said. They hope the industry is only going through its customary first-quarter lull. Advertising executives point to some positive indications for 2001.
Certainly, there is no slowdown at the two premier locations in Times Square: 1 Times Square, the 22-story home of the New Year's Eve ball drop that sits at the south end of the crossroads, and 2 Times Square, the tower that marks the square's north end, at 47th Street, Broadway and Seventh Avenue. The buildings are international signposts for television broadcasts and the tens of millions of camera-toting tourists who flow through Times Square every year.
While Suntory Whisky's ad is dropping off 2 Times Square after 33 years, according to one landlord in the area, it will be replaced by another advertiser at a higher rent, about $2.5 million a year.
"The two goal posts in Times Square are doing superbly well," said Jeffrey Katz, chairman of Sherwood Outdoor, which controls the signs on both buildings. "Everything else is the bleachers."
Mr. Katz would not discuss revenues from signs at the two buildings. But executives in the sign business estimate that Discover Card, TDK Electronics, Nissin Cup Noodles, Budweiser, NBC and Warner Brothers collectively pay more than $12 million a year in rent for the signs lining the north face of 1 Times Square. Nineteen large vinyl billboards, including two that are blank -- cover the other three sides of the building and generate millions more.
In the so-called bleachers, at the nearby Bertelsmann Building, one sign has come down and an electronic billboard is going up, with the rent jumping to more than $90,000 a month from about $60,000.
But along the West Side Highway, in neighborhoods north of Houston Street and elsewhere, blank billboards have begun to crop up.
Part of the problem is that in the rush to cash in on the booming billboard business, landlords erected steel superstructures for signs in all sorts of places. There are billboards in Midtown that cannot be seen by oncoming drivers because the signs face the wrong direction.
After years of trying, the landlord at 4 Times Square, the Conde Nast Building, has rented only one of the four 4,900-square-foot ad panels atop the skyscraper, nearly 800 feet above the street. None of the four panels atop the W hotel at Broadway and 47th Street have been rented. Those signs are hard to install and maintain and, while they may be seen in New Jersey, few pedestrians in Times Square can see them.
Mr. Katz estimates that in the last six years, the number of major billboards in the Times Square area alone has grown fivefold, to 250. And, despite the downturn in advertising, more are on the way. "The good news is that the number of signs being built in Times Square is reaching its geometric limit," he said.

HEADLINE: Japan Forms Task Force To Address StockPlunge 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 13 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori of Japan and his political allies set up a task force today to consider emergency measures to put a floor under the country's plunging stock market.
 A rout today pushed the benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index down another 2.89 percent, to 11,819.70, a 16-year low; it has fallen by 7 percent in the last four trading days. 
 More important to government officials, however, was a slump in the broader Tokyo Stock Price Index, or Topix, which fell 2.94 percent today, to 1,170.58. Fluctuations in the Topix, which is less heavily concentrated in technology, media and telecommunications stocks than the Nikkei, probably have a bigger impact on Japan's struggling banks. 
 On Wednesday, the Nikkei edged up slightly and then fluctuated, with a gain of 0.3 percent as of mid-afternoon. 
Stocks are counted in the capital base of Japanese banks, and they make up a bigger proportion of banks' capital now than ever before, said Craig Chudler, an equity strategist at Nikko Salomon Smith Barney. The ratio has been rising because financial institutions here have been writing off bad loans, he said. But contrary to widespread reports, the banks have not been big sellers of stock.
"Net sales of stocks by banks and corporations have decelerated late last year and early this year, compared to the two years previous," said Alexander Kinmont, chief equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo. 
New accounting rules that take effect April 1 require the banks to begin valuing their stockholdings at market prices. As a result, the frail financial state of the country's banking system is becoming yet more dependent on trends in the stock market.
Last week, the government released the outline of a plan to set the economy and the markets back on track, including the creation of a private-sector fund to buy shares from the banks, and various tax incentives aimed at whetting the appetites of individual investors for stock.
But opinion surveys have indicated that Japanese investors are not interested in buying Japanese shares, with or without tax breaks. "If you boosted corporations' return on equity, someone might consider buying stock, but that's a structural issue," said Kathy Matsui, chief strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company in Japan. "They are setting up an emergency task force to deal with structural problems that have been around a long time in Japan, as if they were something like natural disasters."
Ms. Matsui and other strategists say it is a mistake to conclude that Japan's stock market merely reflects moves in the United States. "That's a nice scapegoat, but that's all," she said.
To some extent, the Nikkei's plummeting fortunes can be tied to changes made in the index last April that increased the weight given to technology and telecommunications stocks. Mr. Kinmont said the index might now be as high as 14,500 had Japan's largest financial daily, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, not reshuffled its makeup. "The Nikkei is now essentially not a great deal more than a high-tech index -- like the Nasdaq," he said, "so it's a great fallacy to believe that the global markets have become more correlated.
"What has happened is that the sectors with the highest global correlation that is, technology and telecommunications -- now represent more and more of the stocks in the index."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
MAIL-WELL SAYS QUARTERLY PROFIT WILL MISS FORECAST

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Mail-Well said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would miss estimates because the slowing economy had reduced orders for printing. 
Mail-Well, a commercial printing company that produces brochures and annual reports, said earnings would be 7 cents to 9 cents a share. The company said it had been expected to earn 25 cents. Mail-Well, based in Englewood, Colo., said it had reduced its work force by 5 percent this year as part of a previously announced plan to cut costs. Officials plan to close 11 plants and offices and are reviewing other operations. The company's stock fell $1.41, or 22 percent, to $5.04.

HEADLINE: Yeshiva U. President to Quit After More Than 25 Years 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Norman Lamm, the president of Yeshiva University in Manhattan for the last 25 years and one of the longest-serving university presidents in the United States, announced yesterday that he would step down in August 2002. 
 Dr. Lamm, 73, is the third president of a New York research university to announce his resignation this month, following George Rupp at Columbia and L. Jay Oliva at New York University. 
 "I didn't want to be carried out feet first," Dr. Lamm said in an interview yesterday. "I always wanted to finish my tenure at the top, the acme. The university has reached a pinnacle of its development. It has further to go, but I feel I am leaving it in good shape."
Dr. Lamm's resignation opens the question of the future religious tilt of Yeshiva's colleges and its theological seminary, which have long embodied the tenets of modern Orthodox Judaism -- a philosophy based on the integration of traditionally rigorous Judaism and modern culture. In recent years, the colleges have been pulled toward stricter forms of Orthodoxy.
"It's been a matter of speculation and a great deal of concern that it will be very hard to find a modern Orthodox successor to Dr. Lamm," said Rabbi Irving Greenberg, president of the Jewish Life Network, an educational foundation in New York, who is associated with the modern Orthodox movement. He is also chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.
Robert M. Beren, the university's chairman, said the university did not plan to change direction. "This university is the world center of modern Orthodoxy and that's where we intend to stay," he said yesterday.
Dr. Lamm was the first American-born president of the 115-year-old university, which started as a day school for boys on Manhattan's Lower East Side and today is an independent, secular university under Jewish auspices centered on 185th Street in Washington Heights, one of its four campuses. 
He assumed leadership of the university as it teetered on the brink of bankruptcy and gradually nursed it back to health. As at other universities, economic prosperity and strong financial markets in the 1990's have significantly bolstered Yeshiva University's finances. Its endowment is now $875 million, up from about $25 million in the 1970's and more than double what it was in 1995. 
Today the university has 6,600 students and more than 1,000 faculty members spread among 17 schools and affiliates, including Yeshiva College (the undergraduate college for men), Stern College for Women, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, the Sy Syms School of Business and the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, a rabbinical seminary. Its undergraduates spend half their day in Judaic studies and half in traditional university studies, in the arts and sciences or in business.
Mr. Beren said the board of trustees would conduct an international search for a successor and Dr. Lamm "will continue to play a major role in defining the priorities of the university and the Jewish community."
The trustees voted yesterday to make Dr. Lamm chancellor when he steps down as president. 
Dr. Lamm was a Yeshiva University student himself, a chemistry major who graduated summa cum laude and was class valedictorian in 1949. He pursued graduate work in science at Polytechnic Institute in Brooklyn for a year while he continued his religious studies and preparation to become a rabbi at Yeshiva, where he earned a Ph.D. in Jewish philosophy. He subsequently joined the Yeshiva faculty.

HEADLINE: Two Comptroller Candidates Try to Make No. 3 Job Visible 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
On an almost daily basis, the two Democratic candidates for New York City comptroller wander from one political function to another, hoping to entice any who will listen to pay attention to the race for the city's No. 3 job.
 Over three recent days, Councilman Herbert E. Berman took his quest to a civic association dinner in Queens, a church organization dinner in Brooklyn, appearances before political clubs and an interview by the Working Families Party. 
 In those same three days, William C. Thompson Jr., Mr. Berman's opponent in the Sept. 11 primary, had a similarly hectic schedule. Mr. Thompson, the president of the Board of Education, attended a women's political breakfast, a meeting of a political club in Harlem and a church service in Brooklyn. 
"Since we're not mayoral candidates, the hard job for us right now is to get noticed," Councilman Berman said. "So you try to get yourself invited to as many functions as possible. There is an exotic, interesting sense around the mayoral race and mayoral candidates. To most people, everyone else is an afterthought."
The city comptroller regularly performs audits of the city budget and makes budget recommendations, as well as approves all city contracts. The annual salary is $160,000. No Republican candidate has materialized, so a victory in the primary is considered tantamount to a victory in the general election.
The two Democrats are prepared to wage a vigorous campaign. Mr. Berman, a 26-year veteran of the City Council and the chairman of its Finance Committee, has already demonstrated considerable fund-raising might, having secured more than $1 million in campaign contributions.
Mr. Thompson has raised only $500,000. But he plans to resign from the board April 1 -- an ethics ruling prohibited him from raising money while holding the post after that date -- and the change will enable him to concentrate more on fund-raising. He has hired Suri Kasirer, a prominent Democratic consultant, to help his campaign.
"I got a late start," Mr. Thompson said. "But now we are focused on it, and I don't think raising money will be a problem." 
The comptroller's race is the only one with just two candidates in the primary. (There are now four Democratic candidates for mayor and five for public advocate.) "It is the race that is likeliest to become nasty," said Jeffrey B. Plaut, a partner at the Global Strategy Group, a political consulting organization.
Mr. Plaut said Mr. Berman would probably seek to put together the kind of coalition that elected Rudolph W. Giuliani mayor in 1993: a swath of white voters in boroughs outside Manhattan. He added that Mr. Thompson, who could be the only black candidate for citywide office, would seek to resurrect the coalition that elected David N. Dinkins mayor in 1989: black, Hispanic and liberal white voters.
The candidates, however, disagree with the suggestion that the race could turn nasty, although they expect it to be heated. "We like each other," Mr. Berman said. "We are friends."
The two Democrats were both born and raised in Brooklyn and have deep roots in the borough's politics. Mr. Berman, 67, grew up in Brighton Beach and Coney Island. He is a lawyer who worked alongside Anthony J. Genovesi, the Brooklyn political leader who ran the Thomas Jefferson Democratic Club.
Mr. Thompson, 47, who grew up in Bedford-Stuyvesant, is the son of William C. Thompson Sr., a prominent Democratic councilman and state senator who recently retired as an appellate judge. The younger Mr. Thompson was an aide to Representative Frederick W. Richmond, a Brooklyn Democrat, then a deputy to Howard Golden, the Brooklyn borough president, who appointed him to the Board of Education in 1994.
While the campaign is just beginning to take shape, the candidates have been busy traveling the city and stressing their bona fides in fiscal management. Mr. Berman emphasizes his leadership of the City Council's Finance Committee and his experience with and grasp of the city's budget. Mr. Thompson discusses his years as a senior vice president in the New York office of George K. Baum & Company, a brokerage house based in Kansas City, Mo.
The two stress vastly different themes in their budding campaigns. Mr. Berman, for example, talks about the need for a comptroller who understands the city's budget process, particularly in light of expectations of a large turnover in Council members.
"As a consequence of term limits," Mr. Berman said, "there will be such a big upheaval in the government that we will need someone as comptroller who is experienced and a source of competent oversight of the budget."
Mr. Thompson discusses the need to make the comptroller "an activist." He said it was important for the comptroller to find ways "to continue to influence policy in this city, to use pension funds to supplement and improve economic development, to provide housing."
"How the comptroller uses his voice," he said, "can help determine the direction of this city."
