HEADLINE: OPEC Is Expected to Announce Reduction in Output of Crude 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE

 BODY:
Hoping to shore up declining oil prices, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to announce a reduction of daily output by 700,000 to one million barrels, or about 3 percent to 4 percent, when it convenes today in Vienna, industry analysts said. 
 But coming at a time of falling industrial activity and rising consumer nervousness in the United States and elsewhere, OPEC's gamble may backfire, analysts warned, if a sharp increase in oil prices sinks the shaky world economy. 
 "There are two things that make the environment extremely unstable: the global economy and low inventories of petroleum products, and that makes any forecasting extremely uncertain," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist with economy.com, a research organization in West Chester, Pa. "The surge in energy prices over the last two years is the most important reason the U.S. economy has hit the wall." 
OPEC hopes to keep the price of oil at $25 to $30 a barrel, a level, it contends, that will not damage the world economy. With the global outlook clouded by conflicting indicators, what OPEC's members apparently have fixed on is the gradual slide in demand for oil. Their concern is that if they continue to export at current levels, there might be a glut of oil and prices would fall. 
OPEC, which produces 40 percent of the world's oil, tracks a basket of oil prices from various commodities markets that has slipped recently to $23 to $24 a barrel. The countries of the 10-member cartel are almost wholly dependent on oil revenue, and they fear that if prices drop further, their own economies will be badly hurt.
After raising production in 2000, OPEC cut output in January by 1.5 million barrels a day, or 5 percent, to bolster prices. Some members that usually lobby for higher prices have called for another cut of 1.5 million barrels. Besides wanting to keep prices high, the so-called price hawks contend that the American economy is not so frail and that demand could rebound.
But Saudi Arabia, the de facto leader of OPEC and its most powerful moderating force, would like to see a smaller cut in production. As a result, most analysts say that OPEC will agree on a cut of 750,000 barrels to 800,000 barrels a day.
"The risk they run is that they will cut too much," said Roger Diwan, a managing director for the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting firm. "So the Saudis don't want to cut too much, because the cuts will hit just as refining kicks into high gear in May for the U.S. gasoline market."
Indeed, some analysts argue that OPEC is misinterpreting economic and industry signals. Worldwide demand has slowed, they note -- but it is still rising, not falling. Although the slackening of the world economy certainly contributes to that reduced demand, appetite for oil traditionally wanes a bit in the second quarter of a year as refiners build inventories of crude and shift production from heating oil to gasoline.
Low supplies of oil last year, a result of OPEC production cuts in 1999, helped drive up summer gasoline prices in the United States. Then, a booming economy sheltered most consumers and businesses from the pain of high fuel prices. But with a weaker economy this year, Americans may feel the pinch.
"Refining is starting to build now, and they're going through their stocks of oil at a fair pace," said Leonidas P. Drollas, chief economist for the Centre for Global Energy Studies in London. "The danger is that the U.S. can go through the same cycles as last year. And if OPEC decides to increase output this summer, it will be too late."
Substantially higher oil prices would add to the burden on consumers already paying high prices for natural gas and electricity. The cost of natural gas has more than doubled since last year, and because many power plants run on gas, electricity bills have gone up sharply, too. 
"Natural gas, electricity and oil are all now coming at us," said Stephen Thumb, a principal with Energy Ventures Analysis Inc., a Washington consulting firm. "It really starts to become a pocketbook issue. Without the stock market there, you'll have a 1-2-3 punch."
Of course, OPEC's members may soften the blow of any export reductions they announce. Cartel members routinely, albeit unofficially, overproduce to cash in on high prices. For example, analysts estimate, January's announced cut of 1.5 million barrels a day translated, in reality, into 900,000 to 1.1 million barrels less production. An announced cut of 750,000 barrels may take about 500,000 barrels out of production. 
Indeed, if the price of oil keeps falling despite OPEC's move, overproduction may become rampant. "OPEC has the best management capability in many years to shore up prices," said Gary N. Ross, head of the PIRA Energy Group, a consulting firm. "They're very scared of it breaking down. Any lack of success in shoring up the price will lead to a deterioration of their unity."

HEADLINE: A Tale of Two Bubbles. Could This One Be Painless? 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
'WE have a strong economy, long term," Richard C. Koo was told this week on his visit to New York. "This is a temporary slowdown."
 For Mr. Koo, an American economist who has worked in Japan since 1984 as the chief economist of the Nomura Research Institute, the confidence he heard brought back memories of Tokyo's days of glory. "A lot of things that are being said in this country now were being said in Japan 10 years ago," he said in an interview. 
 The bubble that burst in this country last year was nowhere near as large as the one that burst a decade ago in Japan. Theirs affected the entire stock market, plus the property market and nearly everything else the banks accepted as collateral for loans. Ours was large, but concentrated in a part of the economy. There is no reason to think that a decade from now commentators will be mocking our inability to recover.
But the American bubble was real, and its bursting will have consequences. There was economic strength, but some of it came from excessive investment in certain industries, and from the spending of the profits, real and anticipated, that came from the boom. Now the money borrowed, either to finance wasted investments or in expectation of wealth to come, will have to be paid back. That will take time. Tax and interest rate reductions will help, but are not magic potions.
In the year before the Japanese bubble burst, the export-oriented Japanese economy seemed to be untroubled by the fact the yen had soared in value. "Japan looked so strong," Mr. Koo said. "After the bubble burst, we came to realize it was bubble-driven economic demand that made the economy so strong."
Many still deny that the end of the bubble is a fundamental change for the American economy. Companies and investors expect their stocks to recover. The economy may be down, but surely that is just an inventory correction that the Federal Reserve will be able to fix in a quarter or two.
It won't be that easy. By the time the economy really hits bottom, there is likely to be talk that the Fed has failed, is "pushing on a string." Companies are starting to take serious steps to cut expenses, but that process is not far along, in part because the profit squeeze that began with the technology companies is only beginning to spread.
After the corporate sector begins to be really worried, consumers fearful of layoffs are likely to do the same, further damaging profits as they cut back on purchases.
The stock market is likely to begin its recovery before the economy does, and to some this week's two really bad days have the feel of the long-awaited capitulation that signals a bottom. But even if that is the case, it is hard to believe that the old days of 20-percent-a-year gains will return. The biggest beneficiaries of the bubble are not likely to come back all the way, said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, "any more than land of the Imperial Palace in Tokyo will again be worth more than the state of California." Yahoo shares are not going to $200 again. Nor will government tax receipts continue to be swollen by stock option profits and capital gains. 
A decade ago there was widespread confidence that the Japanese economy would remain strong, even if there was a temporary problem after stock prices fell. Now the pessimism on Japan is overwhelming, while a quick American recovery is expected. But the lesson to be learned from Japan's woes is not that it will never recover; it is that bursting bubbles can have surprising effects.

HEADLINE: Account Deficit Hit Record $435 Billion in 2000 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15 

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit in goods, services and investments widened in the fourth quarter, pushing the shortfall for 2000 to a record $435.4 billion, government figures showed today.
 The shortfall, known as the current account deficit, is the broadest measure of trade because it incorporates financial transactions. 
It grew to a record $115.3 billion in the fourth quarter after widening to a revised $113.1 billion in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said. 
 The fourth-quarter increase resulted from a rise in imports and a drop in exports. At the same time, overseas investors earned less on their United States holdings than Americans earned abroad.
The shortfall represents money the United States has to borrow overseas to pay for all the goods and services Americans import and to finance investment not covered by savings. The annual deficit amounts to about 4.4 percent of the almost $10 trillion gross domestic product, up from about 3.6 percent of G.D.P. in 1999 and 2.5 percent a year earlier.
Analysts expected a fourth-quarter deficit of $117.7 billion after a previously reported shortfall of $113.8 billion in the third.
The deficit in merchandise trade expanded in the fourth quarter as imports fell 0.1 percent, to $315.4 billion. A drop in automotive products exceeded an increase in consumer goods and industrial supplies, the government said. Goods exports fell 1.9 percent, to $197.1 billion.
Trade in services posted a larger surplus, as exports rose 0.8 percent, to $75.2 billion, and imports rose 0.5 percent, to $55.8 billion. The export increase was largely a result of travel and payments of royalties.
Income on overseas assets held by Americans grew to $89.1 billion from $86.8 billion. Foreign earnings on American assets fell to $88.2 billion from $89.9 billion.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Blue Chips Recoup Some Losses; Technology Shares Fall

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN

 BODY:
Blue-chip investors won a modest reprieve from the week's heavy selling yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average nudged back above 10,000, helped modestly by sharpening hopes for an interest rate cut next week. Technology shares, though, were lower.
 Analysts were divided over whether the stock market had shown its worst. Many were looking to the Producer Price Index for February, to be released today, for a further indication of how aggressively the Federal Reserve might cut rates at its meeting on Tuesday. Until the stock market fell sharply twice this week, many on Wall Street had expected a half-point reduction, but some are now talking about a cut of three-quarters of a percentage point. 
 "What you're seeing," said Jonathan Glaser, a hedge fund manager at JMG Capital Partners, "is some optimism over the Fed coming to the rescue here and people trying to find some bargains. It's very quiet, at least for the moment. I think we're on hold."
The possibility of a bigger rate cut sent investors toward interest-rate-sensitive stocks yesterday, like those of banks and utilities, said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer of Wells Capital Management.
The Dow industrials rose 57.82 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,031.28, rebounding from a drop exceeding 3 percent on Wednesday that resulted in its closing below 10,000 for the first time in five months.
The Dow picked up part of its strength from financial stocks like Citigroup and American Express, which recouped some of their losses on Wednesday after new questions emerged about the stability of Japanese banks. A 2.6 percent gain in Japanese stocks yesterday infused American investors with a small dose of optimism. 
Citigroup rose $1.50, to $46.40; American Express gained $1.32, to $39.80, and J. P. Morgan Chase was up $1.51, to $45.26.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 6.85 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,173.56.
But sharp declines in Intuit and Oracle weighed on technology stocks. The Nasdaq composite index fell by a further 31.38 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,940.71, after a modest rally in the morning. Market breadth on Nasdaq was negative.
After a plunge on Monday, stocks rebounded somewhat as they attracted bargain hunters on Tuesday. "Over the last several days, you have seen at least the beginning of a rotation into some of the beat-up technology companies," said William V. Fries, manager of the Thornburg Value Fund. 
Underlying the market's recent performance are concerns over the weakening American economy and a continuing series of warnings of disappointing corporate financial results. "Clearly, the market knows the next couple of quarters are going to stink," Mr. Glaser said. "The major question is whether we'll see some turnaround later in the year for earnings, or whether we're in a protracted period of low growth or no growth for some of these companies."
Given the prospects for another interest rate cut and the amount of cash on the sidelines, Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at SG Cowen, said he was somewhat surprised that stocks had not rebounded more strongly. "The market's still treading water here," he said. "This is a very anemic rally."
Among technology stocks, Intuit, which makes personal finance software, fell $12.63, or 29.9 percent, to $29.63 after it cut its third-quarter and 2001 sales estimates, though it said it was still comfortable with profit projections.
Oracle dropped $1.38, to $14.69, ahead of its earnings report. After the market closed, Oracle reported that third-quarter profit rose 15 percent, matching forecasts that had been lowered two weeks ago after the company said the sluggish economy was cutting into its software sales. --------------------

Treasury Prices Mixed
By Reuters
Treasury prices were mixed yesterday as investors hopd for an aggressive rate cut by the Federal Reserve next week.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 10/32, to 101 23/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.78 percent from 4.82 percent on Wednesday. The 30-year Treasury bond fell 3/32, to 101 17/32. Its yield was unchanged at 5.27 percent.

HEADLINE: Goodbye to Mr. Hello and Goodbye 

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF

 BODY:
Robert E. Mitchell will retire on March 29. He will take his belongings and his doorman's pension and go back home to New Orleans, where he plans to grow old on the front porch with his relations.
 No one need apply, as Mr. Mitchell's job was filled just days after he announced his retirement. "That's the way it goes," he said at 4 one afternoon as he dragged his broom and dustpan around the perimeter of 801 West End Avenue, a pre-World War II building with 70 apartments on the west side of the avenue between 99th and 100th Streets. "Time moves along and things are forgotten. Including the memories of you." 
 There are, after all, 8,000 doormen in the city, according to the Service Employees International Union. And maybe the new guy will make the residents of 801 forget that for 33 years, Mr. Mitchell was the man who mopped their hallways and shoveled their snow. Or that he was the man who took their children by the scruff of the neck when he saw them doing wrong. Or that he was the man who ran down the wig-wearing mugger who attacked their mother. Or that he was the man who discovered their dead locked away behind the doors.
But it seems unlikely, if the card the 6-year-old girl gave him the other day is any indication. "I love you. Please don't go, Robert," it read.
Nearly every block in New York has its mayor. Some acquire the title through milk crate endurance, passing away the hours in the same spot on the same corner, becoming such a fixture and spectacle that people just start calling out, "Hey Mayor." But others earn it by giving of themselves.
"He was my second father after my father moved away," said Beck Lee, 40, who grew into a man in Apartment 1B. The neighborhood was tough in the 60's and 70's, Mr. Lee said. Schoolchildren were robbed so often that fathers gave their children broken watches and expired bus passes to give the muggers. 
But the children developed their own method of self-defense. They learned to stall, pat their pockets and wait for Mr. Mitchell to catch sight of the larceny from his perch near the building's column.
In the 70's, there was a parade of fathers who packed their bags and walked out through the marble foyer for the last time. Mr. Mitchell was there to help them with their bags. And he was there to help the women put a fresh coat of paint in their apartments and move their furniture around. He was there to teach their kids the curveball. He was, Mr. Lee said, a surrogate man of the house.
Mr. Mitchell cut a handsome figure in his gray uniform with white piping. He wore a colorful sweater, a threadbare tie and smooth hair the color of the uniform. At 65, he is thin and stands erectly. When the neighborhood started changing in the 80's, and the silk-stocking crowd moved in, they asked him to wear a hat. He refused. He has never worn a hat on the job and is proud of it. They do that on the East Side. He's a West Side doorman.
"I opened this door so much they'd run out of numbers if they attempted to calculate it," he said, standing in the cold foyer in thin shoes and no coat. "I'm going to miss this building. It's been my whole life for half my life."
Sept. 28, 1967, was the beginning of that life. That's when the unemployment office sent him to the building's superintendent. "The super told me, 'If you like it, you've got the job for life,' " he said. "I been here ever since."
The true gentleman never insinuates himself into other people's business, Mr. Mitchell said. He keeps to his own, never talks about things unless asked and never talks about people in the building, period. 
"Which doesn't mean I don't know what's going on," he said. "I know just about everything that goes on around here. If I didn't, I wouldn't be a good doorman."
Maybe the people of 801 West End Avenue will forget him, he said. But he'll be thinking of them on his porch down in Louisiana.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Compaq to Cut 5,000 Jobs; Earnings to Come Up Short
Compaq Computer said that it would cut 5,000 jobs and predicted that its first-quarter per-share earnings would be about one-third lower than expectations.
 Analysts said the announcement underscored how long it might take the sector to recover from the slowdown in consumer buying and corporate capital spending. Page C6. 

Oracle met lowered earnings estimates but said its fortunes could worsen. C8.

Senate Approves Bankruptcy Bill
The Senate voted 83 to 15 to approve a bill that would overhaul the nation's bankruptcy laws and make it harder for people to erase their debts. The House has passed a similar bill, and President Bush has signaled that he will sign whatever compromise is reached in a House-Senate conference committee. A1.

UAL and AMR Warn About Results
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, warned that a decline in passengers amid a weakening economy would hurt their first-quarter results more than expected. Investors seemed to take the news in stride after earlier warnings from other carriers. AMR rose $1.73, to $34.54. UAL climbed $1.45, to $36.55. C7.

OPEC Is Expected to Reduce Output
OPEC is convening today in Vienna and is expected to announce a reduction of daily output of 3 percent to 4 percent in an effort to shore up falling oil prices. The move could backfire, analysts warned, if a sharp increase in oil prices sinks the shaky world economy. C5.

Dow Nudges Back Above 10,000
Blue-chip investors won a modest reprieve from the week's heavy selling as the Dow Jones industrial average nudged back above 10,000. The Dow rose 57.82 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,031.28. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 6.85 points, to 1,173.56, while the Nasdaq composite index slipped 31.38 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,940.71. C8.

The stock market's shrapnel is spraying all over York, Pa., an industrial town, just under 200 miles from Wall Street. A1.

Nokia Quarterly Profits Are Flat
Nokia said first-quarter profits would be about the same as a year earlier, even though sales of its mobile phones are falling short of expectations. World Business, Section W.

Ex-Labor Official to Lead Coke Panel
Alexis M. Herman, the former labor secretary, will be the chairwoman of a seven-member panel that will oversee Coca-Cola's diversity efforts. The panel was created by the terms of a settlement of a class-action discrimination suit against Coke and has the power to make binding recommendations about how the company hires, promotes and evaluates employees who are women or minorities. Ms. Herman represents the tie-breaking vote. C7.

The Past Repeats Itself in Japan
A strong sense of the past repeating itself hung over Japan, as policy makers scrambled to brake a falling stock market and revive the flagging economy. The government appeared poised to once again use public funds to prop up stocks, two years after swearing off such interference. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Bill Tightens Rules For Businesses 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS

 BODY:
Most of the proposed changes in the bankruptcy bill passed by the Senate yesterday concern individuals, but the new rules for corporations could ultimately affect far more people.
 The revised law would give faltering businesses less time to settle their debts and reorganize. The changes, intended to prevent companies from languishing in bankruptcy court, could force more small companies out of business, even supporters of the bill say. And critics say the result may be a loss of jobs at a time when the employment outlook is already weakening. 
 The bill would define small businesses as companies with debts of $3 million or less. Such companies account for more than 80 percent of the 9,000 companies that filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code last year, according to the National Bankruptcy Conference, a nonpartisan group of academics, judges and lawyers that has studied changes to the bankruptcy law since the 1930's.
The proposed legislation would set strict timetables for small companies to reorganize, including a deadline of 175 days for a court confirmation of a bankruptcy plan if there is no organized creditors' group monitoring the case.
Some judges now put companies on such a fast track but are willing to be flexible if a company needs extra time, because of seasonal business swings or other factors.
Companies that cannot meet the deadline will have their cases dismissed or be pushed from Chapter 11, which is intended to give them time to get their house in order, into Chapter 7, which forces them to liquidate their assets.
"Here we are on the precipice of a serious recession," said Elizabeth Warren, a professor at Harvard Law School and an expert on bankruptcies. "Why would you be pushing for liquidation of companies at a time like this?"
The proposed deadline and certain other provisions affecting corporations have been opposed by academics and lawyers as well as union officials who are worried about their members' jobs. Last year, companies with an estimated two million workers filed for bankruptcy, while 1.2 million individuals filed, Professor Warren said.
Damon Silvers, associate general counsel of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said, "The bill contains a group of rather technical provisions that we think damage the ability of the bankruptcy system to preserve companies as going concerns."
Small businesses generally owe relatively small sums, and typically no creditors are actively lobbying to get their money back. As a result, many of these companies now linger in Chapter 11 rather than speedily dispensing with their debts.
Supporters of the bill say the changes are necessary to preserve the rights of creditors. "Normally, it takes two to three years before creditors see a dime," said Judge Edith H. Jones of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in Texas. "Time is money."
Judge Jones, one of the biggest supporters of the small-business changes, served on a commission set up by Congress in 1994 to make recommendations on overhauling the bankruptcy code. A prominent Republican, she is viewed as a potential candidate for the Supreme Court.
The bill's supporters acknowledge that some companies that would be able to reorganize under the current law would probably suffer. "The assessment was that maybe we're better off liquidating a handful of companies too soon," said Todd J. Zywicki, a professor at the George Mason University Law School, who advised Congress on the bill.
Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, chairman of the Senate's Small Business Committee, promoted an amendment giving judges discretion on how quickly small companies have to file reorganization plans, but that amendment failed to win the support yesterday of Senator Charles E. Grassley, a sponsor of the bankruptcy bill, according to a Senate official. Senator Bond settled for a change that clarified the bill's various deadlines, rather than eliminated them. 
Companies of all sizes would be affected by some other provisions in the bill. After filing under Chapter 11, companies would have only seven months to reject a property lease. Retailers would be hurt the most by that. The current system "creates instability in a strip mall," Professor Zywicki said. "It's hard for a landlord to fill space when you know the anchor tenant might not be there." 
The amount recovered by creditors could actually be diminished by the new provisions, said Harvey Miller, head of the bankruptcy practice at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, who advised Macy's on its reorganization, which took nearly four years during the 1990's. If the lease provision had been in effect, he said, unsecured creditors would have wound up with far less.
Macy's creditors would also have been hurt by a change in the law that would limit to 18 months a large debtor's exclusive right to file a reorganization plan. Such debtors now have 120 days, but a bankruptcy judge can extend this period of exclusivity indefinitely.
Supporters of the law say the change will keep management from stalling for time and will make it easier for creditors and others to offer their own proposals. But Mr. Miller said that by staying in bankruptcy longer, Macy's ultimately increased creditors' recoveries by 30 percent.
The bill would also make it impossible for a company to settle debts owed to a creditor who, according to an analysis by the National Bankruptcy Conference, "can persuade a court that it relied on a writing that was materially false respecting the debtor's financial condition."
This provision could be used by a renegade creditor, such as the financier Carl C. Icahn in the pending reorganization of Trans World Airlines, to impede a company's getting a fresh start.
Another, more obscure, provision of the bill would affect certain loans that are secured by assets. The bill would allow creditors to seize those assets, and that could make it difficult for the corporation to continue to operate. Last month, a bankruptcy judge ruled against such an asset transfer in the bankruptcy case of LTV, a steel maker that filed for bankruptcy in December. The judge noted that the transfer of assets would mean LTV would be "forced to shut its doors and cease operations."
While a technicality in the bill could have exempted LTV, the measure "could affect other companies in similar circumstances," said Bruce Bennett, a lawyer who represented LTV. 
Bankruptcy experts say they are frustrated that the changes in corporate reorganizations have received so little attention from lawmakers. "There was not significant consideration of the business provisions in any of the hearings," said J. Ronald Trost, chairman of the National Bankruptcy Conference and until recently the head of the bankruptcy practice at Sidley & Austin. "Most of these changes were swept in without any real analysis."
